status_message:
In a rural industrial zone northeast of Edmonton, a deadline draws near. Just months remain before the country's first new-built refinery in decades is set to begin operations, and more than 5,000 workers are labouring around the clock in the dense network of pipes, scaffolding and steel.

The $8.5-billion initial phase of the Sturgeon Refinery is almost complete. It's expected to be processing crude from Alberta's oil sands, and supplying low-sulphur diesel and other fuels, into Western Canadian markets before Christmas.

But away from the hum of machinery and the clanging of steel sit mostly empty grounds prepped for construction but missing the same nearby buzz of activity – a sign of the uncertainty regarding future expansions.

Globe subscribers, read about how Alberta made the Sturgeon Refinery its multi-billion dollar bet: http://trib.al/5or19jS

status_message:
Moment in time: Feb. 24, 1992- Kurt Cobain marries Courtney Love:
As rock nuptials go, the marriage of Kurt Cobain and Courtney Love was a low-key affair. At the time, Cobain was front man for grunge-rock phenomenon Nirvana, while Love was only slightly less famous as the guitarist/vocalist for the band Hole. Their impromptu ceremony was held on a cliff overlooking a Waikiki beach before eight guests, including Nirvana drummer Dave Grohl. The groom wore flannel pyjamas, while the bride wore a lace dress that had previously belonged to actress Frances Farmer. The wedding made headlines worldwide, as did the birth of their only child, Frances Bean, six months later. "Courtney and Kurt are the nineties, much more talented version of Sid and Nancy," said one unnamed music executive in a Vanity Fair profile later that year. Amid rumours of excess and drug addiction, the couple's punkrock romance came to a tragic end two years later when Cobain took his own life.
By: Andrew Ryan

status_message:
Moment in time: Feb. 23, 1909 - The first flight of the Silver Dart:
The first powered aircraft flight in Canada, and indeed in the British Empire, took off from an ice-covered Baddeck Bay, N.S. The Silver Dart looked outwardly similar to the Wright brothers' famed aircraft, which made its historic flight a few years earlier in December, 1903. The Canadian aircraft was built by Alexander Graham Bell (yes, of telephone inventor fame) with John McCurdy at the controls. It's listed as being made from such basic materials as bamboo, steel tubes and rubberized fabric, which gave off a silver sheen that inspired the plane's name. Its first successful flight travelled only about 800 metres with a peak altitude of just nine metres. The original aircraft made the first passenger flight in Canada in August, 1909, but the Silver Dart was damaged beyond repair soon after and never flew again.
By: Patrick Dell

status_message:
It took less than a year for Tim Hortons' new Brazilian owner, 3G Capital, to erase more than 50 years' worth of corporate culture.

Preparation for the purge started even before 3G's Burger King bought Tim's for $12.5-billion in December, 2014.

Before the deal closed, dozens of vice-presidents, directors and other senior staff were called in, one by one, to meet with Burger King CEO Daniel Schwartz, who would lead the merged company, RBI.

Each employee had just 15 minutes to justify their corporate existence. Some of the meetings lasted as little as five minutes. Some took buyouts. 

But once the merger was officially sealed on Dec. 12, other, more senior, managers began to disappear.

Then, early on Jan. 27, 2015, RBI executives gathered in a boardroom dubbed the "command centre." On a large screen was a detailed schedule that showed — in 20-minute increments — when hundreds of Tim Hortons employees were due to be fired.

Globe subscribers, read inside the brutal transformation of Tim Hortons here: http://trib.al/Sv8WQWp

Not a subscriber? Get your first 16 weeks for $1.99 each: http://trib.al/K4V8DRh

status_message:
Moment in time: Feb. 22, 1918 - World's tallest man born in Alton, Ill.:
Robert Pershing Wadlow came into this world weighing 8.7 pounds, but by his first birthday, he was 3 1/2-feet tall and 45 pounds. Diagnosed with hyperplasia of the pituitary gland, he reached six feet by the age of eight and just kept growing. Although Wadlow accepted the inevitable public attention - even touring with the Ringling Brothers Circus in 1936 - his affliction exacted a terrible physical toll, including a weakened immune system and minimal feeling in his lower extremities. In June, 1940, Wadlow's height was measured as 8 feet 11.1 inches tall. Several days later, he developed an infection from a blister caused by an ankle brace. Despite blood transfusions and emergency surgery, he passed away soon after at the age of 22. Nearly eight decades later, Wadlow remains the tallest person in human recorded history.
By: Andrew Ryan

status_message:
Moment in time: Feb. 21, 1941 - The death of Sir Frederick Banting:
War hero, artist, knight, medical pioneer. Frederick Banting accomplished a great deal in his 49-year life, but will forever be associated with the discovery of insulin, for which he shared the Nobel Prize with John Macleod in 1923. However, Banting did not set out to blaze a trail in the field of diabetes research. One night, as he was preparing for a planned lecture at the University of Western Ontario, he happened across a research paper that inspired an epiphany: If he could isolate a secretion from the pancreas believed responsible for controlling blood sugar, he may find the key to controlling diabetes - at that time, an untreatable, fatal disease.
Crude experiments would eventually pay off and Banting became a household name, elevated to legendary status following his death in a Newfoundland plane crash on Feb. 21, 1941.
By: Carly Weeks

status_message:
Moment in time: Feb. 17, 1966 - Take one on Good Vibrations:
The sixties had been good to Brian Wilson and the Beach Boys, but by 1965, he was ready to put the group's surfing-themed pop origins behind him. Wilson intended for Good Vibrations to appear on their ambitious album Pet Sounds, itself a feat of "wall of sound" production techniques. Little did he know when tape first rolled on this day that it would take another seven months and $50,000 in studio costs. Session musicians and bandmates alike marvelled at Wilson's ability to find the perfect instrument for his ideas (here a cello, there a Hammond organ), commit them to tape and then piece together the song from more than 90 hours of recordings. Good Vibrations is often referred to as a "pocket symphony," and it would be the last U.S. No. 1 single Wilson would write.
By: Mason Wright

status_message:
From his fateful 2014 fist pump for Quebec independence to his teary departure as Parti Québécois leader two years later, Pierre Karl Péladeau proved to be a uniquely ungifted politician. 

It's no surprise that, at only 55, he would seek a return to the one job he can't be fired from: Quebecor chief executive.

But neither he nor the company he left in 2013 are quite the same now.

Only Mr. Péladeau knows for sure if he's returning to his old job for the right reasons.

status_message:
Moment in time: Feb. 16, 1923 - The opening of King Tut's tomb:
With a tap of his chisel against a stone wall, archeologist Howard Carter opened a crack just big enough to peek through and, in doing so, unleashed a frenzy of popular interest. This moment had been more than a decade in the making, with Carter's long search for Tutankhamun's tomb having exhausted the patience, if not the pocketbook, of his wealthy sponsor, Lord Carnarvon. Undisturbed for 3,000 years, this was the most intact Egyptian tomb ever found, packed with so many material and intellectual treasures that it required more than 10 years to catalogue them all. Still, the star of the show was undoubtedly the boy king himself, with his story inspiring countless tales, movies, songs, documentaries and museum exhibitions over the ensuing decades. Even today, nearly a century later, King Tut remains known worldwide, with his death mask still a symbol for the entire field of Egyptology.
By: Ken Carriere

status_message:
Moment in time: Feb. 15, 1903 - The teddy bear makes its debut:
Whether it's your teddy, bunny or lamb-lamb, stuffed animal toys were birthed from a less cutesy place: politics. Inventor Morris Michtom named his stitched creation after then-U.S. president Theodore Roosevelt and placed the very first "teddy" in a store window on this day 114 years ago. The origins story of the toy stems from a legend around one of Roosevelt's hunting trips. It's said the president came upon an injured bear tied to a tree. Some say he shot the bear, while other historical references suggest he set it free. Whatever the truth, the stuffed offspring from that tale became an instant hit; plush toys have become a $1-billion industry in the United States. The teddy bear has since evolved, spawning dozens of colours, sizes and variations from high-end collectibles (think $10,000 Gund bears) to low-end, dollar-store trinkets.
By: Angela Pacienza

status_message:
Moment in time: Feb. 14, 1949 - Quebec asbestos workers strike:
On this day, 5,000 asbestos miners in Quebec's Eastern Townships walked off the job in a fight for better working conditions.
Their demands included a wage of $1 an hour and reducing workers' exposure to the deadly dust. Quebec's then-premier Maurice Duplessis, known for anti-union policies, declared the strike illegal and sent in provincial police.
After several months, at a time when Quebec supplied 85 per cent of the world's asbestos, U.S. employer Johns Manville Co. began to hire replacement workers; violence escalated on both sides of the dispute. The four-month strike is seen as a milestone in Quebec's labour history, demonstrating the clout of the francophone majority in a turning point that some historians say paved the way for the Quiet Revolution of the 1960s. It marked, as Pierre Trudeau later wrote, "a violent announcement that a new era had begun."
By: Tavia Grant

Moment in time: Feb. 10, 1971 - Carole King releases Tapestry:
On Feb. 9, 1971, a major earthquake shook Los Angeles, and the next day an even larger one shook the music world with the release of Carole King's second solo album, Tapestry. Recorded in just three weeks, featuring King and her cat Telemachus on the cover and friends Joni Mitchell and James Taylor singing backup, it would win four Grammys, sell 25 million copies and stay on the Billboard charts for five years. As the world hummed You've Got a Friend and I Feel the Earth Move, the album sat at No. 1 for 15 weeks, a record for a female solo artist that stood for two decades. King would later say that the upheaval of the 1970s drew fans to her music: "People around the world have told me Tapestry helped them reconnect with basic human feelings when they really needed that."
By: Elizabeth Renzetti

Moment in time: Feb. 9, 1996 - Donovan Bailey sets 50-metre-dash record:
On a Friday night in Reno, Donovan Bailey provided a prelude of what the summer would look like. The Canadian was already the 100metre world champion, winning the title in 1995 in Gothenburg, Sweden.
In the winter of 1996, he was racing indoors to improve his slow starts ahead of the Summer Olympics in Atlanta. At the Reno meet, contesting the unusual indoor distance of 50 metres - 60 metres was standard - Bailey set a world record of 5.56 seconds. "To be one of the best sprinters ever, that's what I'm working for," Bailey said afterward. There was controversy, questions whether he jumped the gun, but the record stood. Six months later, Bailey had sprinted into history. He won Olympic gold in the 100 metres with a world-record time of 9.84 seconds and won a second gold for Canada in the 4x100-metre relay.
By: David Ebner

Moment in time: Feb. 8, 1967 - 1967 Leafs lose 10 straight games:
Everyone knew the magnitude of this home game against the Detroit Red Wings. Toronto's hold on the final playoff spot was at stake and no Maple Leafs team had ever lost 10 straight games. A scoreless first period provided some hope for coach Punch Imlach's team until the wheels fell off in the second. Detroit's Norm Ullman netted a natural hat trick in less than 3 1/2 minutes and Toronto couldn't recover, losing 5-2. Imlach would be hospitalized a week later for exhaustion. "Losing 10 games in a row really frazzled him up," assistant coach King Clancy said. It may have served as a wake-up call, as Toronto rebounded in time to make the playoffs and win the Stanley Cup that year: an underdog champion and the last Cup winners Toronto has seen. For daily updates on the 1966-67 Leafs, follow @leafs67today on Twitter.
By: Mason Wright

Moment in Time: The Beatles land in America

Feb. 7, 1964: The cultural history of the world changed the moment Pan American Flight 101 touched down at New York's Kennedy Airport at 1:30 on the afternoon of Feb. 7, 1964. Three thousand shrieking teenagers greeted The Beatles' maiden trip to North America, less than 2 1/2 months after the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. By then radio stations had been stoking Fab Four furor for weeks, thanks to a pre-recorded Capitol Records interview that let every rock 'n' roll DJ in the country sound like he was interviewing the mopheads in his studio, while I Want to Hold Your Hand sold 2.6 million copies and hit No. 1. Two days later, 73 million people (almost 40 per cent of Americans) witnessed the Liverpool lads' upbeat charms on TV's The Ed Sullivan Show. Music – to say nothing of the country's mood, or what constituted a successful marketing campaign – was never the same again. – Ian Brown 

Photo: The Associated Press

Moment in time: Feb. 6, 1867 - Ontario's gold rush:
The discovery of gold on John Richardson's farm in 1866 near Madoc, Ont., northwest of Kingston, prompted a gold rush in the region that was in full swing by 1867. In early February, The Globe described several gold finds in the area, one of them on "Mr. Martin's lot, adjoining Kellar's Bridge, about two miles north of the Richardson mine." The reporter had seen with his own eyes a sample from another site on the Bobcaygeon road, "proving beyond a doubt that gold really exists in the townships north of Lindsay." The story added a note of caution, because "scarcely a day passes but we hear of some fresh discovery having been made. As a general rule, however, the discoverers are very chary about imparting any particulars, lest they should lose the reward of their skill, labour, and patience." There wasn't actually much gold though, and within a few years the boom had fizzled.
By: Richard Blackwell

Moment in time: Feb. 3, 1950 - Secrets, spying and the arrest of Klaus Fuchs:
Among Second World War spies, German physicist Klaus Fuchs was in a class of his own. Fleeing Nazi persecution in the early 1930s, Fuchs settled in Britain, where he picked up his PhD and communist sympathies. With the outbreak of war, he was interned in Britain - and later Sherbrooke, Que. - as an enemy alien. It was after a fellow physicist secured his release to work on Britain's atomic-bomb program that Soviet agents enlisted Fuchs to pass secrets. He continued after being tapped to work on the Manhattan Project, which developed the first nuclear weapons. Five years after the war, the FBI discovered he was a spy. On Feb. 3, British authorities arrested him and he served nine years in prison. Nobel-winning nuclear physicist Hans Bethe said: "Klaus Fuchs is the only physicist I know who really changed history."
By: Ian Morfitt

Moment in time: Feb. 2, 1996 - Provinces, regions gain veto power:
The act is short - just 232 words packed with consequences. In the glow of near-victory by separatists in the 1995 referendum, Prime Minister Jean Chrétien proposed and Parliament passed the Act Respecting Constitutional Amendments. British Columbia, Quebec and Ontario gained a veto over constitutional changes. Atlantic provinces representing a majority of their people could team up for a veto. Saskatchewan and Manitoba were at the mercy of more populous Alberta for the Prairie veto. Few were happy with the result.
The "desultory package of constitutional leftovers" described by one Globe and Mail columnist was layered on the Constitution, which required seven provinces representing at least 50 per cent of the population for most changes.
Constitutional reform was already difficult; the new math made it nearly impossible. No politician has dared test either formula with a Constitutional amendment since 1983.
By: Les Perreaux

Moment in time: Feb. 1, 1650 - René Descartes catches a cold:
A pioneer in the rationalist school of philosophy, René Descartes is best remembered for his remark Cogito ergo sum: "I think, therefore I am," as well as his groundbreaking work in mathematics. By 1650, Descartes was employed as a tutor by Queen Christina of Sweden. On Feb. 1, he caught a cold, the beginning of an illness that ended with his death 11 days later at the age of 53. The cause of Descartes's death went down in history as pneumonia, but researchers have always wanted more details, with subsequent theories suggesting his demise was because of Stockholm's frigid climate, the strain of his duties and even arsenic poisoning. Through his philosophy, Descartes sought to know the unknowable with logic and reasoning. More than 350 years removed, it's unlikely the exact circumstances of his death will ever be fully known.
By: Kate Hopwood

Moment in time: Jan. 31, 1985 - Leonard Cohen performs Hallelujah:
Leonard Cohen's Hallelujah had a famously uncertain pathway to fame. He struggled for years to write it, at one point smashing his head on the floor of a hotel room trying to finish it. Cohen was said to have written 80-plus verses. After presenting its accompanying album, Various Positions, to his record company in the mid-1980s, they declined to release the record, forcing Cohen to put it out independently. Its reception was lukewarm.
Then the Velvet Underground's John Cale covered Hallelujah for a compilation record in 1991. When a young songwriter named Jeff Buckley heard Cale's version, he released his own in 1994 - then died tragically three years later, propelling the song to classic status. Cohen's first live performance of Hallelujah has its own uncertainties, hindered by archival setlists' availability.
The most widely circulated date? Jan. 31, 1985, at the start of the Various Positions tour, in Mannheim, Germany.
By: Josh O'Kane

Moment in Time: Accused killer is acquitted

Jan. 30, 1867: Salacious murder trials were popular newspaper fare in the mid-19th century, as they are today. In late January, 1867, there was widespread coverage of the trial of Rev. Jeremie Babin, a Church of England minister in the village of Buckingham, Que., on the north shore of the Ottawa River. He was accused of killing his disabled sister, Mary, who had come to live with him and his wife. In April, 1866, Mary was taken out of their house in the middle of the night under mysterious circumstances, and her body was later found in a nearby river. Circumstantial evidence pointed to Babin, although he claimed he had hired a man named Leduc – who was never found – to take his sister to live in Ottawa. Still, no direct proof directly linked Babin to the crime and church officials "testified to his good character," The Globe reported. After a four-day trial, the jury deliberated for less than 90 minutes and he was acquitted. – Richard Blackwell

Moment in time: Jan. 27, 1967 - The Outer Space Treaty is signed:
It's a treaty that brought arms control to the moon. As the Cold War foes of the 1950s built, tested and deployed an ever-growing arsenal of nuclear weapons, perhaps it was inevitable they would look to the heavens.

Space offered enemies the promise of unmatched vantage points for missiles as well as untouched planets on which to amass weapons of mass destruction, the thinking went. Such fears were fed by Russia's highly secretive space program that was tied to its military. But an agreement signed on this day by the United States, Soviet Union and Britain prevented the arms race from reaching space. The Outer Space Treaty declared the moon and other celestial bodies were to be used only for peaceful purposes and that there would be no claims of sovereignty on any planet. Astronauts, the pact read, were to be regarded as "envoys of mankind," never enemy combatants.
By: Eric Atkins

Moment in time: Maher Arar wins a $10.5-million apology

Jan. 26, 2007: It was the largest compensation package ever awarded by the Canadian government to someone it had wronged. But Maher Arar, an engineer with Canadian and Syrian citizenship, had suffered a horrendous injustice. While flying to Canada from Tunis in 2002, he was detained in New York on suspicion of being linked to al-Qaeda. The Americans deported him to Syria where he spent a year in a cell the size of a grave, sharing space with rats between bouts of torture. His wife launched a campaign for his release and, in October, 2003, he was freed to return home. Three years later, a commission of inquiry found that the U.S. deportation was likely linked to inaccurate information provided by Canadian officials. The Canadian government issued a formal apology along with $10.5-million – the cost of Mr. Arar's year in hell. – Gloria Galloway

Moment in time: Jan. 25, 1996 - Victim of Alberta's eugenics program wins landmark lawsuit:
It was a sweet moment for a woman who had seen so much sadness in her life. Misdiagnosed as a "mental defective" and sterilized without her knowledge, Leilani Muir sued the Alberta government in 1993. In a ruling three years later, she was awarded $740,000 in damages, opening the door to financial settlements for other victims of the province's eugenics program.
From 1928 to 1972, the Alberta Eugenics Board authorized the sterilization of up to 3,000 people. Muir, who had an abusive mother, was packed off to a province-run school when she was 11. After a single, misleading IQ test, her fallopian tubes were removed. After her court victory, she changed her family name to O'Malley, to break with her past. She was a human-rights advocate until she died last year.
By: Tu Thanh Ha

Moment in time: Jan. 24, 1922 - The Eskimo Pie is patented:
A boy in Christian Nelson's Iowa confectionery shop couldn't decide between ice cream and a chocolate bar. That's when the light bulb went off. Nelson set about finding a way to bind chocolate to ice cream (cocoa butter would be the key). His "I-Scream Bars" were such a hit at a local picnic he partnered with a chocolate maker named Russell Stover to mass produce them.
It was Stover's wife who came up with the name "Eskimo Pie." The patent, which would later be declared invalid, originally covered any type of frozen material covered with candy and even the word "Pie." Financial problems would eventually force the sale of the company. Now, the bars are sold by Nestlé and are not as popular as they once were. After all, there are a lot of ice cream bars and as delicious as they might be, that name might leave a bad taste in people's mouths.
By: Dave McGinn

Moment in time: Jan. 23, 1867 - Railways expand in Nova Scotia:
Railways were the physical links that held together the settlements of a new nation. In January, 1867, the eastern rail network was expanding as engineer Sandford Fleming worked to finish an extension of the existing Nova Scotia Railway line between Halifax and Truro, to reach Pictou on the Northumberland Strait. More than 20 miles was complete, The Globe reported, and everyone who rode the new stretch noted its "remarkable smoothness and ease with which the cars travel" and the "immense strength as well as the beauty of the masonry along the line of road." Work was about to begin on another branch to the Annapolis Valley - a project that "in conjunction with Confederation, would certainly double land values in Western Nova Scotia," The Globe said. The NSR became part of the Intercolonial Railway that linked the Maritime provinces to Ontario and Quebec.
By: Richard Blackwell

Moment in time: Jan. 20, 1961- John F. Kennedy's inauguration:
We mostly forget JFK won the (rigged?) election by a hair. We forget the eight inches of snow that fell the night before, almost wrecking the inauguration. (They used Boy Scouts and flamethrowers and much else to clear the streets.) We try to forget some of what followed: The Bay of Pigs, Vietnam, Dallas. But we remember the words. Speechwriter Ted Sorensen steeped himself in the Gettysburg Address, almost equalling it. Both were masterpieces of brevity, balance, rhythm, determination: "The torch has been passed to a new generation of Americans - born in this century, tempered by war, disciplined by a hard and bitter peace. ... We shall pay any price, bear any burden, meet any hardship, support any friend, oppose any foe. ... Ask not what your country can do for you. ... ." His young, strong face, his Boston brogue, Jackie. The day was glorious and Camelot was born.
By: John Ibbitson

For 70 years, the United States has been the architect of a system of rules for global commerce. With Donald Trump's inauguration, it becomes the Middle Kingdom of trade: a country that sees itself as the most important market in the world, able to demand that others bow and give ground to do business there.

In Mr. Trump's world, the United States is the centre of global trade, the big market where everyone wants to sell. Others must make concessions to enter.

It would be a mistake for Canadians to think of this approach to trade as the impulse of a deal maker, like a 3 a.m. tweet.

Moment in time: Jan. 19, 1943 - Canada welcomes a newborn princess:
Technically, it wasn't Canada. With Princess Juliana of Holland scheduled to give birth there, the maternity ward of Ottawa Civic Hospital had been declared extraterritorial. That way, the royal newborn would be Dutch, full stop. Dual nationality might have compromised the baby's place in the line of succession - and for the House of Orange-Nassau, this was an anxious time. Shortly after the Nazi invasion of her country, Princess Juliana arrived in Canada to live out the war with her daughters. Technicalities aside, Princess Margriet became the first and still the only royal to be born in North America. She was named after a type of daisy that had become a symbol of the Dutch resistance. When Canadian soldiers liberated Holland two years later, her mother thanked the family's adoptive home with another famous national flower, by sending 100,000 tulip bulbs.
By: Eric Andrew-Gee

Moment in time: Jan. 18, 2015 - The 'deflategate' debacle:
It was an otherwise forgettable game. Little did fans know the 45-7 rout of the Indianapolis Colts by New England Patriots in the AFC championship would devolve into one of the biggest controversies in National Football League history. After it was discovered that underinflated balls were used in the game, everything from the ideal weight of a football to what Patriots superstar quarterback Tom Brady was hiding in his text messages - which he refused to relinquish and later destroyed - became topics of debate. Blame fell initially on a low-level Patriots equipment manager, but Brady and his head coach, Bill Belichick, became the face of the scandal. After a protracted investigation bordering on the absurd, Brady was suspended for four games. That ban led to a year-long legal battle, ending in the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, where it was upheld.
By: David Leeder

Moment in time: Jan. 17, 1966 - NBC greenlights The Monkees:
When Britain gave the world the Beatles, the United States responded with the Monkees. NBC fast-tracked creation of the sitcom/pop quartet that began with a Variety ad seeking "four insane boys age 17-21." After screening more than 400 respondents, producers settled on the prefab four: Guitarist Mike Nesmith and bassist Peter Tork were low-rung folk fixtures, while drummer Micky Dolenz had never played the drums and Brit import Davy Jones stuck with vocals and tambourine. The Monkees kicked off NBC's 1966 fall season and was an instant ratings hit - and even presaged the modern music video since every episode interpreted at least two songs. The show also sustained a flurry of top-10 hits, including Last Train to Clarksville and I'm a Believer, but by early 1968 the novelty had worn off and the Monkees were relegated to the remainder bin.
By: Andrew Ryan

Moment in time: Jan. 16, 1867 - Globe bulks up for Confederation:
With 1867 likely to be "the most eventful year in the history of the British North American provinces," The Globe told its readers it would beef up its journalistic chops. In a front-page notice, proprietor George Brown said the paper would set up "a large corps of short-hand reporters" to file from the new federal and provincial legislatures. Arrangements had already been made to get same-day European news via the Atlantic cable, and special staff would be sent to London to follow the Confederation bill through the Imperial Parliament. "No expense will be spared in the employment of able correspondents at important points, and in dispatching reporters to distant places whenever their services may be required," Brown said. New printing presses were to be added, and a better quality of paper used. But the subscription price was unchanged: $6 a year for the daily and $2 for the weekly edition.
By: Richard Blackwell

Moment in time: Jan. 13, 1898 - Emile Zola's 'J'accuse...!' letter is printed:
J'accuse...! The headline appeared in large bold type on the front page of France's L'Aurore on this day. In an open letter addressed to the French President, celebrated writer Emile Zola railed against the trumped-up treason charges and conviction of army officer Alfred Dreyfus. Zola hoped his letter would bait authorities into suing him for libel so that he could expose the anti-Semitism and corruption of the court-martial. They did. He lost the case, and fled to England, while Dreyfus was transported to the notorious Devil's Island and placed in solitary confinement. In 1906, the verdict was annulled and Dreyfus proclaimed innocent. The army took almost a century from his conviction to do the same. In 1995, it publicly admitted the Dreyfus affair was a "military conspiracy" based on false evidence against an "innocent man."
By: Ian Morfitt

Moment in time: Dec. 23, 1971 - Corey Haim born in Toronto:
From any angle, the camera loved Corey Haim. The Toronto native was still in grade school when he cut his teeth on the CBC series The Edison Twins. In short order, Haim was appearing in films such as Silver Bullet and Murphy's Romance before his breakout in the 1987 feature The Lost Boys. Even in a cast that included future notables such as Kiefer Sutherland and Corey Feldman, Haim commanded attention. For the next few years, Haim worked steadily but fell into a spiral of drug addiction. By the midnineties, he was relegated to low-budget features such as Snowboard Academy.
Haim reunited with Feldman for the 2007 A&E reality series The Two Coreys, which largely chronicled the formers' efforts to stay sober. In March, 2010, Haim collapsed at his mother's L.A. apartment and died soon after at the hospital. He was 38.
By: Andrew Ryan

Moment in time: Dec. 21, 2012 - The first video to hit one-billion views on YouTube:
As high-speed Internet access became a necessity, a video on YouTube was inevitably going to hit one billion views. What surprised the world was that the honour wasn't bestowed on Justin Bieber or Taylor Swift.
Instead, it was the singer Psy who galloped to the milestone in only five months with Gangnam Style. You've seen it: A clip of a blue-tuxedoed South Korean man doing a dance best described as riding a horse very suggestively, sparking the first global dance sensation since the Macarena. That the song is catchy is beside the point; everyone wanted to see that crazy dance. Dozens of YouTube videos have reached the one-billion mark today, but Gangnam Style is still ahead by hundreds of millions of views and closing in on three billion.
And Psy? His viral moves have made him a multimillionaire.
By: Cliff Lee

Moment in time: Dec. 20, 1957 - Elvis gets drafted:
With his hit Jailhouse Rock riding high on the charts, Elvis Presley received his draft-board notice for mandatory service in the United States Army. After a deferment to finish his movie King Creole, the superstar singer traded in his blue suede shoes for army boots on March 24, 1958. Upon completion of six months basic training at Fort Hood in Texas (which was interrupted by the death of his beloved mother, Gladys), Private Elvis Presley at the Brooklyn Army Terminal spoke to a media swarm - the well-mannered Southerner addressed reporters as "sir" and "ma'am" - before shipping off to Bremerhaven, West Germany. There, he was met by five television news teams, two newsreel operators, a horde of reporters and photographers, and some 1,500 all-shook-up fans. Never has a private been more public.
By: Brad Wheeler

Moment in time: Dec. 19, 1973 - The joke that sparked a toilet paper crisis:
Talk about potty humour gone wrong. Shortages - of gasoline, electricity, even onions - were the norm in 1973. So Johnny Carson couldn't resist joking about news that originated from a U.S. senator that a reduction in pulp paper could mean a shortage of toilet paper. "You know, we've got all sorts of shortages these days," Carson told viewers. "But have you heard the latest? I'm not kidding. I saw it in the papers. There's a shortage of toilet paper!" Panic ensued. People started hoarding the stuff. Stores raised prices and imposed purchasing limits. The more toilet paper flew off shelves, the more it made the myth look true. Finally, Carson had to address the matter.
"I just picked up an item from the paper and enlarged it somewhat ... there is no shortage." We fret about fake news on Facebook today, but we've always been gullible. Nothing can wipe that fact away.
By: Dave McGinn

Moment in time: Dec. 16, 1977 - Saturday Night Fever infects moviegoers:
Well, you could tell by the way they used his walk, the makers of Saturday Night Fever had no time to talk. Or, at least, no time for boring ol' dialogue. Instead, director John Badham introduced the world to the wonder that is Tony Manero via the Bee Gees tune Staying Alive, and the rest is cinematic history. At the height of its buzz, Saturday Night Fever was deemed the musical of the century, disco was a never-get-old sensation and star John Travolta could do no wrong. These truths would all be handily overturned within a decade. (The film is far grittier and music-less than most remember; disco would be declared "dead" on July 12, 1979, at Chicago's Disco Demolition Night; and Travolta would soon be making goo-goo eyes at wisecracking babies in Look Who's Talking.) But for a brief, shining moment, it seemed the music would never stop.
By: Barry Hertz

Moment in time: Dec. 15, 1944 - Glenn Miller's mysterious disappearance:
Glenn Miller walked away from his hit-making band, wife and two children to join the U.S. army in 1942. The trombonist and composer wanted to cheer the fighting forces with the same performances that had made him a star and made In the Mood and Tuxedo Junction the soundtrack for the swing era. He formed the Army Air Force Band, a 42-piece orchestra, to entertain the troops and raise money for the fight against Nazi Germany. But, on a flight to Paris from England on this day in 1944, his plane went missing and he was presumed dead. The aircraft was never found and theories on the cause of the crash include friendly fire, bad weather and engine ice, a debate that has proved almost as durable as his music.
By: Eric Atkins

Moment in time: Dec. 14, 1992-Ralph Klein becomes Alberta's premier: 
Ralph Klein engendered wide support in part because Albertans believed him sincere, and very human. He drank and gambled, and said as much.  He was also decisive and had superb political instincts.  And he was lucky – oil and natural gas prices mostly trended upward through his 14 years in office. When Klein became premier, it was a repudiation of the PC party establishment and a call to action on tackling the growing debt. His government moved quickly with an agenda of spending cuts and privatization. Though many said Klein lacked long-term vision, small-c conservatives still miss his focus on the bottom line and his reverence for the "Marthas and Henrys" of Alberta. In the end, Klein backed down only when necessary – and not often. "You can call me every rotten, stinking name under the sun, but I ain't going to blink." 
By: Kelly Cryderman

Moment in time: Dec.12, 1980 - Apple Computer Inc. goes public:
When Steven P. Jobs was 25 years old, he filed a prospectus with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission seeking to take public the computer company he co-founded with his pal Steve Wozniak a few years earlier in 1976. Apple Computer Inc. wanted to sell about 4.6 million shares for about $22 (U.S.) each with hopes to raise about $82-million - they actually raised $100-million and the shares sold out immediately. Comparing that prospectus with recent results reveals what a good deal those shares were. In 1980, the company held four patents. Today, it holds more than 10,000 and files for about 2,000 a year. In 1980, Apple spent $7-million on R&D, compared with $10-billion in 2016. In its 1980 fiscal year, Apple recorded $117-million in revenue. At the end of 2016, it announced $215-billion in revenue, and $45-billion in net income. Jobs is gone, but in its 40th year, the company is going strong.
By: Shane Dingman

Moment in time: Dec. 7, 1995 - NASA spacecraft Galileo reaches Jupiter:
Six years after it left Earth, NASA spacecraft Galileo reached Jupiter on this day. Named after Italian Renaissance-era astronomer Galileo Galilei, it was the first spacecraft to orbit the enigmatic gas giant and study its atmosphere. The orbiter had previously launched a probe to penetrate dense, turbulent cloud cover and relayed data about Jupiter's weather and air composition, among other things. And when the orbiter arrived at the planet, the probe descended into the atmosphere at a speed of about 250,000 km/h. Exactly two years later, the mission was extended but shifted focus to Jupiter's moons, where it discovered a possible ocean of water under Europa's icy crust and a lava fountain on Jupiter's innermost moon, Io. The orbiter's mission eventually ended in 2003 when it was purposely plunged into the massive planet.
By: Julien Gignac

Moment in time: Dec. 5, 1892 - John Thompson becomes Canada's fourth prime minister:
John Thompson was one of Canada's great might-have-beens.
Though he hated politics, conspicuously able - and honest - men were rare in the early life of our country, and so the Nova Scotia lawyer dutifully served as Halifax alderman, provincial attorney-general, premier, judge (happily) and (under protest) John A. Macdonald's justice minister and indispensable lieutenant - "my one great discovery," Macdonald called him. He refused the prime ministership when Macdonald died, knowing the party would resent his Catholicism, but soon succeeded the ailing John Abbott because there was simply no one else. Quiet, tolerant, rigorous, passionately nationalist, reluctant to dispense or receive patronage, Thompson gave Canada its first criminal code. But he worked himself to death, succumbing to a heart attack at Windsor Castle when he was only 49 after two years in office.
The Conservative Party never recovered from the loss.

Moment in time: Dec. 1, 1988 - Benazir Bhutto becomes prime minister of Pakistan:
Destiny and determination drove Benazir Bhutto to become the first elected female leader of a Muslim country. The eldest child of Pakistan People's Party founder and prime minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, she was born in Karachi but educated at Harvard and Oxford. Following personal setbacks - including the hanging of her father in 1979 - she moved in 1984 to London, where she ran the PPP in exile. She returned to Pakistan in 1986 to campaign for "open" elections, which accelerated when dictator Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq died in a plane crash in 1988. Three months after giving birth to her first child, Ms. Bhutto became Pakistan's 11th prime minister and subsequently served two terms (1988-90 and 1993-96). After another extended exile, she was planning a third run for office when she was assassinated in December, 2007.
By: Andrew Ryan

Moment in time: Nov. 28, 1975 -  Bobby Orr unexpectedly plays his last game as a Bruin:
It seemed like just another game among the several hundred that would be played in the 1975-76 NHL season. The visiting Boston Bruins won 6-4 over the New York Rangers, with Boston's Bobby Orr, the previous season's scoring champion, counting a goal and an assist. The next day, the greatest defenceman ever to play the game - perhaps the best player at any position - tried to stand up in a Boston restaurant and his left knee locked.
Two days later, he was on the operating table. "I never played another game as a Bruin," he wrote in Orr: My Story. He came back to be MVP of the 1976 Canada Cup, but his knees worsened in the 20 games he managed over three seasons with the Chicago Blackhawks. At 30, he was finished. 
By: Roy MacGregor

Moment in time: Nov. 25, 1988 - Powerful earthquake shakes Eastern Canada:
It was a Friday evening around suppertime when the biggest earthquake to hit eastern North America in more than half a century struck.
The convulsion, whose ripple effects were felt as far away as Detroit, Boston and the Annapolis Valley on Nova Scotia's western shore, resulted in surprisingly little damage and no one was killed or seriously injured. But many people feared the worst as windows shattered, walls cracked and a landslide caused a hole along Route 172 in Quebec (pictured below). Media outlets reported a deluge of calls from anxious citizens. The epicentre of the quake - a 5.9 on the Richter scale - was located near Chicoutimi, Que., in the Saguenay region about 150 kilometres north of Quebec City. There were scattered power outages. A former City Hall in Montreal East was left with severe damage to its masonry cladding. For Geological Survey of Canada scientists, the event provided a bonanza of research material helpful in updating the building code. 
By: Bertrand Marotte

Moment in time: Nov. 24, 1974 - Ancient hominin 'Lucy' discovered:
On a hot and dusty morning in the Afar region of Ethiopia, American paleoanthropologists Donald Johanson and Tom Gray were heading back to their Land Rover after surveying a fossil site. Johanson spotted a small piece of bone lying on the slope of a gully. It proved to be the tip of an elbow.
Nearby, they located fragments of a skull, a femur, pelvis, ribs, vertebrae and a lower jaw. The spectacular find would eventually yield a 40-per-cent complete skeleton that belonged to an upright-walking female from a previously unknown species of hominin called Australopithecus afarensis. While Johanson and his teammates were celebrating at camp that night, a cassette with the Beatles song Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds played repeatedly, inspiring the fossil's nickname. Buried in sediments deposited some 3.2 million years ago, Lucy is a precursor to, and possible direct ancestor of, the genus Homo, which includes humans. 
By: Ivan Semeniuk

Moment in time: Nov. 22, 1968 - The first interracial kiss on U.S. network television:
Uhura was never supposed to kiss Kirk. Nichelle Nichols - who played Lieutenant Uhura in the original Star Trek - revealed in her autobiography, Beyond Uhura, the script had Mr. Spock locking lips with her in the episode titled Plato's Stepchildren. But as Nichols puts it, William Shatner declared, "If anyone's going to get to kiss Uhura, it's going to be me - I mean Captain Kirk." The director panicked once he realized its interracial nature.
Network executives were consulted and it was decided to shoot the scene twice: one with the kiss, one without. There were 36 takes in total, most of them used to redo the kiss. Eventually, there was only time to shoot the nokiss ending twice. The next day, it became clear which ending they had to use: Shatner had crossed his eyes in the only usable version of the kiss-less shot.
Despite concerns of backlash, Nichols says she received "one of the largest batches of fan mail," all of it positive. 
By: Madeleine White

Moment in time: Nov. 21, 1877 - Edison invents the phonograph:
It's an invention that, more than a century later, still delights and amazes. Thomas Edison announced on this day in 1877 that he had come up with a way to record and play sounds with a needle and a rotating cylinder.
Edison, a prolific inventor whose legacy includes light bulbs and motion pictures, made his first recordings at his New Jersey laboratory on a contraption with a drum covered with paper. His phonograph would be improved and better marketed by others, but the wonder of Edison's records remains - every groove containing a microscopic landscape of peaks and valleys that hold and reproduce music in a way many enjoy even after the waves of more convenient mediums that have followed. Fittingly, even the first song Edison recorded has proved enduring - Mary Had a Little Lamb. 
By: Eric Atkins

Moment in time: Nov. 17, 1970 - Patent filed for the computer mouse:
Doug Engelbart earned a patent for a "X-Y position indicator for a display system" nine years after he got bored during a seminar on computer graphics and jotted down the idea for a device to interact with images on a computer screen. He developed the technology - which would later be called a mouse - in 1963 at the Stanford Research Institute in Menlo Park, Calif. In 1968, he wowed an audience of 1,000 computer scientists at a demo in which the mouse, windows, hypertext and even video conferencing were combined in one computer. But it wasn't until the original Macintosh launched in 1984 that a mouse became standard equipment for a personal computer. In 2004, Engelbart told mouse-maker Logitech that he had no idea who coined the name: "I wasn't the kind of person that made up the names for what we were going to call it, just, oh, gadget. That name just stuck."  
By: Shane Dingman

Moment in time: Nov. 14, 1972 - Dow Jones closes above 1,000 for the first time:
Traders cheered on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange as the Dow Jones industrial average closed above 1,000 - hitting 1,003.16 - for the first time in its 76-year history. Obviously, the surging Dow meant the economy was headed upward - or did it? Within months, a vicious bear market would maul stock prices, knocking them down as much as 40 per cent.
A cavalcade of economic and political woes, ranging from oil crises and Watergate to spiralling inflation and stagnant growth, would keep the Dow mired in three-digit territory for most of the following decade. It would not be until 1982 that the benchmark index would decisively break through 1,000.
Decades later, the 1972 mania continues to remind us of just how wrong markets can be about what lies ahead. 
By: Ian McGugan

Moment in time: Sept. 28, 1983 - The Big Chill premieres in theatres:
The must-see movie at the Festival of Festivals (now the Toronto International Film Festival), The Big Chill generated both glowing reviews and lineups at the box office. Directed by Lawrence Kasdan, the story focused on a group of former college pals reunited when one of their classmates (played by Kevin Costner in a fleeting funeral scene) dies by suicide.
Boasting a cast that included Kevin Kline, Glenn Close and William Hurt, the film details a boozy, pot-fuelled weekend as the baby boomers reminisce, rekindle old flames and wonder what happened to their Summer of Love ideals. Although it received three Oscar nominations, including one for best picture, the film drew more public attention for its sixties-era soundtrack, best remembered in the scene where the ensemble preps dinner to the Temptations's 1966 hit Ain't Too Proud to Beg. 
By: Kate Hopwood

Moment in time: Sept. 27, 1888 - Vancouver's Stanley Park opened to the public:
Canadian Pacific Railway wanted to use the land "for docks, warehouses and buildings," but Vancouver's founding fathers saw something more promising in the thick, green rain forest cloaking the peninsula at the entrance to the harbour. Instead of industrializing the site, the first city council, at its first meeting, passed a resolution asking Ottawa to lease it to Vancouver as a park for all time. Ottawa agreed, and for the annual fee of $1, Stanley Park, a 400-hectare oasis, was created. Named after then-governor-general Lord Frederick Stanley, it opened in 1888. The seawall walkway, totem pole display, rose gardens, aquarium, beaches and bike paths now draw eight million visitors a year. In 2014, TripAdvisor named it the best park in the world.
By: Mark Hume

Moment in time: Sept. 26, 2014 - Hong Kong's 'Umbrella Revolution' makes headlines worldwide:
The movement had no real name at first, just an idea: Hong Kong needed to be able to choose its own chief executive, the city's powerful top leader, without interference from authoritarian China. But when a group rallied around the city's legislative complex, police responded with pepper spray on Sept. 26, 2014, and, two days later, with tear gas. The protesters used umbrellas as flimsy shields. The images of a harsh crackdown, and fears that it had been directed by Beijing, galvanized the Umbrella Revolution. Hundreds of thousands took to the streets, shutting down the central business area for months. They failed to end Beijing's oversight of the chief executive selection process. But they gave birth to a new independence movement, which sent four candidates to the local legislative council earlier this month.
By: Nathan VanderKlippe

Moment in time: Sept. 23, 1980 - Bob Marley performs his final concert:
Before Bob Marley was packaged comfortably for mass audiences in greatest-hits CDs and dorm-room posters, he and the Wailers were a regular touring band trying to grow their fanbase. At Madison Square Garden in September, 1980, they spent two nights opening for the Commodores, hoping to cultivate new listeners. Marley collapsed the next morning during a jog in Central Park; in hospital, he learned that cancer had spread throughout his body. He forged ahead, playing two nights later at the Stanley Theatre in Pittsburgh. "If you keep it up like this, we'll have to come here every year," Marley told the crowd after Get Up Stand Up, closing the show. "Every week, every month. Thank you." But he didn't play Pittsburgh, or anywhere else, ever again. He died eight months later.
By: Josh O'Kane

Moment in time: Sept. 22, 1985 - Nelson, Mellencamp and Young stage first Farm Aid benefit concert:
After some of the music industry's biggest stars managed to turn the world's eyes to the plight of Ethiopian famine victims in 1985, Bob Dylan suggested some of that attention might well be focused on the plight of family farmers. American farmers were struggling under crushing burdens of debt, depressed commodity prices and dropping land values while, paradoxically, harvests were at record levels. The situation prompted Willie Nelson to approach the governor of Illinois about holding a benefit concert. Nelson, John Mellencamp and Neil Young combined to host the first Farm Aid, a 12-hour concert that brought together the three organizers, plus Johnny Cash, Bob Dylan, Waylon Jennings, Kenny Rogers and Joni Mitchell. The concert raised $9-million, a tiny fraction of the $55-million raised by Live Aid. But Farm Aid is in its 31st year, having held the 2016 concert earlier this month in Virginia.
The headliners? Young, Mellencamp and Nelson, who is now 83. 
By: Wendy Cox

Moment in time: Sept. 21, 1937 - Tolkien's The Hobbit first published:
Yes, there's a fierce dragon and great battles, a powerful wizard and hidden treasures, but at its heart, J.R.R. Tolkien's The Hobbit, or There and Back Again is a small story. First published in 1937, when he was a middle-aged academic at Oxford, Tolkien's first novel is now a classic of both children's and fantasy writing. It tells the story of a simple-hearted hobbit named Bilbo Baggins, who leaves his cozy hobbit hole and ventures out, with a baker's dozen of dwarfs and a wizard to reclaim a vast treasure from a malevolent dragon named Smaug. Partway through the novel, separated from his friends and lost in the tunnels beneath the Misty Mountains, Bilbo finds a strange ring - a moment that would eventually form the foundation of Tolkien's masterpiece, The Lord of the Rings.
By: Mark Medley

Moment in time: Sept. 20, 1967 - Queen Elizabeth 2 launched at Clydebank, Scotland:
The last of the great transatlantic ocean liners made an auspicious entry into this world. Before several thousand spectators along the River Clyde, the Queen introduced the ship and declared, "May God bless her and all who sail in her," before pushing the button sending a bottle of champagne smashing into the behemoth's bow. Although the Queen Elizabeth 2 was conceived as a posh cruise ship - it had more than 1,000 cabins, along with multiple cocktail bars and nightclubs - the craft was pressed into military service in 1982 when it was used to transport British troops during the Falklands War.
The Cunard cruise line retired the ship in 2008, but plans to convert it into a luxury hotel stalled. At last check, the QE2 was rusting away in a Dubai harbour. 
By: Andrew Ryan

Moment in time: Sept. 19, 1982 - The emoticon is born:
The emoticon as we know it - an anthropomorphic expression generated by digital type or code - is an artifact of the digital age. Inventor Scott Fahlman posted it on an early Internet university message board at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh at 11:44 a.m. on Sept. 19, 1982. We even know why: Digital communication needs more than words to express the nuance of feelings. Fahlman's :-) was a joke indicator, and :-(was a "for serious" marker. The emojis and emoticons popular on social media today share a direct lineage to that concept: There are "crying laughter" emojis to denote mockery and fire emojis to highlight a hot takedown. There's some evidence the :-) symbol existed before Fahlman popularized it, but he is responsible for its modern, digital function.
By: Shane Dingman

Moment in time: Sept. 16, 2004 - Bettman announces NHL season will be delayed because of work stoppage:
For the hockey world, it was a dark day that eventually became a dark season. NHL commissioner Gary Bettman announced the 2004-05 season would be delayed because of a work stoppage, two days after Canada won its first World Cup of Hockey in front of a full house in Toronto. At issue was the NHL's desire for a salary cap to control player salaries, something the NHL Players' Association fought bitterly for the next five months. The deadlock led to a cancelled season, a first for any major North American pro sports league. The result: the NHL broke the union, with long-time executive director Bob Goodenow forced out as players acquiesced to Bettman's demand. The cap-based linkage system that was instituted the next season remains largely intact 11 years later.
By: James Mirtle

Moment in time: Sept. 14, 1927 - Dancer Isadora Duncan killed in bizarre car accident:
When Isadora Duncan danced, it was an elegant, free-spirited revolution. Barefoot and wrapped in flowing, Greek-inspired costumes, Duncan rejected the conventional rigidity of ballet. She was a pioneer of modern dance, wowing - and sometimes shocking - audiences with her bohemian moves (and philosophies - feminism, free love, Communism). Born in the late 1870s in San Francisco, Duncan left California for Chicago, New York and then Europe - where she was a sensation. She founded dance schools; her students were dubbed "the Isadorables." For all the light and ecstasy in her dance, her life was heavy with tragedy. Her two young children drowned when their car fell into the Seine. Another baby died. She later married a Russian poet who killed himself. Duncan's life itself came to a tragic end: While riding in a convertible, her long scarf became entangled in the back wheel, killing her.
By: Marsha Lederman

Moment in time: Sept. 13, 1981 - Months after Terry Fox's death, fundraising run in his name held for first time:
Terry Fox's Marathon of Hope may have come to an end on Sept. 1, 1980, outside of Thunder Bay, but just more than a year later, many more feet joined his epic quest to conquer cancer in the first annual Terry Fox Run. Though Fox had succumbed to cancer almost three months prior, 300,000 participants gathered at more than 760 sites across Canada and many others around the world, to walk, run or cycle their way to raising $3.5-million for cancer research. The brainchild of Isadore Sharp, chairman and chief executive officer of Four Seasons Hotels and Resorts, the Terry Fox Run - which its namesake insisted be non-competitive - is held every September in more than 50 countries and is the world's largest one-day fundraiser for cancer research, which has raised more than $650-million since that first event.
By: Paul Attfield

Moment in time: Sept. 12, 1940 - Lascaux cave paintings, engravings and drawings discovered:
Perhaps the best of the several stories about the discovery of the Lascaux cave art in southwestern France involves a dog named Robot.
Seems the mutt was romping in the woods with four teenage boys when a rabbit caught his eye. Pursuit ensued, with the rabbit ducking down a hole.
Curious, the boys dropped stones into the hole to get a sense of its depth.
Then, screwing up their courage, they began to wiggle through the opening, discovering it was actually a narrow shaft 15 metres deep. Could this be, they wondered, a tunnel to treasure? The answer was yes. Except the trove wasn't gold francs but hundreds of vivid images of Paleolithic beasts, rendered with great skill and sophistication 17,000 years ago on a warren of cave walls.
Picasso would visit this "prehistoric Sistine Chapel" and leave it stunned and humbled. "They've invented everything," he said. 
By: James Adams

Moment in time: Sept. 9, 1930 - Percy Williams sets world record in 100 metres:
Percy Williams defied the odds - and his doctors - to become the world's fastest human. After surviving a bout of rheumatic fever in his early teens, the slight Vancouver native was told by physicians to avoid all forms of strenuous exercise. Instead, Williams trained as a sprinter and earned a place on the Canadian Olympic team that competed at the 1928 Games in Amsterdam, where he won gold in the 100- and 200-metre events. Williams's finest hour came two years later at a Toronto track meet, where he ran the 100 metres in a scorching 10.3 seconds - a world record that would stand several years until broken by U.S. track star Jesse Owens. Sadly, Williams's running career, and life, went downhill in years to follow. Stricken by depression and arthritis, he took his own life in 1982.
By: Andrew Ryan

Moment in time: Sept. 7, 1986 - Desmond Tutu named Archbishop of Cape Town:
Soon after Desmond Tutu was chosen as Archbishop of Cape Town, making history as the first black leader of the Anglican Church in South Africa, people began to call him, rather casually, "the Arch." It would have prompted only a giggle from him. Humour and irreverence were the secret weapons of the eloquent Nobel Peace Prize winner, who delivered some of the most powerful blows in the long struggle against apartheid. With his trademark wit and laughter, he led marches and boycotts that shook the white minority government. He coined the term "Rainbow Nation" and, after apartheid's defeat, headed the Truth and Reconciliation Commission that tried to heal its wounds. Unlike many liberation heroes who fell into corruption, Tutu has remained a moral beacon since his retirement, speaking out bravely against government abuses, poverty and injustice at home and worldwide.
By: Geoffrey York
"There goes the 'hood" Today's editorial cartoon by Brian Gable. From Globe Opinion

Moment in time: Sept. 6, 1995 - Ripken breaks Gehrig's consecutive-game record:
In baseball's unrelenting 162-game season, there's no time to rest or recover. So eventually, even the best players yield to injury or age and take a day off - except for Cal Ripken. Over more than 16 years, the stoic Baltimore Orioles infielder didn't miss a game. And while he was a first-ballot Hall of Famer who hit 431 home runs, his most memorable performance was just another day at the office. On Sept. 6, 1995, with U.S. President Bill Clinton looking on, the 35-year-old shortstop surpassed Lou Gehrig's hallowed streak by playing in his 2,131st consecutive game. When the record became official, halfway through the fifth inning, his teammates pushed him forward and the Iron Man ran a slow, joyful victory lap, celebrating a feat that now seems beyond comprehension - in 2015, only one player managed to play every game. 
By: John Allemang

On Friday, the Real Estate Board of Greater Vancouver published its first monthly sales report since the British Columbia government imposed a hefty 15-per-cent tax on purchases of homes by foreign buyers a month ago, and the numbers looked pretty shocking. 

Sales slumped 23 per cent in August from July, and were down 26 per cent compared with a year earlier. In fact, the supposedly booming Vancouver housing market is suddenly generating sales that are below the 10-year average for the month.

But the numbers deserve attention beyond the mere schadenfreude it will certainly illicit from some observers outside of Vancouver or even British Columbia. And there's a danger in reading too much into this single month of data – especially given that those data appear to confirm the worst fears of some observers, David Parkinson writes.

General Motors has been vital to life in Oshawa for almost a century. In the 1970s, Oshawa's mayor John Henry recalls, most men who left high school went to work at GM or one of the myriad of nearby auto plants that fed the giant.

The future of the city's one remaining car plant with its two assembly lines is now in grave doubt, as company management and the union that represents workers face off in talks on a new contract.

At stake are 2,460 direct hourly paid jobs on the two assembly lines in Oshawa, plus thousands more jobs at supplier plants in the city, the surrounding region and across the country; about $1-billion in annual tax revenues for all three levels of government; and the future of manufacturing in what was once the Motor City of Canada.

Moment in time: Aug. 31, 1978 - A Lebanese imam's disappearance still inflames the Middle East:
When Musa al-Sadr, the venerated leader of Lebanon's Shiites, failed to return from a visit with Moammar Gadhafi in Libya, his followers were distraught. While some clung to the hope that the charismatic figure was a "hidden imam" who would one day return - similar to their ninth-century Mahdi - most believed it was foul play. Suspicion fell on many, but it was the Iranian Shia leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, then in exile, who had the greatest motive. The two imams strongly disagreed on whether Islam should govern a country and there was speculation that the Iranian-born al-Sadr, still popular in his birthplace, might confound the radical Khomeini plans that would soon unfold. Perversely, the Lebanese loss of their beloved imam radicalized a generation of young Shiites who would create the militant Hezbollah movement, one of Iran's greatest affiliates.
From: Patrick Martin

Moment in time: Aug. 30, 1988 - Canadian marathon swimmer Vicki Keith completes her crossing of all five Great Lakes:
Just keep swimming. While her body told her to stop, Canadian distance swimmer Vicki Keith's mind told her to fight back. Keith kept swimming in the shivering water of Lake Ontario until she hit land. In the span of just two months, she swam across all five Great Lakes, becoming the first person to accomplish the feat. When Keith swam, she did so with a purpose, helping to raise more than $1-million to date for children with physical disabilities and testing the bounds of human possibility. Her nearly 24-hour-long journey through Lake Ontario was exhausting but worthwhile. "Every muscle in my body hurt," Keith told Chatelaine Magazine in 1989. "I had stomach cramps. I had cramps in almost every part of my body. And you know what?
I never felt better in my life."
By: Mayaz Alam

Moment in time: Aug. 29, 1967 - Final episode of the Fugitive breaks audience records:
On a hot August night, the last chapter of The Fugitive turned TV viewing into a communal experience. Viewers were invested in the story of Dr. Richard Kimble, played by a dour David Janssen, who was unjustly convicted of murdering his wife. After escaping custody in the pilot, Kimble spent four seasons, from 1963 to 1967, chasing the real killer - the enigmatic one-armed man - with dogged Lieutenant Gerard (played by CBC fixture Barry Morse) in hot pursuit. In the closer, Kimble finally caught his nemesis and was exonerated. All told, the finale was viewed in nearly 26 million U.S. households by more than 78 million people, making it the most-watched program up to that point.
The ratings record stood for 13 years - until the famous denouement to Dallas's "Who Shot JR?" storyline in 1980. 
By: Andrew Ryan

Moment in time: Aug. 26, 1968 - DNC begins in Chicago:
With the United States mired in an increasingly unpopular war in Vietnam and rent by conflict at home, a deeply divided Democratic Party gathered to pick its 1968 presidential nominee. President Lyndon Johnson, fed up with factions seeking to oust him, wasn't running. Robert Kennedy, younger brother of the slain former president, sought the anti-war vote in his bid for the nomination before he too was assassinated, leaving the party in even greater disarray. With 100 cities still smouldering from riots following the killing of Martin Luther King Jr., the gathering became the next focal point for massive protests. Heavily armed police viciously beat thousands of demonstrators. "The whole world is watching," they chanted, along with "Hell no, we won't go" and "Pigs are whores." A shattered party eventually picked Hubert Humphrey, who was easily beaten by Republican Richard Nixon.
By: Paul Koring

Moment in time: Aug. 25, 1984 - Turner's debate misstep decides federal election:
Maybe never before or since has an election been lost in 30 seconds. Having just won the Liberal leadership, John Turner called a snap election. But the former finance minister was rusty after a political hiatus, voters were tired of Liberal government, and Turner earned no end of hurt when cameras caught him patting Liberal Party president Iona Campagnolo's bum. (She patted him back.) The real turning point came during the debate, when Progressive Conservative leader Brian Mulroney attacked Turner for acquiescing to a host of patronage appointments foisted on him by outgoing prime minister Pierre Trudeau. "I had no option," Turner replied. "You had an option, sir," Mulroney shot back. "You could have said, 'I am not going to do it.' " Election over. Voters elected a huge Tory majority; the Liberals were reduced to 40 seats. Turner never really recovered.
By: John Ibbitson

Moment in time: Aug. 23, 1973 - A Swedish bank is robbed, and Stockholm syndrome develops:
In the first day of his capture of Stockholm's Sveriges Kreditbank, escaped convict Jan-Erik Olsson had many of his demands met: three million kronor, two pistols and his comrade Clark Olofsson freed from prison to join him. But the bank robbers got something unexpected, too. Over a six day siege while they negotiated a getaway plan, their four hostages bonded with them, seeing small kindnesses as mercy and believing that police were the real threat. When police finally flushed out their bank-vault hiding spot with tear gas, the hostages shielded the robbers by letting them come out first, against police orders. To psychologists and the public, the bankdramat (bank drama) - which gave "Stockholm syndrome" its name - was a cautionary tale of what captives may do to endure the stress of captivity.
By: Evan Annett
"I'd wait ..." Today's editorial cartoon by David Parkins. From Globe Opinion

Penny Oleksiak reflected on her inspirational Rio journey the moment she stepped off the plane in Toronto. Four Olympic medals are great, but like most 16-year-olds, she'd really like her driver's license. (Reupload: this version fixes a previous version where sound cut out.)

Double gold.

Several members of Canada's Olympic team — including multi-medallist and closing ceremony flag-bearer Penny Oleksiak (right) and two-time gold-medal winner Rosie MacLennan — are back home.

Friends, family and fans mingled with reporters waiting for the athletes to clear customs and pick up their luggage.

"I'm just really excited to be home right now," Oleksiak said, adding she looked forward to seeing her mother and her friends.

The Olympic medallist, whose performance this summer has made her a household name, said she is grateful for the support Canadians have shown her and other athletes.

"You know Canada has your back," she said.

📷: THE CANADIAN PRESS/Aaron Vincent Elkaim

Hundreds of Americans were rescued when an unsanctioned event called the Port Huron Float Down took an unexpected turn towards Canada. Strong winds and gusts on the St. Clair River pushed partiers on floatation devices towards Canada, where the Canadian Coast Guard came to the rescue on Sunday. The U.S. citizens were bussed back home. (Canadian Coast Guard/Reuters)

Everyone knew that Shinzo Abe, the prime minister of Japan, was headed to Rio to represent the country that will host the 2020 Summer Olympics. But Japanese viewers who tuned into the broadcast of Rio's closing ceremony were surprised to see their normally sober leader pop out of an oversized green drainpipe dressed as Super Mario, the character from the popular Nintendo video game.

Abe's appearance followed a glossy promotional video showing athletes in stereotypical scenes from Tokyo, as well as various characters from popular culture, including Hello Kitty and Doraemon. The scene cut to Abe in a taxi, fretting that he wouldn't make it to Rio on time, followed by an animated Super Mario diving into a green pipe in Tokyo, emerging as a human figure from the green pipe on the field in Rio de Janeiro. When his costume fell off, the prime minister emerged, holding a red ball and waving a red cap, a shadow of a smile on his face.

📷: REUTERS/Stoyan Nenov

#supermario #rio #rio2016 #olympics #tokyo #japan #abe #hellokitty #doraemon

Moment in time: Aug. 22, 2012 - Botched fresco restoration of Jesus in Spanish church goes viral:
Cecilia Gimenez, an 82-year-old amateur painter, took it upon herself to restore a fresco of Jesus on the wall of her local church in tiny Borja, Spain. Her heart was in the right place. Unfortunately, that was the only anatomically correct part of her effort. The mouth she painted was a child's smear, the eyes those of a cartoon monkey. The nose was barely distinguishable from the flat surface of the face. The botched restoration earned Gimenez viral infamy. The church thought it was an act of vandalism before the truth came out.
Yet even press about being a clueless hack with a brush is good press: The attention helped boost tourism tenfold and raised money for the church, which began charging visitors to see the artwork. The shaming crowd loves a good selfie, after all. 
By: Dave McGinn

Skyrocketing home prices. Media reports of rampant house-flipping, with speculators reaping six-figure gains reselling ramshackle properties. A political furor over what many believe is a wave of offshore money flooding into the city's housing market, pushing out local buyers.

Sounds like it could be Vancouver, right? In this case, it's Auckland, New Zealand. And many countries other than Canada are also scrambling to slow their housing markets: Britain, Norway, Hong Kong and Australia, to name a few. 

Global policy makers are searching for a silver bullet to their housing-market woes. But have they found it in any of these countries' attempts?

Corporate Calgary has lost much of its swagger, and nowhere is that more on display than the Stampede party scene.

During the annual fair that takes over the city beginning next week, some of the most sought-out networking events have been cancelled. For those Stampede-themed parties that remain on the calendar, rambunctious, ostentatious displays of wealth are out. Beef-on-a-bun, beer-in-a-plastic-cup, charity-minded gatherings are in.

Even if firms can still afford to host a party, many are choosing not to while the layoff notices continue.

Moment in time: June 22, 1986 - Diego Maradona scores his two most famous goals:
The England-Argentina quarter-final match of the 1986 World Cup was bound to be fraught with emotion, coming just four years after the Falklands War. The first goal was scored by Argentina's cocksure superstar, Diego Maradona. While jumping as if to head a ball in front of the net, he swept an arm up and banged it in. The referee missed it. The goal was allowed to stand, and later Maradona would cheekily credit it to "the hand of God."
Just four minutes later, he made a spectacular 55-metre dash past four England players, faked out the goal keeper and dispatched the ball into the net. It clinched Argentina's victory, and the team went on to claim the Cup. In 2002, that second goal was voted World Cup Goal of the Century. 
By: Ian Morfitt

Moment in time: Morse patents his telegraph code
June 20, 1840 - American Samuel Morse was a sought-after portrait painter in the early 1800s, but he is remembered for creating an eponymous system of dots and dashes used to communicate over great distances. Morse code could be transmitted by telegraph and, later, light signals and sounds. With the exception of some navies and amateur radio buffs, its use is limited today. At the time of its introduction, however, it was revolutionary. Morse,
or "-- --- .-. ... .," created a set of characters that could overcome language barriers, poor visibility and bad reception. It replaced messages carried by foot and by hoof and preceded the telephone, the Internet and even Twitter. – Eric Atkins

Jason Kenney was surprised and annoyed, last December, to read that he was planning to ditch national politics for a bid to unite Alberta's fractured right.

The prospect wasn't even really on his radar, then; nothing much was, because he was so burnt out after the federal Conservatives' election loss. 

Publicly, he is now saying that he will decide by summer's end whether to seek the federal leadership or try to forge a "united alternative" to Alberta's governing NDP (or do neither). 

Privately, according to several sources close to him, he is leaning toward the provincial option, and may move quicker than he has let on.

Moment in time: June 16, 1960 - Hitchcock's Psycho has its world premiere in New York:
Alfred Hitchcock had spooked audiences with his psychological thrillers Rear Window and Vertigo, but what Paramount wanted was another star-studded adventure like North by Northwest. The studio declined to underwrite a horror film based on the Robert Bloch novel Psycho, forcing the director to shoot in black and white with a TV crew while dodging censors to show Janet Leigh in a bra during a lunchtime tryst. Critics were divided when the low-budget movie opened in New York, but audiences immediately responded to a level of sex and violence never seen in mainstream American cinema.
Latecomers weren't permitted lest they missed Leigh, whose dubious heroine was famously stabbed in the shower before the halfway mark by Anthony Perkins as superbly creepy Norman Bates. Psycho proved Hitchcock's biggest hit, and critics soon agreed this was the most artful horror movie ever. 
By: Kate Taylor

Moment in time: June 10, 2003 - The Michaels tie the knot:
It was a quickie wedding - but for Michael Leshner and Michael Stark it was decades in the making. The Michaels, as they were dubbed, had been together for more than 20 years - and became the first same-sex couple in Canada to legally marry. Their civil ceremony took place just hours after Ontario's Court of Appeal ruled that Canada's marriage law was unconstitutional. It was a joyous day - a triumph for equality as Ontario became the first jurisdiction in North America to acknowledge same-sex marriage. In 2005, Ottawa passed legislation legalizing it across the country. However, in 2006, the Conservatives came to power promising a free vote to revisit the issue. It failed. Last month, the federal Tories voted at their convention to erase the traditional definition of marriage from their policies.
By: Jane Taber

Moment in time: June 9, 2008 - CBC loses The Hockey Theme to CTV:
It was a national call to prayer, and for 39 seasons its brassand-bass fanfare prompted a Pavlovian pricking up of Canadians' ears as they tuned in to CBC's Hockey Night in Canada broadcasts. But after years of feeling ill-treated by the public broadcaster for various perceived sins (lack of onscreen credit, tussles over ancillary rights to such uses as ring tones), composer Dolores Claman rejected CBC's contract offer and sold her baby for a reported $2.5-million to CTV for use in its TSN hockey broadcasts. Canadians of a certain age took it hard, decrying the cold calculations of capitalism. The symbolism may have hurt more than the loss itself: If a nation's unofficial anthem was in fact private property that could be bought and sold like so much chattel, what did that mean for the nation itself?
By: Simon Houpt

Moment in time: June 8, 1998 - Charlton Heston becomes NRA president:
The political journey of actor and activist Charlton Heston ranged from civil rights advocacy to challenging political correctness as "tyranny with manners." He became the most outspoken and controversial champion of the Second Amendment on his election as president of the National Rifle Association. At the 2000 NRA convention, Heston famously raised aloft an old flintlock rifle and warned that Democratic presidential nominee Al Gore would "slander you as gun-toting, knuckle-dragging, bloodthirsty maniacs." He would attempt to take away your guns, Heston warned before delivering what has become his most enduring line, a variation on an old gun-rights slogan: "Mr. Gore: From my cold, dead hands!" Gore narrowly lost to George W. Bush, and Heston announced in 2002 that he had Alzheimer's disease. He died in 2008, but the United States remains deeply divided over gun rights.
By: Paul Koring
