Moment in time: June 6, 1933 - First drive-in movie theatre opens in Camden, N.J.:
It was a very American invention. "Sit in your car," invited the original tagline. "See and hear movies." Beckoned by such a harmony of Hollywood and Detroit, who could say no? The answer, by the middle of the century, was hardly anyone. The first iteration in Camden, N.J., came with tinny sound and laboured to turn a profit, but drive-in movie theatres spread wildly across the United States in the next three decades, peaking at about 5,000 by the mid-1960s. The reasons for that popularity are a digest of postwar American culture: the proliferation of kids (who could be noisy at the drive-in); the rise of teen culture (where better to neck?); the adoration of the automobile; and, in the country that gave us the shopping cart and the washing machine, a lust for consumerist convenience.
By: Eric Andrew-Gee

Moment in time: June 3, 1994 - Montreal Canadiens win Game 2 after gambling on an illegal stick penalty:
With one minute 45 seconds left in the third period of the second game of the Stanley Cup final, his Montreal Canadiens down 2-1 against the Los Angeles Kings, coach Jacques Demers called for a measurement of Marty McSorley's stick. Had the stick's blade not been found to exceed the maximum half-inch curve allowed, the Habs would have been penalized, likely lost the game and fallen behind 2-0 in the series. Instead, McSorley was penalized and Demers pulled goalie Patrick Roy for a two-man advantage.
Habs defenceman Eric Desjardins scored with 1:13 left and again 51 seconds into overtime to win the game. The Canadiens went on to beat the Kings, clinching their 24th Stanley Cup. Some fans believe the McSorley stick call cursed all Canadian NHL teams: None has hoisted the Cup since.
By: Bertrand Marotte
One of the biggest stories of the day. http://trib.al/cQCgRgy

Moment in time: June 2, 1917 - Billy Bishop's dawn raid earns him the Victoria Cross:
Canada's flying ace dived through the clouds toward the German airfield at dawn on this day in 1917. Captain William Avery (Billy) Bishop gunned down the first Albatross as it took to the air. He then wheeled his Nieuport biplane around and fired on a second, causing it to crash. Bishop engaged the third German in a dogfight and shot him down, while a fourth enemy flew away from the battle. Bishop, 23 at the time, sped back to his airbase in Filescamp Farm, France, evading four more German warplanes and safely landing his bullet-scarred plane. He was awarded the Victoria Cross for the battle, becoming the first Canadian airman to win the honour. He scored 72 victories in the First World War, cementing his status as one of the great fighter pilots.
By: Eric Atkins
Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau raises a pride flag during a ceremony on Parliament Hill for the first time in Canadian history. (Chris Wattie/Reuters)

Moment in time: June 1, 1997 - Johnson, Bailey compete in 150-metre race for 'World's Fastest Human' title:
Officially, the race was to determine the "World's Fastest Human." Unofficially, it was a 150-metre dash to settle a clash of the biggest egos in track and field that had smouldered since the previous summer's Olympics. Despite a world-record 100-metre run, Donovan Bailey, from Oakville, Ont., had been overshadowed by American golden boy Michael Johnson's record-setting sprints. NBC sportscaster Bob Costas added fuel to the fire by anointing Johnson the fastest man on the planet after dividing his 200-metre time in half, with the resulting 9.66 bettering Bailey's 9.84-second mark. Bailey had the final say on home soil, however, overcoming concerns about the tight curve of the SkyDome's track to lead Johnson coming into the home straight, at which point Johnson turned into "a chicken," according to Bailey, reaching for his left thigh and pulling up lame. 
By: Paul Attfield

Moment in time: May 31, 1859 - World's most famous clock starts ticking:
Trivia buffs know that Big Ben is the name of the bell, not the clock, that towers over the British Houses of Parliament. But Ben and his companions wouldn't know when to chime without the methodical precision of the Great Clock, which for 150 years has faithfully kept time for Londoners.
In hot weather and cold, the 15-foot pendulum sways back and forth and the hands move steadily around the four faces. The time is regulated with predecimal pennies: Adding one causes the clock to gain two-fifths of a second over 24 hours. The bells will fall silent early next year while the clock and tower undergo maintenance and repairs - but anyone wishing to hear the familiar melody in the meantime can download the ringtone from the Big Ben page on the parliamentary website. 
By: Kate Hopwood

Moment in time: May 30, 1974 - Robert Stanfield misses the catch of his life:
Before he dropped the ball, Robert Stanfield had thrice been premier of Nova Scotia; led the Progressive Conservatives to within two seats of the Trudeaumania-steeped Liberals; and entered the 1974 campaign following a no-confidence vote that defeated Trudeau's government.
During a break on the campaign trail in North Bay, Ont., Stanfield threw perfect spirals and frequently caught that football. But it was the photo of him clumsily missing a catch - snapped by Canadian Press photographer Doug Ball - that made the front page of this newspaper. It's trite to say a single image lost him the election. But it didn't help. And that fumble presaged the growing influence of political image crafting. It's fitting that the man who beat Stanfield in that election also fathered a prime minister who, in today's world of social media, is a master of the photo op. 
By: Susan Krashinsky

Moment in time: May 20, 1980 - Quebeckers reject the push for independence:
The question posed to Quebeckers in 1980 was almost as long as this vignette but could be boiled down to this: Should Quebec begin negotiations toward greater autonomy from Canada? That may sound reasonable, but the objective behind the question was Quebec independence and the breakup of Canada. The answer on referendum night was a resounding "No." Most Quebeckers saw safety in a strong Quebec remaining in a united Canada. In his concession speech, Parti Québécois Premier René Lévesque prophetically mused, "My dear friends, if I understand you correctly, you're saying, 'Until next time.' " Quebec would spend the next 15 years seeking special constitutional status. Rejected, the province would come within a percentage point of a Yes vote in 1995. With no major flashpoint since, the movement has faded - now a distant dream held by about a third of Quebeckers.
By: Les Perreaux

Moment in time: May 17, 2006 - Nichola Goddard killed in Afghanistan:
In the traditionally male world of the Canadian military, Captain Nichola Goddard believed that gender shouldn't matter. When a training sergeant referred to a light backpack as a "girlie" bag, she told him to change the term. When a commander ordered tarps to separate the male and female sections of their tents in Afghanistan, she objected fiercely.
And when Canadian troops were ambushed by dozens of Taliban militants near Kandahar, she fought fearlessly in the counterattack, becoming the first Canadian army officer to direct artillery fire at an enemy force since Korea.
As the crew commander, she was standing half-exposed in her armoured vehicle when it was hit by two rocket-propelled grenades. She became the first female Canadian soldier to be killed in combat. But she wouldn't have wanted the obituaries, either, to dwell on her gender. 
By: Geoffrey York

Moment in time: May 16, 1983  - Michael Jackson introduces the world to the moonwalk:
It was one funky step for Michael Jackson, one giant leap for pop culture. During a performance of his hit single Billie Jean on the TV special Motown 25: Yesterday, Today, Forever, the sequined superstar dazzled his audience with a popping dance routine that included a gliding manoeuvre and optical illusion - moving backward while appearing to walk forward.
Known as the moonwalk, the origin of the fancy piece of footwork was traceable to Cab Calloway, who, in the 1930s, used to do something similar that he called "the buzz." After the mono-gloved Jackson showcased the step, the moonwalk became his signature move and trendy worldwide - the snazzy slide seemingly something out of this world. 
By: Brad Wheeler

Moment in time: March 24, 1874 - Houdini born in Budapest: 
The man who would become the greatest magician in history was born Ehrich Weiss, the son of a rabbi. After immigrating to the United States as a boy, he seized on magic as his escape from poverty. At 17, he renamed himself after his idol, French magician Jean-Eugène Robert-Houdin. Houdini dabbled in card tricks, billing himself as "The King of Cards" in performances at sideshows. At 22, having failed to find much success, he took out a newspaper ad offering to sell his magic and secrets for $20. No one responded. With that moment of doubt behind him, Houdini's determination never wavered. For proof, look no further than the words he would add to his autographs for adoring fans. "My brain is the key that sets me free."
By: Dave McGinn

Moment in time: March 23, 1973 - Dick Wilmarth wins first Iditarod race:
The Iditarod Trail was originally used to carry mail and supplies to remote Alaskan communities, most famously in 1925 when a sled-dog relay was used to rush diphtheria medication to Nome during an outbreak. Inspired by that historic journey, the first edition of the 1,000-mile (1,600-kilometre) sled-dog trek through the wilderness from Anchorage to Nome saw Dick Wilmarth win $12,000 (U.S.) with his first-place time of 20 days 49 minutes 41 seconds on a route that included stretches with no trail.
That's a far cry from the multiple check points, GPS and groomed paths in use today. Even so, the experience is a gruelling one; many do not complete the race. Those who do become local heroes, such as 2016 champion Dallas Seavey, who crossed the finish line in a record-breaking time of 8 days 11 hours 20 minutes 16 seconds.
By: Kate Hopwood

Moment in time: March 22, 1963 - The Beatles release their first full-length album:
Clipped British efficiency was the real backbeat behind the Fab Four's inaugural studio album. Spinning off the success of the breakout single Please Please Me, the inevitable LP was recorded at EMI Studios in 10 hours, for which John, George, Paul and Ringo were each paid the princely sum of roughly £20. At 14 tracks, the song list was split between pop standards (Chains, Baby It's You) and Lennon-McCartney originals (Love Me Do, Ask Me Why). Producer George Martin wanted the cover to be photographed at the London Zoo, but the Zoological Society of London scotched the idea, so they posed in an EMI stairwell. Released in mono, followed by a stereo version four weeks later, Please Please Me held the top spot on the British music charts for 30 straight weeks, until it was replaced by the group's second album, With the Beatles.
By: Andrew Ryan

Where has Stephen Harper gone? What is he up to?

The man who was prime minister for nearly 10 years and wanted to make it 14, the polarizing political mastermind who reinvented partisanship and confidently subjected his citizens to the longest, bitterest election in Canadian history, which was his to win and which he then shockingly lost, has virtually vanished.

The House of Commons doesn't publish attendance records. But in the five months since the election, Harper has introduced no bills, has made no interventions in the House or in committee. He hasn't taken the floor once. 

Here's the strange thing: Whatever your political stripe, however much he was your hero or your enemy, do you not somewhere, if only in the remotest corner of your political subconscious, want to know where he is and how he's doing, and whether defeat and distance have cracked the kiln-fired veneer of the most emotionally reserved prime minister in living memory? He ran the whole show, and now he has vanished, like Waldo.

Moment in time: March 17, 1824 - Montreal hosts its first St. Patrick's Day parade: Montreal was almost a quarter Irish in 1824 when its St. Patrick's Day parade - one of the oldest in the world - was founded. While some parades in the 1800s were extremely nationalistic (Toronto's was occasionally cancelled due to passions and loutishness), processions in Montreal "were quiet and respectable affairs that brought together the Irish elite and reflected the cordiality that existed between Protestants and Catholics," according to academic Rosalyn Trigger. Today, the parade is one of the biggest parties of the year in Montreal (almost 40 per cent of francophone Quebeckers have some Irish roots), but it has fallen on hard times. Amid rising costs and waning sponsorship, organizers are asking for donations. The parade survived 192 years, through the Rebellions of 1837, Fenian raids, the assassination of Thomas D'Arcy McGee and two world wars. It seems likely to survive this, too.
By: Les Perreaux

Moment in time: March 16, 1872 - First Football Association Cup final played: 
The first Football Association Cup final was played between the Wanderers and Royal Engineers. The English didn't invent the game, but with the creation of the FA Cup, they gave it its eternal, meritocratic flavour.
Only 20 teams compete in the country's top division. But each year, every outfit in the lower divisions is given a chance to play for the sport's oldest cup.
It amounts to more than 700 teams in all. As a rule, the big clubs win it in the end. But every once in a while, a team from the back of beyond will go on a dream run through the competition. Those names are etched in English soccer history: Wrexham, Sutton, Colchester, Hereford United. All it takes is one great day to create a historic moment. More than watching the best play, that is the magic of the FA Cup. 
By: Cathal Kelly

Moment in time: March 11, 1985 - Gorbachev named next leader of the Soviet Union:
Mikhail Gorbachev looked like change from the moment he was sworn in. Unlike his two immediate predecessors - septuagenarians who died just 13 months apart - Gorbachev was a relatively young 54 when he became General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union. He was the first leader of the USSR to have been born after the 1917 revolution. Still, no one could have foreseen what Gorbachev's six years in the top post would bring: glasnost, perestroika, the fall of the Berlin Wall, the collapse of the Soviet Union, the end of the Cold War. While still hailed as a hero in the West, Gorbachev is not as well regarded at home. Many Russians blame him for the collapse of living standards they experienced in the 1990s - and for letting Russia's empire slide away.
By: Mark MacKinnon

Moment in time: March 10, 1992 - The House of Commons recognizes Louis Riel as a founder of Manitoba:
In an intense and often divisive era of constitutional reform, Joe Clark looked to the past for a unifying symbol. In 1885, the Métis leader Louis Riel was executed for treason after leading the disastrous North-West Rebellion. But through the passage of time, as well as the political needs of the moment, the rebel could now be transformed into a nation-builder - a charismatic Westerner and francophone who rallied the disenfranchised peoples of the Red River settlement toward self-government, creating the conditions for Manitoba to join Confederation in 1870. The former prime minister's resolution, adopted unanimously, acclaimed Riel "for his unique and historic role as a founder of Manitoba" - but stopped short of calling him a Father of Confederation or granting him the posthumous pardon appropriate to his new-found status.
By: John Allemang

Moment in time: March 9, 1997 - Notorious B.I.G. gunned down in Los Angeles:
After two decades spent clawing its way in, hip hop was flourishing in music's mainstream, but it was marred by tragedy. California's Tupac Shakur died the previous year following a drive-by shooting, and, in the early morning of March 9, rap lost another figurehead. Shakur's friend-turned-rival Christopher Wallace, the Brooklyn rapper better known as the Notorious B.I.G., was gunned down at a red light outside a Los Angeles party. He was only 24. Investigators, media and the public spent years scouring for any juicy detail they could find to link the two murders to the East Coast-West Coast "rivalry" that coincided with Shakur and Wallace's falling out. Both cases, however, remain unsolved. Wallace's sophomore album, Life After Death, was released two weeks after his killing, and his legacy has fulfilled that title's prophecy: He remains one of the most influential rappers of all time. 
By: Josh O'Kane

Moment in time: March 8, 2004 - Bertuzzi hit takes Moore out of Canucks-Avalanche game:
It was one of the ugliest incidents in recent NHL history. Todd Bertuzzi, then one of the Vancouver Canucks' biggest stars, sucker-punched Colorado Avalanche rookie Steve Moore in the head late in an 8-2 game in Vancouver. Exacting revenge for a legal hit to the head that Moore had put on Canucks captain Markus Naslund a month earlier, Bertuzzi knocked Moore unconscious before a pile of players landed on top of them. Moore suffered three fractured vertebrae and a serious concussion and had to be taken off the ice on a stretcher. He spent months in a Denver hospital. After a tearful televised apology, Bertuzzi was suspended for the remainder of the season - 20 games and more than $500,000 (U.S.) in salary - and was never the same player again. Moore was never able to return to the NHL. They settled a civil lawsuit for an undisclosed amount in 2014. 
By: James Mirtle

Moment in time: March 7, 1876 - Alexander Graham Bell patents the telephone:
Alexander Graham Bell wasn't the only inventor racing to submit paperwork at the U.S. Patent Office on a winter morning in 1876. But for reasons that touched off years of legal battles, the Scottish teacher was the first to be granted a patent for the telephone. The device, which sprung from his studies of sounds and vibrations, was invented at his Boston lab and his family home in Brantford, Ont. He described it in his patent application as a "method of, and apparatus for, transmitting two or more telegraphic signals along a single wire." In an adorable bit of old-timey understatement, he also said it featured "new and useful improvements in telegraphy." He was granted U.S. patent No. 174,465 and would grow wealthy from his invention, which became quite popular.
By: Eric Atkins

Moment in time: March 4, 1971 - Pierre and Margaret Trudeau marry at a private ceremony: 
Pierre Trudeau seemed every inch the happy bachelor in the late winter of 1971. Canada's 15th Prime Minister, 51 at the time, had squired many an attractive female since his 1968 election, including Barbra Streisand and the daughter of a former Liberal cabinet minister, Margaret Sinclair. But he seemed in no rush for the altar. Then one Thursday evening, news broke that Trudeau had married Sinclair, nearly 29 years his junior, in a small, secret ceremony at a North Vancouver church. Even the presiding Catholic priest hadn't known the groom's name in advance. The couple had first met in 1968, became engaged in fall, 1970, and, had the October Crisis not intervened, planned to marry that December. Canadians showered the newlyweds with good wishes and for a while the unlikely union of worldly politico and selfdescribed "hippie" seemed to work. Six years and three children later, though, the two announced their separation. 
By: James Adams

Moment in time: March 3, 1887 - Anne Sullivan arrives at the Keller residence:
Anne Sullivan relished challenging convention. Partially blind, the daughter of Irish immigrants was sent to an overcrowded, dilapidated home for the poor at the age of 10 after her mother died and her father abandoned the family. She might have remained in squalor had she not summoned up the moxie to tell a group of visiting officials that she wanted to go to school. She started far behind her peers but was, as the school director dubbed her, a spitfire. She persevered and went on to become valedictorian. That pluck and cleverness served her well for her next challenge: becoming governess to a wild and stubborn child, Helen Keller, who was blind, deaf and mute. Sullivan unlocked Keller's silent world, teaching her the meaning of words, how to multiply and how to read Braille. She was by her side always, guiding her pupil and friend to become the first deaf-blind person to graduate from an American college. 
By: Renata D'Aliesio

Moment in time: Grand Canyon declared a U.S. national park
Feb. 26, 1919 - With the Grand Canyon's status as an icon of Americana, it's hard to believe its future was once threatened. For almost 30 years a political battle raged between conservationists (including Theodore Roosevelt, who once proclaimed the site "fills me with awe") and their foes – various commercial interests, including miners, who wondered whether a few well-placed sticks of dynamite might just uncover thick veins of gold. Even Roosevelt at the height of his presidential powers was unable to push a bill through Congress to preserve the canyon. It was only in 1919 that U.S. President Woodrow
Wilson assembled enough votes to succeed in declaring the site a national park, thereby outlawing private development, including mines. In the ensuing decades, the baby boom, coupled with the rise of the automobile, made the Grand Canyon a destination for countless family road trips and cemented its place in the American psyche. Today, the natural wonder receives more than five million visitors every year. – Ken Carriere

Moment in time: Sir Christopher Wren dies at 91
Feb. 25, 1723: Born the son of a rector in Wiltshire, Christopher Michael Wren dabbled in astronomy and mathematics before committing to architecture in his 30s. Wren essayed his unique design on several buildings, but his finest hour came in the wake of the Great Fire of London in 1666, which reduced two-thirds of the city to smoking rubble and required rebuilding on a massive scale. Wren's initial design for St Paul's Cathedral was rejected – bringing him to tears – but he came back with a toned-down version of the great dome. All
told, Wren designed 53 churches and dozens of other London landmarks. Wren took frequent trips into the city and on one such visit he caught the chill that claimed his life at 91. Buried in the church that embodied his life's work, he received a fitting epitaph: "If you seek his memorial, look around you." – Staff

Moment in time: Feb. 22, 1990 - Milli Vanilli win Grammy for Best New Artist: "It's an award for all the artists in the world!" trilled Milli Vanilli's Rob Pilatus while accepting the Best New Artist trophy at the 1990 Grammy Awards. In consort with photogenic pop partner Fabrice Morvan, Pilatus was coming off a debut album that sold 14 million units and produced five charttopping hits - but a bumbled live MTV appearance had already sparked rumours the dreadlocked duo might be poseurs. The truth came out in November when German record producer Frank Farian admitted to recruiting Pilatus and Morvan to front for songs he had created using studio musicians. Four days later, Milli Vanilli were stripped of their Grammy and promptly plunked into pop-star ignominy. Sadly, the next time Milli Vanilli made headlines was in 1998 when Pilatus was found dead of an apparent drug overdose in a Frankfurt hotel room.
By: Andrew Ryan

Moment in time: Feb. 9, 1964 - The Beatles perform on The Ed Sullivan Show: "Ladies and gentlemen, the Beatles." The Fab Four were still a magical mystery on this side of the Atlantic when they scored a No. 1 Billboard hit with I Want to Hold Your Hand in early 1964. That changed in early February when John, Paul, George and Ringo landed at New York's John F. Kennedy International Airport, greeted by legions of rapturous fans. Two days later, the Beatles made history. Appearing on The Ed Sullivan Show, their U.S. television debut exhilarated fans here, there and everywhere. You could hear the studio audience screaming as the band ran through early hits such as All My Loving and She Loves You, but the excitement wasn't contained to the Manhattan theatre: A reported 73 million people watched the broadcast - 60 per cent of all televisions turned on in the United States - cementing the Beatles as the biggest band in the world. 
By: Josh O'Kane

Moment in time: Dec. 31, 1972 - Baseball's Roberto Clemente dies in a plane crash: Roberto Clemente, the 12-time All-Star and career Pittsburgh Pirate, died in a plane crash off the Puerto Rican coast, not far from where he was born, on New Year's Eve. The plane was set to deliver supplies to Managua, Nicaragua, where a deadly earthquake had struck a week earlier.
The 38-year-old baseball great had been a big part of Puerto Rico's aid efforts, helping to raise $150,000. He even chartered the flight after suspicions arose that supplies weren't reaching victims. There is dispute over the cause of the crash, but the plane was allegedly 1,900 kilograms overloaded and had a history of mechanical troubles. Everyone aboard died and Clemente's body was never found. He was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame on March 30, 1973 - only fitting for a player who won four National League batting titles, 12 Gold Gloves and two MVP awards. 
By: Madeleine White

Moment in time: Dec. 30, 1816 - Mary Godwin marries Percy Bysshe Shelley: The circumstances surrounding the marriage of the English Romantic poet and the daughter of the feminist Mary Wollstonecraft were scandalous, even by today's standards: In the summer of 1814, the already-married Shelley ran off to mainland Europe with then-16-year-old Godwin and her stepsister. Godwin soon found herself pregnant (she lost the baby when it was born two months premature) and cut off from her father, but the relationship continued. In the summer of 1816, the lovebirds spent part of the summer visiting Lord Byron at his villa in Switzerland, telling each other ghost stories (one of which became Frankenstein, which Mary Shelley published anonymously in 1818). That fall, Shelley's wife, Harriet, herself pregnant (though the child was not Shelley's), threw herself into Hyde Park's Serpentine River. Shelley and Godwin were married 20 days later. The marriage, alas, was short-lived: He died in 1822 at the age of 29. 
By: Mark Medley

Moment in time, Dec. 28, 2014: All 162 passengers and crew on board AirAsia Flight 8501 were killed when pilots lost control of the perfectly flyable Airbus A320 and it crashed into the Java Sea on a dawn flight from Surabaya, Indonesia, to Singapore. After a routine change in course to avoid storms, the less-experienced French co-pilot, Rémi-Emmanuel Plesel, inexplicably pulled the Airbus into a dizzying climb. This occurred after Indonesian Captain Iriyanto, a former fighter pilot, left his seat to fiddle with circuit breakers in an unorthodox attempt to reset one of the aircraft's computers. Nose high, the steeply climbing jet lost so much speed that it ceased flying, rolled into a spiral dive and plummeted into the sea. Crash investigators, who have ceased using the term "pilot error," concluded: "Flight crew action resulted in inability to control the aircraft." – Paul Koring (Photo: Darren Whiteside/Reuters)

Merry Christmas Canada! Here it is, our annual painting: Lake Superior III (circa 1923-24), by Lawren S. Harris (1885-1970). Lawren Harris's first visit to the north shore of Lake Superior, in the fall of 1921, was a revelation. Here at last were skies of "singing expansiveness and sublimity," a stark landscape of "mystery and bigness" that seemed the purest complement to his deepest spiritual, nationalist and artistic yearnings. Not for Mr. Harris the "opulent" wilderness of Ontario's Algoma or Algonquin. His soul had been scoured by the deaths of his brother Howard and his painter friend Tom Thomson, as well as his own nervous breakdown in April, 1918 and an unsatisfying marriage. Seeking "replenishment" of his life and art, he found it in the "cleansing rhythms" and "greater living quiet" of the granitic Canadian Shield country. In all Mr. Harris would make eight trips to the north shore, always in autumn, producing such signature works as the panoramic Lake Superior III. An austere masterpiece of deep, illumined pictorial space, it's a suite of simplified, almost abstract forms crisply rendered with flattened brush strokes of blue and grey, burgundy, umber and amber. While Mr. Harris went on to render other latitudes, other altitudes, including the Rockies and the Arctic, his brilliant metaphysical mystery tour started here. And as this year ends, a year that for many has seemed especially dark, there's solace to be found in the enduring rocks, the wide, open horizon and the eternal persistence of the light coming in. – James Adams (Painting courtesy of the estate of Lawren S. Harris)

Moment in Time: Dec. 23, 1992: 
Surely the year 1992 could not inflict any more pain: By late November, the Queen had suffered so much she referred to it as her ''annus horribilis.'' Over the previous 11 months she had endured the crumbling of three of her four children's marriages - including mortifying revelations about their affairs - a fire that devastated her beloved Windsor Castle and a rancorous debate over whether the Crown should pay income tax. Yet 1992 had one more insult left. On Dec. 23, the Sun printed a leaked transcript of the Queen's annual Christmas broadcast, blemishing a cherished tradition that dated back 60 years to her grandfather's voice on the radio. The leak, however, was widely seen as needlessly disrespectful, and so, ironically, 1992 would end with the Queen winning back a measure of public sympathy. - Ken Carriere

Moment in time: Dec. 22, 1808 - World hears Beethoven's Fifth for first time: The theatre was bitterly cold, the semi-professional orchestra was under-rehearsed and the performance went on for four hours. And yet the benefit concert at Vienna's Theater an der Wien was a dream event that saw the premieres of Beethoven's Symphonies No. 5 and No. 6, and of the Piano Concerto No. 4, with the composer conducting from the keyboard. During the concerto, the wildly gesturing Beethoven knocked two candles off the piano, then accidentally smacked the face of one of the boys delegated to hold fresh candles. Another piece at the end of the show fell apart and had to be restarted. It was all a bit much, musically and every other way, but that hasn't stopped others from recreating this landmark concert - the last Beethoven ever gave.
By: Robert Everett-Green

Moment in time: Dec. 21, 1967 - Pierre Trudeau speaks on the 'bedrooms of the nation': "There's no place for the state in the bedrooms of the nation," Pierre Trudeau declared. The Justice Minister was defending legislation that, in its final form, decriminalized homosexuality, permitted abortion in certain circumstances, decriminalized contraception, introduced the 0.08 bloodalcohol concentration limit for drinking and driving, legalized lotteries, restricted the use of firearms and more. The same year Trudeau introduced the bill, the Supreme Court had upheld a dangerous-offender life sentence for a man convicted of homosexuality, and NDP Leader Tommy Douglas appeared enlightened when he declared in 1968: "Instead of treating [homosexuality] as a crime and driving it underground, we ought to recognize it for what it is: It's a mental illness." Despite an attempted filibuster from the Créditistes, Bill C-150 passed in May, 1969 - with Trudeau as Prime Minister at that point - forever shattering the power of religion to restrict the actions of government and bringing social tolerance to this land. 
By: John Ibbitson

Moment in time: Dec. 18, 1966 - CBS airs Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas: You're a rare one, Mr. Grinch. TV's most enduring festive chestnut came into existence through a perfect creative trifecta: Theodor Geisel's guileless 1957 book served as source material; veteran animator Chuck Jones, best known for Bugs Bunny, essayed the crisp visuals converting the story into a 26-minute cartoon; and horror-film legend Boris Karloff - in one of his final roles - was both narrator and growly voice of the Grinch himself. CBS earned solid ratings for the inaugural broadcast and likewise for the next two decades, after which the special resurfaced annually on NBC, TNT, TBS and ABC. Over the years, the redemptive concept has been revisited in a handful of TV specials, including the Emmy-winning Halloween Is Grinch Night, but none captured the charm of the original - and the less said about the 2000 film starring Jim Carrey, the better.
By: Andrew Ryan

Moment in time: Dec. 17, 2014 - 'Cuban Thaw' commences: No longer an existential threat to the Free World, Cuba was facing financial ruin. The Communist bulwark of the Caribbean had lost its patron state, Venezuela, and President Raul Castro needed a wealthy new friend to help replenish his country's empty coffers. U.S. President Barack Obama's own economy was on the rebound, but his cupboard of foreign-policy victories was looking bare. So after behind-the-curtains diplomacy led by Pope Francis and the office of U.S. Senator Patrick Leahy, the so-called Cuban Thaw commenced. Hoping to repair the damage wrought by a century of mutual suspicion, military misadventure and the unlawful nationalization of U.S. property, the two leaders announced a normalizing of relations. While obstacles remain in lifting the United States' economic blockade - el bloqueo - the next Yanqui invasion has already leapt over the crumbling seawalls of the Malecon. There is now Wi-Fi access, greater freedom of financial transactions and, most of all, travel. Unfathomable even a couple of years ago, the red, white and blue of American Airlines now touches down at Havana's airport.
By: Craig Offman

Moment in time: Dec. 16, 1775 - Jane Austen is born: Jane Austen's sister called her a "dear Angel," while some of the novelist's 19th-century readers knew her only as "A Lady." Austen - once an anonymous author and now one of Britain's most celebrated writers - was born exactly 240 years ago, in 1775. Hollywood has turned her classic novels into box-office hits, although sometimes still on the stealth. Clueless, the 1995 flick starring Alicia Silverstone, riffs off Emma, as if no one would notice. Shades of Pride and Prejudice show up in Bridget Jones's Diary. Kandukondain Kandukondain is a Tamil version of Sense and Sensibility. Even Austen's unfinished work has fetched global attention. An unidentified buyer in 2011 paid $1.6-million ("U.S.) for a draft of The Watsons, which the author wrote in 1804. The manuscript sports edits in her handwriting. Austen wrote six books, two of which were published after she died in 1817. 
By: Carrie Tait

Moment in time: Dec. 15, 1973  - Sandy Hawley becomes first jockey to win 500 races in one year: Sandy Hawley, a quiet, unassuming Canadian with long hair and an unorthodox riding style, became the first jockey in the world to win 500 races in a single year. Riding seven days a week for two months, he erased the previous record of 485 set 20 years earlier by famed U.S. rider Bill Shoemaker - a mark thought to be unbreakable. The 24-year-old Hawley would add 15 more wins by Dec. 31, but his total would be eclipsed the next year. Still, he left an indelible mark on the sport, winning so often at Hollywood Park in California that it was dubbed Hawleywood. Canadian fans were already familiar with his ability, often betting on his mounts regardless of their past performance. The future Hall of Fame athlete ended his career with 6,450 victories. His 20.5-per-cent winning percentage ranks sixth among riders with more than 4,000 victories. 
By: Brian Milner

Moment in time: Dec. 14, 1994 - Construction begins on China's Three Gorges Dam: From the outset, the Three Gorges Dam was a study in superlatives. It would be the world's largest hydroelectric dam, create a 600-kilometrelong reservoir, raise the waters of the Yangtze River by nearly 175 metres and hold it all back with 27.15 million cubic metres of cement that made 231,000 square metres of concrete wall - equivalent to 39 CFL fields. Construction began Dec. 14, 1994, but did not end until 2012, when it reached 22.5 gigawatts of electrical generating capacity, five times what exists on both sides of the Niagara River. China's ability to engineer and construct the monumental structure has inspired immense pride in its people, providing one of the markers of the country's ascension as a rising superpower. But in submerging 1,503 cities, towns and villages - and displacing more than a million people - it is also a defining symbol of the environmental and social destruction China has countenanced in the name of growth. 
By: Nathan VanderKlippe

Moment in time: Dec. 11, 1962 - Canada conducts its last executions: In the early minutes of a cold Tuesday morning, Arthur Lucas and Ronald Turpin were hanged back to back at Toronto's notorious Don Jail, the last of about 700 state-sanctioned executions in Canada's history. Lucas had been convicted of killing a drug trial witness and his wife; Turpin of killing a policeman in a gun battle. No matter that both trials were questionable and that Lucas protested his innocence right to the end. Outside the jail, as the executions took place, hundreds of picketers held a vigil, yelling "murderers" and "killers" at the authorities. A growing public distaste for capital punishment prevailed, but it took until 1967 for Parliament to vote that it should be limited to killers of police officers and prison guards. Only in 1976 was the death penalty abolished in Canada.
By: Richard Blackwell

Moment in time: Dec. 10, 1901 - First Nobel Prizes awarded: Five years to the day after the death of explosives manufacturer Alfred Nobel, the prizes named after him were handed out for the first time. Nobel, who worried he'd be forever remembered for the military uses of dynamite, bequeathed nearly all of his fortune to establishing five awards honouring achievement in the sciences, literature and the promotion of "fraternity between nations." The identities of the winners were kept secret until the night of the ceremony. Germany's Wilhelm Roentgen, who discovered X-rays, and Emil von Behring, who developed a diphtheria serum, won in the physics and medicine categories. Dutch scientist Jacobus H. van 't Hoff took the chemistry prize for his foundational work in the field. The literature prize went to French poet Sully Prudhomme - to the surprise of those who were expecting Leo Tolstoy. Red Cross founder Henry Dunant of Switzerland shared the peace prize with Frédéric Passy of France. 
By: Ivan Semeniuk

Moment in time: Dec. 9, 1990 - Marie-Marguerite d'Youville canonized as first Canadian-born saint: Like any true saint, Marie-Marguerite d'Youville never let adversity stop her from helping others. Born in Varennes, Que., in 1701, Marie-Marguerite Dufrost de La Jemmerais lost her father when she was seven, after which she took care of her four brothers and sisters. Her marriage to François d'Youville resulted in six children (four died in infancy) and his death in 1730 left her destitute. Soon after, the young widow funnelled her unwavering faith into founding the Sisters of Charity of Montreal, a.k.a. the Grey Nuns, which tended to the growing city's poor. Although Marie-Marguerite died in 1771, it took the Catholic Church nearly two centuries to recognize her. At her 1959 beatification, Pope John XXIII called her the "Mother of Universal Charity." The final honour came in 1990, when Pope John Paul II officially canonized her - the first native Canadian elevated to sainthood. 
By: Andrew Ryan

Moment in time: Tuesday, December 8, 2015 - Timothy Eaton opens first store on Yonge Street: Timothy Eaton was 20 years old in 1854 when he sailed from Ireland to a new home in Southern Ontario. After working as an apprentice shopkeeper and briefly owning a bakery with his brothers, he opened a drygoods store in the small town of St. Marys. Following its success, he opened the first T. Eaton Co. in Toronto at 178 Yonge St., in 1869. It was less than 1,500 square feet and had a staff of just four, but it marked the beginning of an empire. The store was built on two principles: goods had one price - no haggling allowed - and honest dependability, captured in the long-standing slogan, "Goods satisfactory or money refunded." The business thrived, becoming one of the greatest retailers in Canada, making history with nearly every step.
By: Dave McGinn

Moment in time: Dec. 7, 1963 - Instant replay debuts in televised Army-Navy football game: Hot-shot director Tony Verna, 30, was in a taxi heading to Philadelphia Municipal Stadium when he revealed his plan to replay footage live during that day's Army-Navy football game on CBS. "You're going to do what?" play-by-play man Lindsey Nelson squawked. It had never been done, and a country was watching. President John F. Kennedy, who was assassinated 15 days earlier, had planned to attend; the game became a form of national mourning. Play after play, Verna watched in frustration as a 544-kilogram video machine spat out tape marred by static or previously recorded I Love Lucy episodes. Then Army quarterback Rollie Stichweh ran in a late touchdown. "Here it comes," Verna said. The run replayed on millions of TVs like magic. Fearing confusion, Nelson exclaimed, "Ladies and gentlemen, Army did not score again!"
By: James Bradshaw

Moment in time: Dec. 4, 2008 - Harper seeks and is granted permission to prorogue Parliament: People who care about such things still debate the prorogation of 2008. An overconfident minority Conservative government, fresh off its second election win, refused to run deficits to counter a worsening recession - but did cut funding for political parties in its economic statement. Furious, Liberal Leader Stéphane Dion and NDP Leader Jack Layton, supported by the Bloc Québécois, agreed to defeat the Conservatives and form a coalition government. To stop them, Stephen Harper asked Governor-General Michaëlle Jean to prorogue Parliament for several weeks, to let tempers cool and allow the government to prepare a budget replete with a huge deficit. Jean kept the PM waiting for two hours to show her displeasure, but then agreed. It took seven years for the Liberals to finally bring the Conservatives down.
By: John Ibbitson

Moment in time: Dec. 3, 1985 - Old Quebec City named a UNESCO World Heritage site: After travelling by steamboat from Montreal, Charles Dickens landed in Quebec City, took its measure and was smitten. He lauded its "giddy heights" and "picturesque steep streets." He praised the "frowning gateways" through its stone fortifications and declared the town the Gibraltar of America.

The year was 1842. More than 140 years later, the descriptions still held. The heart of Quebec City survived fires, demolitions, tourist hordes and other vagaries of history to remain a timeless gem. It led UNESCO to put Old Quebec on its World Heritage List. The city founded by Champlain, capital of New France and then the new British colony, was the only surviving walled city north of Mexico and the continent's most "complete fortified colonial town," the agency declared. Dickens could not have written a tale of one city any better. 
By: Ingrid Peritz

Moment in time: Dec. 2, 1962 - Winnipeg wins Grey Cup a day late in CFL 'Fog Bowl': 
The Grey Cup has a long tradition of weather-related drama, but one December weekend in Toronto 53 years ago has etched an enduring place in CFL lore. Exhibition Stadium's location on the shores of Lake Ontario often left it at the mercy of the elements, but when fog engulfed the Hamilton TigerCats and the Winnipeg Blue Bombers during the 50th Grey Cup, play became impossible. Winnipeg Tribune columnist Jack Matheson summed up the thoughts of those in attendance: "I don't know if it was a good game or not, I didn't see it." The referee agreed, and with Winnipeg leading 28-27 and 9 minutes 29 seconds remaining in the contest, he took the players off the field.
They returned the next day, but with no further scoring, the Blue Bombers secured their fourth championship in five years.
By: Paul Attfield

Moment in time: Dec. 1, 1761 - Marie Tussaud born in Strasbourg, France:
Visitors to Madame Tussauds' tourist attractions are greeted by the frozen, perfect smiles of Brad Pitt, Katy Perry and other celebrities. But the real Marie Tussaud's early work was sculpting death masks from the severed heads of France's aristocracy after their executions in the country's revolution of 1789. Imprisoned during the uprising, Tussaud avoided the guillotine by making the death masks of King Louis XVI, Marie Antoinette and other royalty, some of which were paraded as revolutionary trophies. Tussaud was eventually released from prison and began touring Britain to display her creations, which by then included Napoleon and some notorious serial killers.
By: Eric Atkins

Moment in time: Nov. 30, 1999 - WTO meeting in Seattle sets stage for massive protests: Tens of thousands of anti-trade protesters turned downtown Seattle into an urban battlespace in 1999 as a motley coalition of unionists, environmentalists and small groups of violent anti-capitalists gathered to vent their fury at the perils of globalization. Instead of a mundane meeting of World Trade Organization countries to launch a new round of trade talks, the protests and heavy-handed police response ignited furious street battles and a public debate over the merits and dangers of globalization. The protests, confrontations and outbreaks of violence attracted international media attention. Seattle police, in riot gear, unleashed tear gas and rubber bullets on protesters. More than 150 were arrested; all eventually were released without charge. Inside the besieged summit, talks broke down after a bitter deadlock among rich countries over farm subsidies. Outside, protesters danced in the streets at news of the failure.
By: Paul Koring

Moment in time: Nov. 27, 2005 - French patient receives first successful partial face transplant: The world's first partial face transplant was a merge of medical science and miracle. At the Centre Hospitalier Universitaire Nord in Amiens, France, surgeons Bernard Devauchelle, Benoît Lengelé and Jean-Michel Dubernard gingerly lifted a triangle of face tissue, including nose and mouth, from a brain-dead donor and grafted it onto 38-year-old Isabelle Dinoire, whose Labrador had mauled her face. The 15-hour surgery altered the patient's appearance - her original wide nose and thin lips replaced by a narrow nose and fuller mouth - but in 2007 Dinoire declared she was "very satisfied" with the outcome. The groundbreaking surgery led to further medical advances, most notably a 2010 procedure in which a team of 30 Spanish doctors performed the world's first full face transplant on a man injured in a shooting accident.
By: Andrew Ryan

Moment in time: Nov. 26, 1922 - Howard Carter reaches King Tut's tomb: Plundering preoccupied Howard Carter. Robbers had systematically ransacked the tombs in Egypt's Valley of the Kings, and the broken alabaster jars at the bottom of the excavated passageway told Carter someone had reached King Tut's treasures before him. He had been working on Egyptian digs since he was a 17-year-old artist with a gift for recording the details of pharaohs' tombs. Now at 48, his lifelong dream came down to a single moment. With his skeptical backer, Lord Carnarvon, looking on, he chipped a hole at the corner of a sealed inner doorway. "Can you see anything?" the impatient earl demanded. "Yes," Carter replied. "It is wonderful."

Gilded couches, painted caskets, a golden throne, two guardian ebony effigies - and between them, the door that led to Tutankhamen. 
By: John Allemang

Moment in time: Nov. 25, 1885 -  Process to create Canada's first national park begins: Perhaps William McCardell was a natural conservationist.

Or maybe he sensed a chance to earn a fast buck. What's clear is that when the Canadian Pacific Railway worker and two others stumbled upon a thermal spring in a misty cave on the slopes of Sulphur Mountain, they decided to cordon the area off to other visitors. In so doing, the trio created a crude boundary around what would later become Canada's first national park.

"Like some fantastic dream from a tale of the Arabian Nights" is how McCardell characterized his "discovery" of the hot spring in the fall of 1883 - the waters were well known to First Nations and earlier inhabitants of the Bow Valley. By 1885, the Cave and Basin historical site was subsumed by Banff National Park, which remains a modern refuge for Calgarians and is Canada's most-visited national park. 

By: Jeff Lewis

Moment in time: Nov. 24, 1963 - Jack Ruby shoots Lee Harvey Oswald on live television: NBC was on its third day of special programming, keeping a sombre televisual vigil after the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, when the network cut to the basement parking garage of the Dallas Police Department. As accused gunman Lee Harvey Oswald emerged from the elevators, the protective police cordon seemed to dissipate. A shadowy figure in a hat - identified later as Jack Rubenstein, a.k.a. Jack Ruby - bolted from the pack of waiting reporters, rushed for Oswald and fired a single shot into his belly. "The incident marked the first time in 15 years of television around the globe that a real-life homicide had occurred in front of live cameras," The New York Times noted. Oswald died during surgery at Parkland Hospital, just down the hall from where Kennedy had died two days earlier.
By: Simon Houpt

Moment in time: Nov. 23, 1936 - First issue of Life magazine released
There was life before Life. Life the magazine, that is. Today, if the magazine's remembered at all, it's for its most famous incarnation as a New York-based weekly packed with the world's best photojournalism, selling millions of copies. The original Life, founded in 1883, was an illustrationheavy, light-entertainment publication - until, that is, Time magazine founder Henry R. Luce bought it for $92,000 (U.S.). Life and only Life, Mr. Luce felt, could be the title for the mass-circulation, all-photograph weekly he was keen to launch. For the first cover story he assigned Margaret Bourke-White to travel to the Missouri River in Montana to photograph the construction of Fort Peck, then the world's largest earth-filled dam. An immediate hit, Life thrived as a weekly for the next 36 years, every cover emblazoned with that bold white-on-red LIFE logo. It limped on in various formats until 2007, when Time Inc. declared the print edition dead. 
By: James Adams

Moment in time: Nov. 20, 1945 - Nuremberg trials start: Seven months after Adolf Hitler's suicide and the end of fighting in Europe, 20 surviving Nazi leaders sat in a small, oak-panelled courtroom in the Palace of Justice in the Bavarian city of Nuremberg listening to a six-hour indictment of their war crimes. Facing a tribunal of judges from the victorious countries - Britain, France, the United States and Russia - they were accused of starting a war of aggression and horrendous atrocities, including organizing and carrying out the murder of millions. The verdicts came 10 months later, when a dozen of them, including Germany's former foreign minister Joachim von Ribbentrop and Luftwaffe leader Hermann Goering, were sentenced to death. Others got prison sentences, and a few were acquitted. Trials of dozens of lower-level Nazis continued for years afterward.
By: Richard Blackwell

Moment in time: Nov. 19, 1969 - Pele scores his 1,000th goal: Edson Arantes do Nascimento, known as Pele, scored his 1,000th career goal from the spot. "A penalty is a cowardly way to score," the Brazilian said later. Perhaps. But he'd slotted so many of such exquisite quality, the odd, rough smear on the canvas only highlighted the overall beauty of the work. After retrieving the ball, Pele jogged around the pitch, kissing it and crying. Reporters asked for his thoughts. "Now that everyone is listening," the 29-year-old said, "help the children, help the helpless." Looking on, the man on the wrong end of history was hanging in his net, bereft. "I didn't want to be that goalkeeper," Edgardo Andrada said. The Argentine knew in that moment that his 20-year career had been reduced to a footnote in Pele's story. A halfcentury later, he's been proved right.
By: Cathal Kelly

Moment in time: Nov. 18, 1929 - Atlantic tsunami hits Newfoundland's southern coast: Newfoundlanders know all too well that the ocean can take as much as she gives, but nobody foresaw this cataclysm. An underwater earthquake, with a magnitude of 7.2, struck about 250 kilometres south of the island's Burin Peninsula. Over the next half-hour, three giant waves began hurtling toward shore at up to 140 kilometres an hour. This rare Atlantic tsunami would take 28 lives - most of them women and children - rip homes from their foundations, destroy wharves, boats and flakes, and sweep provisions and fish that were about to be sold into the sea. Because the telegraph line had been damaged in an earlier storm, people in the 40 affected communities were on their own. That is until three days later, when the SS Portia made its scheduled stop, with the ship's captain spying a large store drifting along the shore.
By: Alison Gzowski

Moment in time: Sept. 29, 1898 - Canada holds national referendum on the prohibition of alcoholic beverages

The question was simple: "Are you in favour of the passing of an Act prohibiting the importation, manufacture or sale of spirits, wine, ale, beer, cider and all other alcoholic liquors for use as beverage?" It was the first national referendum in Canada's history, though it served mostly to prove how divided the country was. More than 80 per cent of Quebec voters said no to prohibition, while almost 90 per cent of Nova Scotians called for it. Over all, the non-binding plebiscite was almost perfectly balanced: 51 per cent for, 49 per cent against. But in the sober aftermath, the Laurier government decided not to act. The glass was half empty - only 44 per cent of the eligible voters, all men, had participated, and that wasn't enough to kill the party. - Jared Bland

Moment in time: Sept. 28, 1891 - Herman Melville dies in New York in virtual obscurity

Herman Melville, 72, author of Moby Dick, died of a heart attack at home while in his iron-frame bed. His funeral was a small affair - at his residence, near the old Madison Square Garden. The New York Times death notice mistakenly referred to him as Henry. His first two critically acclaimed novels - inspired by his time on a whaling ship - were followed by commercial flops. Moby Dick, published in 1851, was savaged by reviewers - "purposeless extravagance," and not worth its $1.50 price. He died a hermit and unknown. But a Canadian essayist and Dalhousie University professor saw a genius. In 1889, Archibald MacMechan wrote Melville lamenting that Moby Dick had not received "due recognition." In 1899, MacMechan published "The Best Sea Story Ever Written" in the Queen's Quarterly - echoing the revivalist movement that brought posthumous fame and made Melville a literary giant of the 20th century. - Affan Chowdhry

Moment in time: Sept. 25, 1992 - Mars Observer is launched into space

The state-of-the-art structure of metal, wheels, antennas and solar panels was to be cartographer, geologist, climatologist and physicist all in one. The Mars Observer was launched into space on Sept. 25, 1992, from Cape Canaveral as part of an $813-million (U.S.) mission. The spacecraft had been kitted out with a host of scientific instruments that were to observe, measure and report back on everything from the magnetic field around the Red Planet to its seasonal cycles. On Aug. 24, 1993, it was to enter into stable orbit around Mars, but just three days prior NASA lost contact. An investigation pointed to a fuel-line rupture as the most likely cause of the problem. To this day the whereabouts of the spacecraft are unknown. It might be orbiting Mars as intended, or might have been thrown off course and is now orbiting the sun. - Dakshana Bascaramurty

Moment in time: Sept. 24, 1905 - Fleming becomes first person to band a bird in Canada

The son of a Scottish immigrant who settled in Toronto, James Henry Fleming had been fascinated by birds since his teens. By the turn of the 20th century, Fleming was a respected ornithologist. One Sunday in the fall of 1905, he noted in his diary: "In the garden in the afternoon I caught a robin which I will release with a ring, Number 1." He had attached a tiny aluminum band to one of the bird's legs and then released it, to track where it wintered. "Notify The Auk. N.Y.," the band said, referring to the journal of the American Ornithologists' Union, of which Fleming was a member. It was the first time a bird had been banded in Canada, and one of the earliest banding attempts in North America. Since then, millions of birds have been banded in what is now a standard scientific tool to track migrations. - Tu Thanh Ha

Moment in time: Sept. 23, 1338 - A naval arms race begins

For most of naval history, it was risky to try to destroy an enemy vessel. A captain could ram it or send a flaming ship in its direction and hope for the best. It wasn't until the Hundred Years' War that artillery - offering the chance to punch a hole from a safe distance - was used at sea. It was in the Battle of Arnemuiden, near Bruges, when five grain-carrying English ships armed with a trio of cannons went up against 48 French vessels. The small armament of the English couldn't save the day, and all the prisoners were massacred, but the rules of engagement had changed. A seven-century naval arms race had begun. Ships wielded ever-more powerful guns manned by growing crews aboard bigger and stronger vessels. Not until the 20th century was the battleship supplanted by the aircraft carrier, launching warplanes instead of shells. - Oliver Moore

Moment in time: Sept. 22, 1862 - Lincoln issues preliminary Emancipation Proclamation

U.S. President Abraham Lincoln's first move to free the slaves was not absolute. The preliminary Emancipation Proclamation issued on Sept. 22, 1862, declared the three million slaves held in the South would be "thenceforward and forever, free" as of Jan. 1, 1863, if the rebel states abandoned the Civil War. No mention was made of the slaves held in the four border states whose support was critical for the Union forces. Naturally, the proclamation that made slavery - not the Union - the focus of the war that began more than a year earlier was ignored by the Confederacy, which did not give up the fight for independence and slave ownership for another three years. Nonetheless, Lincoln's proclamation marked the first step in a long, long journey African-Americans would take in their fight for civil rights. - Eric Atkins

Moment in time: Sept. 21, 1897 - New York Sun answers the Santa Claus question

The handwritten letter to the editor from eight-year-old Virginia O'Hanlon arrived in The New York Sun's mailbox long before the Christmas season. She needed to know the truth, because "some of my little friends say there is no Santa Claus." Her letter prompted the famous editorial, published on Sept. 21, 1897, "Yes Virginia, there is a Santa Claus." The unsigned editorial, written by Francis Church, explained: "He exists as certainly as love and generosity and devotion exist, and you know that they abound and give to your life its highest beauty and joy. Alas! how dreary would be the world if there were no Santa Claus! ... The eternal light with which childhood fills the world would be extinguished." When Ms. O'Hanlon was in hospital at the age of 80, just weeks before Christmas, thousands of letters of encouragement were delivered to the hospital for "the Santa Claus girl." She died months later and her obituary in The New York Times, in May, 1971, recounted how she came to pen her letter: The New York Sun was regarded in her family as the arbiter of disputes. "Father would always say, 'If you see it in The Sun, it's so' and that settled the matter." - Justine Hunter

Moment in time: Sept. 18, 1970 - Jimi Hendrix dies

Before he blazed into our consciousness, setting his guitar on fire at the 1967 Monterey Pop Festival, James Marshall Hendrix, born in Seattle on Nov. 27, 1942, and later to become better known as Jimi, would have to endure a childhood of deep poverty, dislocation and abuse. His first instrument was a broken ukulele he retrieved from the garbage when he was 15. Later that year, he found a cheap electric guitar, and with it in his hands, the self-taught musician would eventually become a guitarist without peer. By the mid-sixties, he would move to London, front the Jimi Hendrix Experience band and become the highest-paid rocker in the world. His heavily metalized rendition of the American national anthem at Woodstock would become arguably the most iconic moment of the festival. "Feeling, sweet feeling drops from my finger, fingers," he sang in Manic Depression. Famous for hits such as Purple Haze, Hey Joe and The Wind Cries Mary, Hendrix had a wild but short-lived ride atop the music world. He died in a London flat on Sept. 18, 1970, after choking on his own vomit while intoxicated with barbiturates. - Gary Mason

Moment in time: Sept. 17, 1916 - The Red Baron claims his first victims

A dashing Prussian aristocrat, Manfred von Richthofen embodied the chivalric mystique of First World War aces. Known in England as the Red Baron for the colour of his triplanes, he executed his first air combat victory of an eventual 80 - the most of any pilot in the conflict - with characteristic cold-blooded élan. Flying an Albatros D.II - a poky little machine to modern eyes - the Baron closed in on a British fighter over the northern French town of Cambrai. He killed both its observer and pilot - then, to celebrate, ordered an engraved silver cup from a jeweller in Berlin. Ruthless though they could be, early dogfights were relatively courtly compared with what followed. It was, ironically, another von Richthofen -Manfred's cousin Wolfram - who wrenched aerial warfare into its full modern brutality. As an officer in the German Condor Legion during the Spanish Civil War of 1936-39, Wolfram pioneered the bombing of cities to deplete civilian morale. Among his first targets: the small Basque city of Guernica. - Eric Andrew-Gee

Moment in time: Sept. 16, 1932 - Gandhi begins fast in protest of caste separation

While jailed in Yerwada prison for his latest civil disobedience campaign, Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi vowed to "fast unto death" or until the British stopped a new Indian constitution that would separate the electorate by caste. Gandhi, who was born into the wealthier Vaishya, or merchant, caste, predicted such a system would further segregate India's most underprivileged social class, known as "untouchables" because of the menial jobs their ancestors performed. His hunger strike ended after six days when the British agreed to an alternate proposal that did not divide the electorate. Though India's constitution makes it illegal to discriminate based on caste, the country is still grappling with social problems caused by the centuries-old hierarchy, especially outside its major cities. This summer, tens of thousands of members from a land-owning caste took to the streets in the state of Gujarat to protest the Indian government's affirmative-action quotas. They want the removal of a system that has reserved space for members of the lower castes in educational institutions and the public service since the country gained independence. - Mike Hager

Moment in time: Sept. 15, 1963 - Four black schoolgirls killed in Alabama church bombing

Denise McNair was 11 years old. Addie Mae Collins, Carole Robertson and Cynthia Wesley were 14. The four girls were at the 16th Street Baptist Church in Birmingham, Ala., for a youth service when a bomb ripped through the building and killed them. Twenty-two others were injured. The bombing of the predominantly black church was carried out by white supremacists and intended to stop civil-rights advances in the thoroughly segregated city. The explosion occurred days after Birmingham was ordered by the courts to desegregate its schools and less than three weeks after Martin Luther King Jr.'s "I Have a Dream" speech. The deaths would spark immense outrage and help galvanize the civil-rights movement, with the Civil Rights Act passed the following year. In 2013, the four girls were posthumously awarded the Congressional Gold Medal, the highest honour the U.S. Congress can award civilians. Black churches remain a target for white supremacists - a gunman has been charged with killing nine people at a Charleston, S.C., church in June. - Sunny Dhillon

Moment in time: Sept. 14, 1994 - Expos' dreams die as baseball season cancelled

The Expos were not alone in their dejection when acting commissioner Bud Selig, pictured, announced the cancellation of the 1994 Major League Baseball season. Many dreams were bitterly deferred by the players' strike that summer. But nowhere was the sense of thwarted potential stronger than in Montreal. The team had a mouth-watering record of 74-40 - the best in baseball - and sent five players to the All-Star Game. The roster was studded with young talent such as Larry Walker, Moises Alou and Pedro Martinez. The perennial also-rans seemed ready to take on all comers. It was not to be: Lost revenue from those cancelled games blew a hole in the Expos' finances, and the team traded away many of its best players the following spring. Nos Amours never recovered - the team was relocated to Washington after the 2004 season. - Eric Andrew-Gee

Moment in time: Sept. 11, 1942 - Women required to register for war-time employment

"The supply of unemployed men is exhausted. We shall put our dependence on womanpower." With those words, the federal government announced that all childless women between the ages of 20 and 24 were required to register for work with the National Selective Service. Within a year, a million women were employed, double the number in 1939. Many took up jobs in war-related industries, including a third of the aerospace industry. Women with children could stay home, the government said, but the shortage of labour was so severe that officials opened dozens of nurseries for children from two to five years old, to encourage mothers to work too. Surveys at the time showed that most women had no interest in giving up their jobs after the war. And many didn't. By 1951, a third of mothers were working, three times as many as before the war. - Simona Chiose

Moment in time: Sept. 10, 1963- Twenty black students enter Alabama public schools following standoff

Alabama Governor George Wallace promised "segregation forever" in the "cradle of the Confederacy" and ordered armed soldiers to stop black children from attending white schools. President John F. Kennedy had different ideas, and took federal control of the Alabama National Guard to force the state to comply with a Supreme Court ruling that struck down racial segregation. As a result, 20 black students entered schools in Birmingham, Tuskegee and Mobile on Sept. 10, 1963. The desegregation, which lagged that of other southern states, came amid protests and violence, and was followed by a bombing five days later that killed four black girls at a Birmingham church, another bloody reminder the civil-rights movement faced a long battle for equality. - Eric Atkins

Moment in time: Sept. 9, 1979 - Lynn Johnston premieres her For Better or For Worse cartoon strip

When readers in Canada and the United States opened their newspapers on Sept. 9, 1979, they met the Pattersons, a family rooted in a fictitious Ontario town. For Better or For Worse, the comic creation of Canadian Lynn Johnston, was born. The series, which was based on Johnston's family and progressed in real time, chronicled the lives of Elly, John, Michael, Elizabeth and April, who was born in 1991. Fans grew attached to the characters - for better or for worse: When Michael's friend came out as gay in 1993, conservative newspapers boycotted the strip; when the family dog died saving April from drowning in 1995, Johnston received hundreds of emotional letters. For Better or For Worse ended its original run in 2008, but not before appearing in more than 2,000 newspapers globally. A Pulitzer Prize nominee, Johnston was the first Canadian and first woman to win the National Cartoonists Society's most prestigious annual award. - Kathryn Blaze Baum

Moment in time: Sept. 8, 1991 - Concrete beam falls in Montreal's Olympic Stadium

"The Montreal Olympics can no more have a deficit than a man can have a baby," assured Montreal Mayor Jean Drapeau in 1973. So launched the construction of Olympic Stadium, on of the most renowned money pits in Canadian history - marred with labour problems, structural issues and a chronically malfunctioning retractable roof made of a bullet resistant material that proved no match for the city's weather. The most serious result of these follies appeared in 1991, when a combination of shoddy new renovations and shoddy old construction sent a 55-ton chunk of concrete crashing down into the exterior walkway. Nobody was hurt, but the accident forced the Expos baseball team to play their final 13 games on the road. Final cost for the venue: $836-million, or about $1.5 billion when the mortage was finally paid off in 2006, seven years after Mr. Drapeau's death. - Patrick White

Moment in time: Sept. 7, 1991 - Worst hail storm in Canadian history

The clouds began to roll in and the wind started whipping up about the time many Calgary residents were sitting down to their Saturday evening meal. Then the skies emptied and what followed was the worst hail storm in Canadian history - a half-hour of severe weather that sent hail the size of golf balls onto the city's northern suburbs. The hail broke windows, dented cars, downed trees and even crushed flocks of migrating birds with its weight. Motorists found themselves stranded on streets transformed into lakes. Homeowners filed 116,000 insurance claims, with property damage estimated at more than $300-million. In the days after the storm, developers of neighbourhoods on the slopes of Nose Hill were criticized for not considering the paths rainwater would take as it travelled downhill to the Bow River and city engineers promised a response. - Elizabeth Church

Moment in time: Sept. 4, 1972 - Montreal museum is robbed in largest art theft in Canadian history

The thief climbed a tree to reach the roof of the two-storey museum, and passed a ladder to two waiting accomplices after midnight on Sept. 4, 1972. Masked and armed, the trio slipped inside the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts through a skylight and lowered themselves to the floor. They overpowered three guards and would make off with art worth $2-million, including jewellery, figurines and 18 paintings. The prize of their haul was Rembrandt's 1654 Landscape with Cottages, worth $1-million.

The unsolved art theft remains Canada's largest, but it could have been worse: The burglars were startled by an alarm and fled with their loot, leaving behind a pile of paintings they had stacked on the floor. - Eric Atkins

Moment in time: Sept. 2, 490 BC - Pheidippides inspires the marathon

Pheidippides did not run 40 kilometres from Marathon to Athens, much less announce a victory over the Persians with his dying words. The truth is more impressive: The professional messenger made a 250-kilometre overnight run from Athens to Sparta, which included a hallucinated conversation with the god Pan in the high mountains, to seek urgent military aid against the barbarian invaders. The Spartans hesitated - they'd like to help, they said, but would be delayed by some religious obligations. Pheidippides immediately turned around and dashed home with the discouraging news. The original marathon of the 1896 Athens Olympics honoured the romanticized version and started near the battlefield. But in 1983, the more authentic 'Spartathlon' was inaugurated so that runners could retrace the route of the real Pheidippides - the record time for the one-way race is 20 hours and 25 minutes, including hallucinations. - John Allemang

Moment in time: Sept. 1, 1969 - King Idris of Libya is deposed in coup that brings Gadhafi to power

At 79, Libya's first (and last) monarch, King Idris, was in the Turkish town of Bursa with its renowned thermal springs, seeking relief from rheumatism. Back home, soldiers seized the palace, police stations and airwaves - facing little resistance. The King's entourage waved the news off as unimportant, but the constitutional monarchy era that began in 1951 was over, and the coup redefined Libya as a socialist republic under one man's iron rule: Moammar Gadhafi. Leading up to the overthrow, Libyans increasingly looked past the unifying symbol of the King to Arab nationalist movements that called for an end to western bases. In the end, the King was shown through a Turkish hotel laundry room to avoid crowds of reporters before sailing for Greece and later settling in Egypt - never to return home.

Moment in time: Aug. 31, 1971 - Albertans wake up to a new era of Tory rule 

A new political dynasty dawned in Alberta as, for the first time since 1935, a party other than Social Credit prepared to take power. Under leader Peter Lougheed's campaign slogan "NOW!" and a focus on the economic possibilities of oil and gas, the Progressive Conservatives picked up almost all of Alberta's urban ridings, sweeping Edmonton and winning all but four of Calgary's seats to oust the Social Credit government that had ruled since 1935. The PCs had 49 seats to the Socreds' 25 when the results came in, while Grant Notley won the NDP's sole seat. Lougheed died in 2012, three years before the political tide would change again in Alberta. The NDP's "orange wave," led by Rachel Notley (Grant's daughter), took the party to a historic majority government - winning all the Edmonton ridings and leaving the PCs with just eight seats in Calgary. - Madeline Smith

Moment in time: Aug. 28, 1971 - First large-scale gay-rights rally takes place on Parliament Hill

Standing in the rain on Parliament Hill, gay and lesbian activists gathered for the first large-scale gay-rights demonstration in Canada. They read a list of 10 demands, including the right to serve in the military and "all legal rights for homosexuals which currently exist for heterosexuals." Two years earlier, amendments to the Criminal Code allowed sexual relationships between any two consenting adults older than 21, effectively decriminalizing homosexuality. But the activists argued that they had hardly achieved equality. It would be 25 years before sexual orientation was added to the Canadian Human Rights Act. The ban on gays and lesbians in the Armed Forces was lifted in 1992, and in 2005 Bill C-38 gave same-sex couples the right to marry across the country.- Madeline Smith

Moment in time: Aug. 27, 1973 - Supreme Court upholds legality of Indian Act

After Jeannette Corbière Lavell married a non-First Nations man and lost her Indian status, her on-reserve home and treaty benefits, she lost her case to the Supreme Court, too. In a 5-4 vote, the court ruled the Bill of Rights didn't apply to section 12(1)(b) of the Indian Act, which said indigenous women who married non-indigenous men were no longer Indians. Under the act, men who married non-indigenous women remained Indians and their wives and children acquired status, too. The law was finally reversed in 1985 when Sandra Lovelace challenged it through the UN Human Rights Committee. The federal government passed Bill C-31, allowing indigenous women who married non-indigenous men to have their status restored. Today, Kahnawake Mohawks filed in response to the territory's 'marry out, get out' policy, which prohibits Mohawks who marry non-indigenous people from living on reserve, are ongoing. - Kristy Hoffman
Cartoon of the day: "Taste of summer" by Brian Gable

Moment in time: August 26, 1971 - Orr inks first million-dollar contract

At the start of the 1971-72 season, Bobby Orr was at the height of his power. He had already made history in professional hockey to become the NHL's highest-paid player in 1966. But he broke that record when he signed a five-year contract with the Boston Bruins, with a pay of $200,000 (U.S.) a year. That put the total value of the contract at $1-million, the first-ever in NHL history. His agent, Alan Eagleson, was key in the negotiations. But Orr never got to see much of the money. In his biography, Orr says Eagleson tightly controlled his life and mismanaged his finances to the point where Orr had to declare bankruptcy. Still, the million-dollar contract opened the door for seven-figure deals, which now are routine in the NHL. - Oliver Sachgau

Moment in time: Aug. 25, 1944 - Paris is liberated from Nazi occupation

More than four years of Nazi occupation in France ended when Allied and French Resistance forces entered Paris and took control of the city, driving the Germans out. The liberating forces met Parisians who were "mad with joy," the Associated Press reported. Adolf Hitler had ordered that the city not be handed over "except lying in complete debris," but Paris was still standing when General Dietrich von Choltitz surrendered. He claimed that he defied Hitler's order because he was unwilling to destroy the City of Light. It was a major symbolic victory for the Allies and put an end to the Vichy regime in France. But while Free French General Charles de Gaulle led a victory march down the Champs-Élysées the following day, the Second World War wasn't officially over for another nine months. - Madeline Smith

Moment in time: August 24, 1989 - Cincinnati Reds manager Pete Rose exiled for betting on baseball

In March, 1989, Cincinnati Reds manager Pete Rose (also known as "Charlie Hustle") stood behind an armed guard at a team spring training game, after Major League Baseball announced just two days prior he was suspected of betting on games. As his players spread out on the field in Florida that night, his professional life was officially on the line. After the long investigation culminated, which dug up betting sheets with Rose's fingerprints on them, he was exiled from the game with an Aug. 24 news conference. It would take 15 years for him to admit he had gambled, but not on his own team. The ban prohibits the "Hit King" - so named for his record total career hits of 4,256 - from being inducted into baseball's Hall of Fame. However, the league's new commissioner, Rob Manfred, is said to be reviewing Rose's longstanding application for reinstatement. - Kristy Hoffman
