Moment in time: Aug. 21, 1986 - Thousands killed by poisonous volcano
Scientists knew Lake Nyos, a volcanic lake in Cameroon, West Africa, had a large amount of carbon dioxide trapped in it. But they weren't expecting a large-scale disaster, especially after some of the gas had already escaped in 1984. But during an August night, somewhere between 100,000 and 300,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide were suddenly released. The gas rose at nearly 100 kilometres an hour and sped into the valley, pushing away all the air. Once it reached the villages, nearly every living being caught in the eruption suffocated and died. The death toll was estimated at more than 1,700. Of those, 1,200 were in the village of Nios, where four people survived. Studies of the lake since have found more gas was forming at the bottom of the lake, so a pump was installed in 2001 that would remove gas from the lake faster than it could recharge. - Oliver Sauchgau

Moment in time: Aug. 20, 1965 - Rolling Stones release Satisfaction in U.K.

One of the Rolling Stones' biggest hits came to Keith Richards in a dream. "Da-da da-da-da, I can't get no satisfaction," goes 30 seconds of a tape the guitarist-songwriter woke up to record mid-sleep in early 1965. Frontman Mick Jagger picked up the melody and penned the lyrics poolside in Las Vegas later that month. The single was released in June in the United States, but was initially banned by the BBC in the group's native England, where it could only be heard on pirate radio (it was finally released in Britain in August). Jagger said the lyrics came from youth's frustration during that period, which was evinced in the frenetic first live performances of the song in concert and on TV. Fifty years later, the Stones are still singing it. They just wrapped up a tour last month and Jagger's moves still manifest that need for satisfaction. - Verity Stevenson

Moment in time: August 19, 1960 - Canine cosmonauts go to space - and back

It must have been a crowded party. The Soviet satellite Korabl-Sputnik 2 carried 40 mice, two rats, plants and two dogs, Belka and Strelka. Less than a month before, a satellite carrying two other dogs disintegrated during launch, killing both animals. The Soviets needed Korabl-Sputnik 2 to return successfully in order to prove humans could survive space flight. At 8:44:06 UTC, Korabl-Sputnik 2 launched, and Belka and Strelka made it into space, orbiting Earth 17 times. Part of the mission was to intercept a U.S. satellite, and audio recordings reveal both dogs barking at it, but that was the closest they'd come to an intercept. The dogs' story has a happy ending, as they both made it back to Earth alive the next day. Strelka even went on to have a litter of six puppies, one of which was given to John F. Kennedy's daughter, Caroline. - Oliver Sachgau
Cartoon of the day: "On balance ... " by Brian Gable

Moment in time: August 18, 1958 - Lolita is published in the United States

Humbert Humbert, 37, justifies his attraction to 12-year-old Dolores Haze with comparisons: Dante and Beatrice; Petrarch and Laura. His ripe language - Nabokov's language - at times makes you forget it's describing a prepubescent girl. ("Light of my life, fire of my loins. My sin, my soul," the book begins.) At other times, it makes you cringe. So scandalous was Lolita, the Russian émigré's third novel, it took five years - and a stint in France before being banned there - to get published in the United States. "Dull, dull, dull" and "repulsive," New York Times reviewer Orville Prescott called it that day. The next, a wave of reviews, including one by Dorothy Parker, praised it and ignited its success. Its second sentence: "The tip of the tongue taking a trip of three steps down the palate to tap, at three, on the teeth. Lo. Lee. Ta." - Verity Stevenson

Moment in time: June 26, 1925 - Charlie Chaplin's The Gold Rush premieres in Hollywood

Barrymore! Pickford! Fairbanks! Every big star of 1925 Hollywood turned up at Grauman's Egyptian Theatre for Charlie Chaplin's The Gold Rush - as did more than 15,000 fans. The silent comedy was written, produced and directed by Chaplin, who naturally reprised his Little Tramp persona to play a luckless everyman trying to survive the Yukon gold rush. Conspicuously absent from the premiere was Chaplin's wife, teenaged actress Lita Grey, who was originally supposed to co-star in the film. Five days later, an announcement went out that Grey had given birth to Charlie Chaplin Jr. As it turned out, Charlie Jr. had been born several weeks before, but since his parents had only been married six months, Charlie Sr. paid a doctor to falsify the birth certificate. Scandal averted, The Gold Rush went on to become the highest-grossing silent comedy in cinema history. - Andrew Ryan

Moment in Time: June 25, 1993 - Kim Campbell takes office as Canada's first female PM

On the day she became the country's first female prime minister, Kim Campbell wanted to project an image of austerity. The Canadian economy was sputtering, and if more than 11 per cent of the labour force was unemployed, she would put some ministers out of work, too. Only 24 were appointed, one of the smallest cabinets Ottawa had seen in decades, and government departments were combined, restructured or eliminated. The theme continued to her swearing-in at Rideau Hall. Politicians took taxis, not limos, and deputy prime minister Jean Charest and his family arrived on foot. Inexpensive wine was served. At Campbell's first Parliament Hill social function, guests were even charged a $5 cover. Four months later, she, too, would be cut, as the Progressive Conservatives lost the election in a historic rout. -Chris Hannay

Moment in time: June 24, 1948 - Soviets impose blockade on Berlin

The Soviet move to close all road and railway access to the German capital touched off fears of a new battle in a continent still shattered by the Second World War. Moscow's action was a bid to persuade the United States, Britain and France to withdraw from Berlin. But the Allies saw the city as a valuable outpost in Eastern Europe and a rampart against communism in an increasingly chilly Cold War. They briefly considered a military response to ensure Berliners had access to food and water. Instead, they launched a massive airlift, supplying goods to the city by plane - and delivering more than two million tonnes by the time the Soviets relented and ended the failed blockade almost a year later. - Eric Atkins
Cartoon of the day: 'First past the post' by Brian Gable

Moment in time: June 23, 1926 - Preacher Sister Aimee reappears after five-week 'abduction'

The celebrity evangelist known around the world as Sister Aimee had been given up for dead until she suddenly re-emerged in the Mexican desert. In a bedside interview, Aimee Semple McPherson claimed a man and woman had lured her to a car while she was swimming at Venice Beach, and asked her to pray for their sick child. They drugged her, drove her across the border and held her in a shack until she escaped five weeks later. To this day, this episode in the life of one of the most influential preachers of the 20th century hasn't been fully explained. Did she fabricate her kidnapping and run away with a radio sound engineer who disappeared at the same time? The scandal did not diminish her popularity. McPherson attracted thousands of followers to her white-domed church in Los Angeles and her radio broadcasts, paving the way for modern televangelists.
- Karen Howlett

Moment in time: June 22, 1969—The Cuyahoga River catches fire in Ohio.

The real shocker about the Cuyahoga River catching fire in 1969? It wasn't the first time. The famously toxic waterway winding through northeast Ohio had caught fire on at least a dozen previous occasions, the first time in 1868 and including a 1952 whopper that caused more than $1-million in damages. But the 1969 fire - a minor mid-river blaze of oil-soaked debris doused by firefighter tugboats - made the cover of Time magazine (though the cover shot was from the 1952 fire). Besides providing a dark counterpoint for the nascent environmental movement, the fire inspired Randy Newman to pen the acidic ditty Burn On. More important, the incident forced the U.S. government to address water pollution, which in turn resulted in the Clean Water Act and the creation of the federal Environmental Protection Agency. And the Cuyahoga hasn't caught fire since. - Andrew Ryan

Moment in time: June 19, 1999- Prince Edward marries Sophie Rhys-Jones

On a blustery afternoon, 34-year-old commoner Sophie Rhys-Jones climbed the steps of St. George's Chapel at Windsor Castle to marry her prince. Born in Oxford, she had forged a career in public relations before meeting Prince Edward, Earl of Wessex and the Queen's youngest son.
The two met in 1993 at a match of real tennis - a racquet sport played on an asymmetrical court. Rhys-Jones had started her own PR firm in 1996, but that didn't save her from a media nightmare weeks before the wedding. The British tabloid The Sun printed a decade-old racy photo of her with the headline "Sophie Topless." Buckingham Palace said it was "premeditated cruelty," and the woman who sold the photo lost her job. The royal drama subsided, and Welsh gold wedding rings sealed a union that has withstood the test of time thus far- Jacqueline Nelson

Moment in time: June 18, 1815- Napoleon meets his Waterloo in afternoon of battle

By nightfall, at least 10,000 men had been slaughtered in an epic battle on blood-soaked fields south of Brussels. Defeated by British and Prussian armies, Napoleon saw the end of both his quixotic, 100-day second stint as Emperor of the French, and France's supremacy in the Western world.
Unlike the slow annihilation of his army by Russia's bitter winter three years earlier, Napoleon "met his Waterloo" in a single afternoon of furious fighting in muddy slop, as artillery blasts tore infantry to shreds and cavalry charged with sabres flashing. Nearly 200,000 men fought; tens of thousands were wounded. Napoleon lost, but it was "the nearest-run thing you ever saw," the victorious Duke of Wellington admitted. Napoleon's vainglorious vision ended in solitary exile on a remote island, while Britain emerged as the global power of the 19th century.- Paul Koring

Moment in time: June 17, 1982- Roberto Calvi, 'God's banker,' dies mysteriously in London

God's banker was dead. Roberto Calvi, chairman of Italy's Banco Ambrosiano, was found hanging from the Blackfriars Bridge near London's financial district, his pockets stuffed with cash and bricks. Calvi, known for his ties to the Vatican Bank and to the Mafia, had allegedly angered some powerful people when his bank, the second-largest in Italy at the time, collapsed in a financial scandal. Calvi had already been convicted in Italy of making illegal money transfers, and he was facing more charges when he shaved off his mustache and fled to England. There was talk that his death was not a suicide, and mentions of a dark Masonic sect and mob hit men seeking to avenge lost money. But it would be 25 years before five people went on trial - and were cleared - in Calvi's death.- Eric Atkins
Cartoon of the day: "Remember when?" by Brian Gable

Moment in time: June 16, 1963- Valentina Tereshkova becomes first woman in space

Having beaten the United States into orbit, Soviet space program officials saw another chance to score a propaganda win by launching the first female cosmonaut. Their search for a candidate led them to Tereshkova, a Communist youth leader, factory worker and qualified skydiver who could handle being ejected from her Vostok 6 space capsule after re-entry and parachuting to Earth - standard landing procedure at the time. The 26-year-old Tereshkova did not have an easy ride. During nearly three days in orbit she threw up and suffered with a persistent leg cramp, among other discomforts.

She realized the spacecraft was not oriented properly and had to persuade skeptical ground controllers to make a correction that likely saved her life.

Now 78, she lives in Russia and took part in opening ceremonies at the 2014 Winter Games in Sochi.- Ivan Semeniuk

Moment in time: June 15, 1992- U.S. vice-president Dan Quayle misspells 'potato'

"It was more than a gaffe," former Republican U.S. Vice President Dan Quayle wrote in his memoirs of his famous spelling mistake. "It was a 'defining moment' of the worst imaginable kind." However, Mr. Quayle was already well-known for his foot-in-mouth disease before the fateful campaign stop in Trenton, N.J., where he oversaw a spelling bee. 
Aides had even checked the words in advance, to ensure they were easy.
But when sixth-grader William Figueroa, 12, wrote "potato" on the blackboard, the vice-president told him he had left off an "e" at the end. To be fair, the word was also misspelled on the flashcard Mr. Quayle had in his hand. A media frenzy followed, and William was on the David Letterman show within days. Mr. Quayle's place in history as a punchline was secured. -Jeff Gray

Moment in time: June 12, 1986- Ontario doctors begin 25-day strike over fees

Day 1 of Ontario's first provincewide doctors' strike began with rotating walkouts, some hospitals treating only life-threatening cases and an emergency department in Toronto closing its doors. "This is a war," declared one doctor. For the next 25 days, TV screens were filled with scenes of white-coated doctors waving placards on the Ontario Legislature lawn. At one point, Premier David Peterson was called a "gutless tyrant." Doctors walked off the job over proposed legislation that would take away their freedom to charge patients fees above provincial insurance rates. For many doctors, this threatened their cherished independence from government. The strike failed to stop the ban on extra billing. It wouldn't be the last time doctors clashed with government and appeared to be looking out for their own financial interests. -Karen Howlett

Moment in time: June 11, 1955- Collision at Le Mans 24-hour motor race kills spectators 

What had looked to be one of the greatest races since the Second World War culminated in the worst disaster in motorsports history, killing 84 people and injuring 120. Early on in the star-studded event, Mike Hawthorn's Jaguar turned abruptly into the pits, causing a trailing Austin-Healey to swerve across the track - right into the path of Pierre Levegh's Mercedes, travelling at 240 km/h. The collision shot the Merc into the air before it split into three pieces on landing, killing Levegh. Hay bales offered little protection for onlookers, the hood of the car decapitating some like a guillotine, while racing fuel exploded onto others. Concerned that stopping the race would clog roads and prevent ambulances getting through, organizers decided to carry on, allowing Hawthorn to take the chequered flag and celebrate with champagne. -Paul Attfield

Moment in time: June 10, 2000- Swaying Millennium bridge makes Londoners green around gills 

Bridges are meant to span the waves, not move like them.

When the Millennium pedestrian bridge spanning the River Thames in central London opened - overbudget and behind schedule - it swayed so dizzyingly that people crossing it joked that they needed seasickness pills. A victim of its own popularity, the Norman Foster-designed bridge welcomed an unexpectedly huge crowd of 160,000 on its opening weekend. As the bridge swayed, pedestrians changed their gait to steady themselves, and began to move in lockstep. This only increased the wobble, as the engineering firm Arup discovered. The £18-million bridge closed for repairs just three days after opening. Twenty months, £5-million and 91 shock-absorbing "dampers" later, it reopened and remains a beloved (and steady) friend to Londoners.- Elizabeth Renzetti

Moment in time: June 9, 1934- Donald Duck makes his first screen appearance

Long before he became a blustery big-screen superstar, Donald Duck was a bit player in the Disney cartoon universe. Sporting a longer bill - but wearing his unmistakable sailor cap and jacket - the wisecracking waterfowl made his debut in the Silly Symphonies short The Wise Little Hen. The seven-minute film finds Donald (voiced by Clarence Nash) and barnyard pal Peter Pig doing their utmost to avoid helping the Wise Little Hen with her corn harvest. The Little Wise Hen naturally catches on, and the story wraps with Donald and Peter repenting their shiftless ways by repeatedly kicking each other's behinds. Over the next five decades, Donald starred in more than 150 theatrical features and spawned a cartoon lineage that included nephews Huey, Dewey and Louie, and his love interest Daisy Duck. - Andrew Ryan

Moment in time: June 8, 1949- George Orwell's Nineteen Eighty-Four is published

Eric Blair struggled mightily with Nineteen Eighty-Four.

"The execution would have been better," he told his agent, "if I had not written it under the influence of TB." The author known as George Orwell, an Etonian scholar who turned himself into a tramping Everyman, craved adversity as the ultimate reality test. To create his chilling vision of a totalitarian dystopia - alternative title: The Last Man in Europe - the recently widowed journalist fled to a bare-bones cottage in the Scottish Hebrides, as far as possible from what he would mockingly call civilization, and began coughing blood.

The climate was so foul and his tuberculosis so debilitating that he did most of his work in bed. "Of course it's awkward to type there," he told a friend. Seven months after his bedbound masterpiece was published, he was dead. -John Allemang

Moment in time: June 5, 1963- British war minister Profumo resigns amid sex-for-spying scandal

The Profumo affair had all the makings of a British sex scandal - a middle-aged and married cabinet minister, a Russian spy and a 21-year-old call girl who was sleeping with both. When rumours of his trysts with Christine Keeler could no longer be ignored, John Profumo, the secretary of state for war, stood in Parliament and denied it. Ten weeks later, he admitted he had lied, and resigned, his confession eventually bringing down the government of Harold Macmillan. Yevgeny Ivanov, the Russian attaché, fled England before the scandal broke and was never proven to be a spy. But Keeler, in her 2013 book, admitted she "betrayed her country" by bedding Profumo to extract secrets about missile movements that were shared with the Cold War enemy. -Eric Atkins

Moment in time: June 4, 1972- All-white jury acquits black activist Angela Davis

Angela Davis, Black Power activist, radical intellectual, Communist - and an incendiary speaker who routinely referred to police as "pigs" - was acquitted by an all-white California jury of murder and kidnapping, capping a 22-month drama emblematic of the bitter racial divide of the time.
Davis had purchased the guns used by a 17-year-old African-American to kidnap a judge, a prosecutor and jurors from a Marin County courtroom in a scheme to trade them for the release of the Soledad Brothers. The kidnapping ended bloodily, with the judge and three others killed in a wild gunfight with police. Davis fled, shaved her iconic Afro and was a fugitive for months. After her arrest, then-president Richard Nixon hailed the FBI for the "capture of the dangerous terrorist, Angela Davis," while a "Free Angela" movement attracted worldwide donations for her defence.- Paul Koring

Moment in time: June 3, 1989- SkyDome opens to the heavens - and the rain

The opening-night gala for Toronto's SkyDome featured an eclectic mix of performers - a precision motorcycle team, the world's longest kick line, rock band Glass Tiger, even TV dad Alan Thicke. But never mind Jason Seaver: the real star of the show was the stadium's revolutionary retractable roof, and dome officials had no intention of letting a rainstorm keep them from showing it off. So as the Toronto Symphony accompanied jazz pianist Oscar Peterson on Prelude to Forever, the $40-million motorized roof peeled itself back and the heavens poured in, drenching 50,000 spectators and wreaking watery havoc on what remained of the show. Skydivers skidded on the wet concrete. Dancers wiped out. Makeup ran down faces. Still, owners of the SkyDome - now called the Rogers Centre - insisted they made the right call.- By Kelly Grant

Moment in time: June 2, 1966- Surveyor 1 touches down on the moon

Three years before Neil Armstrong set foot on the lunar surface, Surveyor 1 set the stage by becoming the first U.S. spacecraft to soft-land on the moon. The mission was over-budget and behind schedule, touching down more than four months after its Soviet counterpart, Luna 9. But it was also bigger, more robust and a better test of the sort of landing system that would be needed to get human astronauts safely onto the moon. By the time its mission ended six weeks later, Surveyor 1 radioed back 11,240 images of its landing site on Oceanus Procellarum (the Ocean of Storms) and provided information about the load-bearing capacity of lunar soil. Together with a sister series of lunar orbiters, the Surveyor program is credited with giving birth to planetary science.

Moment in time: June 1, 1980- CNN signs on for its first broadcast day 

The United States's first 24-hour news channel began with founder Ted Turner promising viewers: ''We won't be signing off until the world ends.'' The brash owner of the Atlanta Braves, who had already transformed the old-movie cable outlet TBS into TV's first superstation, launched his Cable News Network from a makeshift studio (formerly a country club) in midtown Atlanta. CNN struggled financially its first few years, but with the arrival of bankable personalities - Bernard Shaw, Paula Zahn, Larry King - and the opening of foreign bureaus, the network eased into profitability. In decades to follow, CNN's media ascension was commensurate with its real-time coverage of such stories as the Gulf War, the O.J. Simpson trial, Hurricane Katrina and 9/11. While formats and staff have changed over 35 years, CNN remains the go-to channel for breaking news worldwide.

Moment in time: May 29, 1985- Steve Fonyo completes cross-Canada run for cancer research 

Steve Fonyo was inspired by Terry Fox. Four years after Fox had to abandon his cross-Canada run in Thunder Bay when his cancer returned, Fonyo, who was also from B.C. and had lost a leg to cancer, decided to finish it. He succeeded, running from coast to coast on his artificial leg. A beach was named after him, a couple of roads bear his name and he received the Order of Canada. But since Fonyo's triumph, his life has been plagued by troubles, from cocaine addiction to depression and convictions for impaired driving, assault with a weapon, theft and fraud. In 2009, he was stripped of his Order of Canada. Violence came into his life earlier this year when he was stabbed in a home invasion. Despite having raised $14-million for cancer research, Fonyo lacked the charisma and appeal of terry Fox and was viewed as a copycat, not a hero.

Moment in time: May 28, 1967- Francis Chichester completes solo sail around the world 

When businessman and adventurer Francis Chichester arrived in Plymouth, England, after his unprecedented 226-day solo sail around the world, he was greeted by a crowd of 250,000, a flotilla of welcoming boats and a Royal Artillery 10-gun salute. His 53-foot yacht, Gipsy Moth IV, had crossed nearly 46,000 kilometres of ocean, rounding both the Cape of Good Hope and Cape Horn, with a seven-week stop in Sydney. It was a journey of constant seasickness, capsizes, 40-foot waves and a poorly performing boat, all endured by the 65-year-old Chichester along with chronic pain and cramping in his leg. Soon after, he was knighted. The Queen used the same sword that Elizabeth I had used to dub Sir Francis Drake - the first Englishman to circumnavigate the globe (though not alone).

Moment in time: May 27, 1995- Christopher Reeve paralyzed in fall from his horse 

As the Man of Steel, Christopher Reeve was faster than a speeding bullet, more powerful than a locomotive and able to leap tall buildings in a single bound. An invincible and beloved comic-book hero, Superman spent his days saving Earth from the clutches of the villainous Lex Luthor. In reality, Reeve was just a hard-working actor with a keen passion for riding horses, a hobby he described as ''the most dangerous thing I do.'' Those words would prove a telling portent. At an equestrian event in Culpeper, Va., his horse, Eastern Express, stood him up at a jump, throwing Reeve to the ground, where he landed head first. Despite wearing a helmet, he shattered two vertebrae and was paralyzed from the neck down. Reeve dedicated the remainder of his life to raising awareness of spinal cord injuries.

Moment in time: May 26, 1974- Hysterical teens stampede at David Cassidy concert

That March, pop star David Cassidy had been described as a ''health hazard'' by an Australian minister. Some 300 teenagers had suffered minor injuries at a Melbourne concert, where fans worked themselves into an agitated lather in their affection for the I Think I Love You-crooning heartthrob. In London two months later, a crowd of 35,000 at White City Stadium was similarly frenzied. In the crush to get closer to the stage, several fans were trampled. One, 14-year-old Bernadette Whelan, never recovered from her asphyxiation. Cassidy sent a note of condolence to her parents; a coroner called her ''a victim of contrived hysteria'' and suggested that ''trendy, high platform shoes'' had contributed to girls tumbling in the swarm. Cassidy took a hiatus from performing. Exhausted at the age of 24, he never regained his pop-culture eminence.

Moment in time: May 25, 1915- The Second Battle of Ypres ends

It began around 5 p.m. on a Thursday in April, when the Germans unleashed a cloud of chlorine gas at the Allied lines dug in on the Flemish plain. Thousands of soldiers fled in terror or suffocated in their trenches. For the next month, the Kaiser's Army pounded away at the defenders - including a hefty contingent of Canadians, who played a crucial role plugging a gap in the line created by the gas attack. When it was all over, more than 100,000 people on both sides were killed, injured or missing; 6,000 of these were Canadians. For this catastrophic waste of human life, the Germans gained nothing but a few kilometres of ground, and pushed the chemical arms race into high gear.

Moment in time: May 22, 1976- Karen Ann Quinlan is taken off respirator as legal right-to-die era dawns

Karen Ann Quinlan was removed from a mechanical respirator, and government protection over the "sanctity of life" began to give way to the right to personal control over one's death. The 22-year-old New Jersey woman had been in a vegetative state since ingesting alcohol and tranquilizers at a party and losing consciousness on April 15, 1975. Her father and legal guardian, Joseph Quinlan, a devout Roman Catholic, had fought for his daughter's right to die with "grace and dignity," and the New Jersey Supreme Court accepted his argument, saying that withdrawing life-support systems was not murder but "a matter of self-determination." The right-to-die movement would ultimately lead to the legalization of physician-assisted death in five U.S. states and, as of 2014, in Canada. Quinlan herself surprised everyone by living nine more years without the respirator, her nutrients provided through a tube.

Moment in time: May 21, 1999- Susan Lucci finally wins her first Daytime Emmy

The 19th time was the charm for Susan Lucci. For 18 straight years, the Daytime Emmy Awards bestowed a nomination for outstanding actress upon the raven-haired beauty for her portrayal of Erica Kane on All My Children - and for 18 years she went home empty-handed. Although Kane was arguably the hottest character on daytime television, Lucci's Emmy envy became a running joke in Hollywood, and even inspired a series of commercials for a sugar substitute in which she spoofed her desire for TV's top honour. When finally handed her trophy, a tearful Lucci closed her speech by promising fans, ''I am going back into that studio on Monday, and I'm going to play Erica Kane for all she's worth!'' And Lucci kept that promise until ABC finally pulled the plug on the soap opera in 2011.

Moment in time: May 20, 1932- Amelia Earhart flies solo across the Atlantic 

After packing a can of tomato juice and a Thermos of soup from Archibald's Hotel in Harbour Grace, Nfld., Amelia Earhart lifted off in her red-and-gold Lockheed Vega, bound for Paris. Rose Archibald's soup sustained the aviator for a taxing flight that included rain, fog and a broken altimeter in Earhart's single-engine plane. Nearly 15 hours later, she touched down in a farmer's pasture near Londonderry, Northern Ireland, but the miscalculation didn't diminish her feat: Earhart was celebrated as only the second person to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean, and the first woman to do so. Five years later, in 1937, Earhart vanished in the South Pacific while attempting to become the first woman to fly around the world.
Cartoon of the day: 'All the king's horses and all the king's men' by David Parkins

Moment in time: May 19, 1845-- Doomed Franklin expedition sets sail from England

For centuries, British sailors had tried and failed to discover a navigable trade route through the unforgiving Arctic that would connect the Atlantic and Pacific oceans - the fabled Northwest Passage. Sir John Franklin set off on the quest for his fourth time, amid great fanfare, with a crew of 128, setting sail from Greenhithe, England, with two Royal Navy ships. But alas, the voyage ended in disaster when the HMS Erebus and HMS Terror became icebound in the Victoria Strait. While the exact details remain a mystery, the entire crew eventually perished. Many artifacts from the expedition have been found, including the HMS Erebus itself, but not the HMS Terror. More than half a century later, the Northwest Passage was successfully navigated by an expedition led by Norwegian Roald Amundsen.

Moment in time: May 15, 1800- George III survives assassination attempt 

The King kept his cool. When a gun went off in Hyde Park and wounded a man a few steps away, George III calmly offered his assistance. Later that day, the unflappable monarch took in a comedy at the Theatre Royal. As the national anthem played, a disturbed war veteran named James Hadfield fired his pistol at the royal box, convinced he could hasten the Second Coming of Christ by being killed in an act of regicide. When he missed, he offered friendly words to the unfazed sovereign - and the play went on. Hadfield was acquitted of treason due to insanity and should have been freed. But the prospect of an assassin on the loose was so worrying that new legislation was drafted, allowing insane offenders to be detained indefinitely ''at His Majesty's pleasure.''

Moment in time: May 14, 1969-- Parliament passes omnibus bill extending Canadian freedoms 

By current standards, it was a relatively small ''omnibus bill,'' but the impact of the Criminal Law Amendment Act on basic human freedoms was immense. Not everyone agreed with Pierre Trudeau's assertion that ''there's no place for the state in the bedrooms of the nation.'' Opposition to the legislation he introduced in 1967 was fierce. Its least controversial sections imposed new gun controls, regulated lotteries and made it an offence to drive while drunk. But it also made it legal for a woman to use contraception and to obtain an abortion if doctors said her health was at stake. And it decriminalized homosexual acts between consenting Canadians over the age of 21. Still reviled by some, the bill marked a major step towards Trudeau's vision of a Just Society where ''inhibitions to equality would be eradicated.''

Moment in time: May 13, 1993-- 21 kindergarten pupils taken hostage in Paris suburb 

He's hunting a wolf, the teacher told her class of three- and four-year-olds. The masked gunman with dynamite strapped to his waist was nothing to fear, Laurence Dreyfus told the 21 children taken hostage at her school in the Paris suburb of Neuilly-sur-Seine. For two days, Dreyfus steadfastly refused to abandon the children to hostage-taker Eric Schmitt, who called himself the Human Bomb and was threatening to kill them all if he didn't get $18-million. He got his ransom, and some children were released, but not all of them. When Schmitt nodded off, police slipped into the classroom and killed him with a few bullets to the head, freeing the children from a terror their teacher never let them glimpse.

Moment in time: May 12, 1937-- Coronation of King George VI

The date was originally set for the coronation of Edward VIII - George's elder brother, who had relinquished the throne six months earlier - and the pomp and circumstance of the crowning of George VI represented a return to normal after the abdication crisis. Public sentiment was warm toward the entire Royal Family, particularly the 11-year-old heir-apparent, Princess Elizabeth - now Queen Elizabeth II. Affection was also pronounced for the obviously shy George. What his subjects didn't know was how anxious he was: A lifelong stutter made the task of oath-taking a frightening prospect. But all went smoothly amid the flowers and finery, and millions listened to the fourhour ceremony on the radio, direct from Westminster Abbey - the first truly global live news event.

Moment in time: May 11, 1960-- Israeli agents nab Adolf Eichmann in Argentina

The man calling himself Ricardo Klement was getting home from work in the suburbs of Buenos Aires when a stranger approached him and said, Un momentito, senor - ''One moment, sir.'' In just seconds, the stranger and another man wrestled ''Klement'' to the ground, then bundled him into a waiting car. Eleven days later, Israeli Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion startled the world by announcing that Mossad had captured Adolf Eichmann, the fugitive SS officer who had supervised the transport of Jews across Europe to Nazi death camps. Put on trial, Eichmann portrayed himself as an ordinary man who was just following orders, the epitome of Hannah Arendt's famous phrase about the ''banality of evil.'' New scholarship reveals that Eichmann was no mere cog, but an unrepentant fanatic. He went to the gallows in 1962.

Moment in time: May 8, 1982-- Gilles Villeneuve killed in qualifying race in Belgium
Gilles Villeneuve knew full well the risks of his chosen profession. ''I am always aware of the possibility that this sport could kill me at the next corner,'' the Formula One driver said five years before that fateful day of qualifying at Belgium's Zolder circuit. Still angry at teammate Didier Pironi for defying orders and denying Villeneuve victory two weeks prior, the 32-year-old from Berthierville, Que., was a man on a mission as he powered his No. 27 Ferrari through the Terlamenbocht corner. It was to be his last. A collision with a rival sent his car somersaulting 150 metres through the air, and a snapped safety harness catapulted Villeneuve into a steel catch fence. The first Canadian to win on the world's most glamourous racing circuit - taking the checkered flag six times in 67 starts - died in hospital seven hours later.

Moment in time: March 27, 1998 -- FDA approves use of Viagra for impotence

It only took three words to launch a revolution: ''little blue pill.'' The first oral medicine for impotence, Viagra was a failed heart-disease drug whose male trial patients had reported an unusual side effect: erections. Drug company Pfizer introduced the world to the phrase ''erectile dysfunction'' through a marketing campaign unprecedented in scale, and demand was sky-high. Despite the cost - as much as $10 (U.S.) for each pill - $78-million worth of the drug was prescribed in its first 48 hours on the market. Within two months, doctors had made out one million prescriptions; one Edmonton urologist described it as ''mass hysteria.'' Pfizer's share price soared by almost 40 per cent in the six weeks after the launch. Demand sagged somewhat after the initial surge, but Viagra remains a case study for success in the pharmaceutical industry. -- Kate Hopwood

Moment in time: March 26, 1953 -- Jonas Salk presents his polio vaccine

When word leaked out that University of Pittsburgh scientist Jonas Salk had developed a vaccine for polio amid a record outbreak of the paralysis-causing and potentially fatal disease, he agreed to explain his discovery, tested on himself and his own family, in a national radio broadcast. His anointment as public saviour - he soon graced the cover of Time - saw him shunned by fellow researchers who felt his scientific accomplishment was overstated. And during rushed countrywide testing of his vaccine on schoolchildren, 204 would catch polio from a single bad batch. Manufacturing standards were tightened and the vaccine soon spread around the world. In 1962, a rival vaccine produced by scientist Albert Sabin was deemed more effective by some. Both are still used today, and polio has been eradicated in much of the world. -- Jeff Gray

Photo: Associated Press

Moment in time: March 25, 1911 -- 146 garment workers die in Triangle Shirtwaist fire

Regulations are there for a reason. When people complain about the nanny state, remind them of the fire at the Triangle Shirtwaist Company in New York.It started with a match or cigarette butt tossed into a scrap bin on the eighth floor of a Greenwich Village factory producing button-down blouses for stylish working women. In less than 30 minutes, 146 people died, most of them young female immigrants. There were no sprinklers or alarms in the 10-storey firetrap. Corridors and stairways were too narrow and elevators too cramped to allow a speedy exit when a rotting fire hose failed. A door to the street had been locked to prevent employee theft. The single, flimsy fire escape fell to the ground. Now we know better. And the garment workers die instead in Bangladesh, where they haven't yet learned from history. -- John Allemang

Moment in time: March 24, 2005 -- Wendy's hit by finger-in-the-chili hoax

For flesh that had been simmering in a pot of chili, the severed finger was remarkably undercooked. There were other clues that the digit Anna Ayala claimed to have been served at a Wendy's restaurant was planted, including the fact that all who worked at the California eatery could count to five on each hand. And then there were the many lawsuits the woman had filed against others. The chili-finger lady, as she became known, dropped her case against Wendy's and was given four years in jail for larceny, but not before making headlines for weeks with her tale and costing the burger chain millions in lost sales. As for the finger, it belonged to a co-worker of her husband, who lost it in a mechanical lift at a paving company and gave it away to pay off a debt. -- Eric Atkins

Moment in time: March 23, 1983 -- The first recipient of a permanent artificial heart dies

In the weeks leading up to his death, Barney Clark was in near-constant distress: slipping in and out of consciousness, battling infections and suffering a series of small strokes. But he was still alive, which was more than the retired Seattle dentist expected when, in the hopes of advancing medical research, he agreed to become the first human recipient of a permanent artificial heart. The Jarvik 7 was a total heart replacement made of two polyurethane pumps implanted in the chest and connected by tubes to an air compressor the size of a dishwasher. It kept Clark, 62, alive for 112 days, long enough for a fierce public debate about whether the scientific knowledge that might be gained was worth letting him suffer. In the end, his sacrifice showed the promise of total heart replacements, which today keep the severely ill alive while they wait for human heart transplants. -- Kelly Grant

Moment in time: March 20, 1999 -- Duo set hot-air balloon record

It only took them 20 days to travel around the world, not 80, but then Phileas Fogg didn't have the benefit of a $2-million hot-air balloon, a dozen ground crew and state-of-the-art weather-forecasting technology. When Bertrand Piccard and Brian Jones crossed a finish line some 36,000 feet above Mauritania in the Breitling Orbiter 3, they became the first to complete a non-stop balloon trip around the globe - besting rivals Richard Branson and Steve Fossett. The duo called it the ''final adventure of the 20th century,'' and it would be hard to argue with them. To complete the trip, they were hurled through jet streams at speeds approaching 210 kilometres an hour, faced down ferocious storms and floated dangerously close to countries that would sooner shoot them down than see them collect the $1-million prize from brewing giant Anheuser-Busch. -- Chris Wilson-Smith

Moment in time: March 19, 1931 -- Nevada legalizes gambling

The Depression was kicking up dust and hardship across the United States, and few places felt it as squarely as the hardscrabble state of Nevada. With mining fortunes in the Silver State fizzling, legislators scrambled for new revenue sources and decided upon gambling and heartbreak. Aspiring divorcees had long flocked to Nevada and its liberal six-month residency requirement for obtaining a legal separation. In those desperate times, the state doubled down, cutting the residency law to six weeks and giving the lovelorn a new way to spend their time and money. In Reno, hotels and divorce ranches - complete with ample gaming options - popped up to accommodate the surge of demand. Las Vegas began its growth spurt in the 1940s, and today 45 per cent of Nevada's revenues come from the hotel-casino industry.-- Patrick White

Moment in time: March 18, 1990 -- Boston Museum is robbed of 13 works of art

The thieves came at night. Disguised as police officers, they duped the guards - handcuffing them in the basement - and were free to roam the halls of Boston's Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum for 81 minutes, helping themselves to 13 works of art in what the FBI has called the largest property crime in U.S. history. From the museum's first floor, they took a small painting by Manet. From the second floor, they took five works on paper by Degas, several pieces by Rembrandt and Vermeer's painting The Concert (above). The latter, one of only 36 known Vermeers in existence, is considered the most valuable stolen painting in the world. The thieves were never found, and to this day the frames hang empty at the Gardner, in the hope the paintings will be recovered. --Ann Hui

Moment in time: March 16, 1926 -- Robert Goddard launches liquid-propellant rocket

Rudimentary forms of rocketry had existed since the Chinese invented gunpowder.But the modern rocket era began one spring afternoon in 1926 in Auburn, Mass., when Clark University physics professor Robert Goddard erected a metal frame in a cabbage patch at the farm of his aunt, Effie. The frame held up the world's first liquid-propellant rocket. Fuelled with gasoline and liquid oxygen, his rocket rose just more than 12 metres in the air. Goddard was an eccentric character whose visionary papers on lunar travel were mocked by newspapers, but his work paved the way for a new age of flight. While more difficult to manufacture, liquid-propellant rockets have a higher thrust than powder ones and can be throttled, shut down and restarted, essential features for spacecraft - from the moon-bound Saturn V to the space shuttle. -- Tu Thanh Ha

Moment in time: March 13, 1940 -- Peace treaty ends Finnish fight against Soviets

The Moscow peace treaty marked the end of four months of fierce Finnish resistance to the Soviet Red Army. Faced with overwhelming numerical superiority, the Finns had used guerrilla tactics and their knowledge of the wintry local terrain to confound their enemy. Dressed in white camouflage, and often on skis, the Finnish units moved faster than the ponderous Soviets, who had been decimated in leadership by Stalin's purges. To counter Soviet tanks, the Finns developed an enduring weapon they called the Molotov cocktail, named for the Soviet foreign minister. Failure to secure a rapid victory was humiliating to the Soviets, but they eventually got the upper hand. Attempts at reinforcement by Britain and France were thwarted, and Finland agreed to a peace that ceded roughly one-tenth of its territory and one-third of its industrial might to the Soviets. -- Joe Friesen

Moment in time: March 12, 1857 -- Great Western Railway train falls into Desjardins Canal

Between 5 and 6 in the evening, at a time of year not yet warm enough to have melted the two feet of ice covering the Desjardins Canal outside Hamilton, a train plunged 20 metres off a wooden swing bridge into the abyss. Fifty-nine of its 100 passengers died, including Samuel Zimmerman, a railway investor who was one of Upper Canada's richest men. The inquiry that immediately convened established the cause: A broken axle on the locomotive had forced the train to derail and the bridge to shatter. The month-long hearing revealed that the tragedy had its roots in safety oversights that were preventable: The bridge's strength had not been tested in case of derailment. But it also brought up an enduring mystery: The reason the axle broke was never discovered. -- Simona Chiose

Moment in time: March 11, 1935: Bank of Canada opens its doors

Until the 1930s, Canada's banks pretty much ran their own show, printing currency and handling credit without involvement from a central bank. But the Great Depression increased pressure to create an institution that would regulate credit and keep prices stable. Following the recommendations of a Royal Commission, on a late-winter Monday the Bank of Canada opened its doors in Ottawa. At first a private institution that sold shares to the public, it was later nationalized. The big change for ordinary Canadians was the appearance of new Bank of Canada currency - smaller and more colourful than the old Dominion of Canada notes or those from chartered banks. But there was some confusion about the new bank's role: A few people showed up at its offices on the first day to try to open accounts or cash cheques. -- Richard Blackwell

Moment in time: Batista seizes power in Cuba

It took just 77 minutes for the group of retired army officers to overthrow Cuban President Carlos Prio Socarras. The early-morning coup led by former president Fulgencio Batista was not widely challenged, in large part because the regime it replaced was seen as corrupt. Batista promised Cubans a new brand of "disciplined democracy," but his presidency soon took on the hallmarks of dictatorship. He won an election in 1954 in which he was the sole candidate, and developed close ties with the U.S. government and the Mafia. Corruption and police brutality were widespread during his rule, and while gambling and tourism flourished in Havana, most of the Caribbean country remained poor and undeveloped. Nearly seven years after seizing power, Batista fled Cuba as Fidel Castro's revolutionaries took control of the country. -- Kim Mackrael

Moment in time: March 9, 1978 -- Vern Taylor lands first triple axel

Three men attempted triple Axels at the 1978 World Figure Skating Championships in Ottawa, but only one landed in the history books. Canadian Vern Taylor had never won a national title and was sitting 14th heading into the free skate. But on his third jump in a performance set to music from Rocky, the 20-year-old became the first human to complete the forward-takeoff, 3.5-revolution jump in competition. The landing wasn't perfect - he continued to rotate on the ice afterward - but he kept his balance and stayed on one foot. He finished 12th overall. Yet the placement was not what counted. Taylor had raised the standard: What had once been an unconquered Everest would soon be a requirement for serious competitors. The following year, the feat was repeated by another Canadian, a junior skater named Brian Orser. -- Joy Yokoyama

Moment in time: March 6, 1869 - Mendeleev unveils the periodic table

The ancient Greeks once thought the world was made of four basic elements, but by the 1860s scientists had found more than 50. In St. Petersburg, a chemistry professor named Dmitri Mendeleev was determined to make sense of it all. He produced a set of pin-up cards, one for each element, and arranged them in order of weight, starting with the lightest, hydrogen. Working down the list, he saw that some elements shared properties that repeated in a periodic way, so he formed them into columns alongside their like-behaving kin. This created gaps that Mendeleev reasoned might one day be filled by still-undiscovered elements. He was right: Six years after he presented his "periodic table" before the Russian Physicochemical Society, the element gallium turned up with precisely the characteristics Mendeleev predicted. -- Ivan Semeniuk

Moment in time: March 5, 1966: BOAC jet breaks up near Mount Fuji

When British Overseas Airways Corp. Flight 911 took off from Tokyo's Haneda Airport, it taxied past the site of a horrific plane crash that had killed 64 people less than 24 hours earlier. The Boeing 707 would meet a similar fate: Soon after takeoff, the Hong Kong-bound plane broke apart and crashed into the forested slope of Mount Fuji, killing all 113 passengers and 11 crew members on board. Aviation experts said adverse wind conditions around the third volcanic cone may have been to blame, according to The New York Times. The crash was the third in a deadly few weeks for Japanese aviation: One month earlier, All Nippon Airways Flight 60 had crashed in Tokyo Bay, killing 133 people. -- Andrea Woo

Moment in time: March 4, 1980 -- Robert Mugabe declared election winner

Even with 20 seats reserved for white voters, Robert Mugabe and his ZANU-PF party won a landslide victory in independent Zimbabwe's first election. Only a few weeks earlier, the guerrilla commander had returned triumphantly from exile, greeted by huge crowds. His party won 57 of the 100 seats, defeating his guerrilla rival Joshua Nkomo, and Mugabe began to consolidate his dominance over the country. Since then, the world has seen his rise and fall and rise again. He became a pariah to the West when he encouraged the violent seizure of white-owned farms; he lost the first round of the 2008 election and clung to power through brutal force and deal-making; then he made an extraordinary return with a manipulated election victory in 2013. Today, at 91, he's chairman of the African Union and the world's oldest ruling president. -- Geoffrey York

Moment in time: March 3, 1875 -- Carmen has world premiere in Paris

Every opera-goer knows the story: The young composer delivers a masterpiece of realism that shocks the public, whose scorn tips him into despair and early death. But that's not quite how Carmen came into the world, or how Georges Bizet left it. Carmen's first run at Paris's Opéra-Comique was actually the most successful of any Bizet opera during his lifetime. The theatre had doubts about whether a gritty story of lust and revenge would suit its family clientele, and some reviews were harsh. But Carmen satisfied a current craving for exotic tales, music and imagery from southern Spain and Morocco. The theatre was packing in the crowds when Bizet died of a heart attack on June 3. Carmen had just finished the 33rd performance of its initial 45-show run. It has seldom been absent from a stage somewhere in the world ever since. -- Robert Everett-Green

Moment in time: March 2, 1882 -- Roderick Maclean tries to assassinate Queen Victoria

Victoria had just stepped off the train at Windsor and begun the carriage ride to her nearby castle when a bedraggled man emerged from the crowd and squeezed off a shot at the Queen. The round missed. A local photographer grabbed the gun from the would-be assassin, and several bystanders set upon him - including a pair of Eton schoolboys who whacked him over the head with their umbrellas. The shooter, a ne'er-do-well named Roderick Maclean, was found not guilty by reason of insanity and spent the rest of his life in the asylum at Broadmoor. It was the seventh time someone had tried to kill Queen Victoria who, of course, escaped every attempt and went on to become Britain's longest-reigning monarch. --  Adrian Morrow

Moment in time: Feb. 27, 1980 -- First (and last) Grammy for disco awarded

The pop music of the past few years has been heavily populated by shiny, danceable odes to empowerment. Katy Perry roars and whatever doesn't kill Kelly Clarkson only makes her stronger. But it wasn't always that way, which is why something like the Gloria Gaynor hit I Will Survive is so memorable. A defiant, melodramatic statement written by Freddie Perren and Dino Fekaris, the single in 1980 would win the inaugural Grammy for best disco recording, besting, among others, Rod Stewart's Da Ya Think I'm Sexy? and Michael Jackson's Don't Stop 'til You Get Enough. Ironically, the boogie itself was dying. By 1981, the disco prize was summarily eliminated from the Grammys, making I Will Survive not only the category's first winner, but its last. Still, the song's message message would live on. -- Brad Wheeler

Moment in time: Feb. 26, 2001 -- Taliban orders demolition of Buddha statues

The Taliban's first crack at demolishing two towering stone Buddha statues carved into cliffs in Bamiyan, Afghanistan, didn't work. The aging icons were first hit with anti-aircraft and tank fire, "but they are very tough ones," as Taliban foreign minister Wakil Ahmad Muttawakil put it. They stood amid the caves at Bamiyan for more than 1,400 years, one 53 metres tall, the other 37 metres. But on Feb. 26, 2001, Taliban leader Mullah Mohammed Omar ordered all non-Islamic statues destroyed. His troops, undeterred by early failures, packed a truckload of dynamite into the sixth-century masterpieces, even as United Nations secretary-general Kofi Annan pleaded for their preservation. The explosives levelled the Buddhas, and the contents of Kabul museums were similarly desecrated. Talk of rebuilding the Buddhas has resurfaced over the years, but for now only their empty outlines remain. -- James Bradshaw

Photo: Omar Sobhani/Reuters

Moment in time: Feb. 24, 2006 -- Gushue's team wins Olympic curling gold

It was a provincial decree that all Newfoundland and Labrador schools be closed at noon so students and staff could watch the broadcast from the 2006 Winter Olympics in Turin, Italy. It promised to be history in the making - St. John's skip Brad Gushue and his curling rink-mates out to win Newfoundland's first Olympic gold medal. The final game, against Finland, was sheer domination. The Gushue team scored six in the sixth end to gut the Finns in less time than it took to spell their skip's name, Markku Uusipaavalniemi. The victory set off a spree of celebrations. Gushue presented an award at the 2006 Junos. The team received honorary doctor of laws degrees from Memorial University. There were streets named after them, books written about them. All that for history made.-- Allan Maki

Moment in time: Feb. 23, 1821 -- John Keats dies at 25 in Rome

The poet John Keats made the most of his short life. Hailing from tragic family circumstances - including the death of both parents before he was 14 - Keats flirted with a medical career before devoting himself to poetry in his teens. Although his first efforts were scorned by Blackwood's Magazine in 1817, Keats published his masterpiece, Endymion, the following year. That same year, he lost his brother, fell in love with Fanny Brawne and wrote a prodigious amount of poetry, including Ode to a Nightingale. In late 1820, Keats, by then racked with tuberculosis, and painter Joseph Severn went to Rome, where the poet rallied briefly but was soon bedridden. In his final moments, Keats told his friend, ''I shall die easily. Don't be frightened. Be firm, and thank God it has come.'' He was 25. -- Andrew Ryan

Moment in time: Feb. 19, 1878 -- Edison patents the phonograph

When Thomas Edison presented his "talking machine" to the staff of the Scientific American, it inquired as to their health and bid them a cordial good night. 
Few could have predicted they were witnessing the recording technology that would lead to the commercialization of recorded music in the 1890s and go on to make the modern music business possible. Two months later, Edison received U.S. Patent No. 200,521 for his phonograph, the first device that not only recorded sound, but could reproduce and play back those recordings.
Many improvements to Edison's original phonograph followed, including one from his competitor, Alexander Graham Bell, who used wax in his machine instead of Edison's tin-foil-covered cylinders. Even today, the recording industry's vocabulary of "spinning wax" has long outlived the technology that inspired it. -- Kat Sieniuc

Moment in time: Feb. 18, 2005 -- Fox hunt ban comes into effect

Spoiler: the fox dies, and it's messy. England and Wales banned the practice of letting loose a pack of hounds to chase down foxes 10 years ago. The debate that preceded the move pitted those who wanted to preserve a rural tradition against animal rights advocates, who saw only cruelty in the hunt. Amid renewed calls to end the ban, the hunt continues today, with some modifications: Hounds can follow a scented trail while the hunters get to enjoy a day on horseback in the countryside. The dogs are to be called off if a real quarry is cornered, and it's a bullet - not the pack - that finishes off the fox. -- Eric Atkins

Moment in time: Feb. 17, 1673 -- The Death of Molière

The play that night was Malade Imaginaire, or The Imaginary Invalid, a fierce comedy attacking both the medical profession and those hypochondriac patients who abuse it. On Feb. 17, 1673, it was in just its fourth performance, though it would later be recognized as one of the great plays of Molière, the French master of comedy. It would also be his last. Molière took the stage in the role of Argan, the titular invalid, even though his wife had cautioned him that morning that he was not well enough to perform. She was right: As the play neared its end, Molière, a long-time pulmonary tuberculosis sufferer, had a coughing fit, which he tried to disguise with a loud laugh. Later that evening, he died at home, his final performance complete, and Western comedy forever changed. -- Jared Bland

Moment in time: Feb. 13, 1990 -- Groundwork for reuniting Germany is laid down in Ottawa

On a painfully cold February morning in Ottawa, the foreign ministers of France, Britain, the Soviet Union, the United States and East and West Germany headed to the German ambassador's residence in Rockcliffe for breakfast. They attracted little notice: The ministers were officially in Ottawa for a conference of Warsaw Pact and NATO foreign ministers on the unexciting subject of aerial observation. Nobody would have guessed that their coffee talk, held only three months after the Berlin Wall fell, would reshape the world. Yet it was the agreement struck over that breakfast, overcoming strong resistance from Britain and France and winning the support of Moscow, that led to talks beginning in May that would create a single, reunified Germany, and thus a united Europe, and finalized the lifting of the Iron Curtain. -- Doug Saunders

Moment in time: Feb. 10, 1986 -- Mafia trial opens with more than 450 defendants

Church bells tolled across Palermo to mark the start of Italy's first mass trial of the Mafia. More than 450 defendants, some held in steel cages, were guarded by 2,000 police officers in a courtroom built to resist rocket attacks. For the first time, insiders known as pentiti broke the code of silence to testify about an organized campaign of murder, kidnapping, drug deals and extortion that extended from Sicily to North America. More than 330 men were found guilty, including Michele Greco, who ordered 78 homicides including the assassination of Italian public officials. The trial did not cripple organized crime in Sicily, but six years later Giovanni Falcone, the courageous prosecutor behind the maxi-trial, was killed by a roadside bomb, fuelling an anti-Mafia backlash. -- Joe Friesen

Moment in time: Feb. 9, 1933 -- Oxford students vote against fighting for king and country

The motion under debate at the Oxford Union - that this House will in no circumstances fight for its King and Country - was clearly meant to irritate the pompous and powerful. Blind, unthinking patriotism no longer seemed justifiable after the slaughter of the Great War, and the economic divide of the Depression had further undermined any instinct of jingoistic obedience. But when the anti-war resolution passed by 275-153 (thanks in part to a speech by future Canadian NDP leader David Lewis), Oxford's students were denounced as cowards whose decadent views (''abject, squalid, shameless,'' according to Winston Churchill) provided comfort to Britain's enemies. In fact, it was the tepid foreign policy of the British leadership class, not the well-chosen words of a few left-wing debaters, that gave Hitler his licence to conquer. -- John Allemang

Moment in time: Feb. 5, 1982 -- Pioneering Laker Airways goes bust 

Sir Freddie Laker saw a market for fun and affordable aviation when he founded the first low-cost transatlantic airline, Laker Airways, in 1966. By cutting out heavy cargo freight to save on fuel, charging extra for food and accepting standby passengers, Laker paved the way for today's budget flights. But as swiftly as the airline ascended, the turbulence of the early 1980s recession brought it down to Earth. With lacklustre ticket sales, even a bailout by its entrepreneur founder couldn't stave off creditors. (Sir Freddie would later blame colluding competitors for the collapse.) Facing a 270-million-pound ($515-million) debt, Laker buckled and planes were recalled to Britain, leaving some passengers in the lurch. Loyal fans tried to relaunch the airline with a crowdfunding campaign, but it was to be permanently grounded. -- Jacqueline Nelson

Moment in time: Feb. 4, 1983 -- Karen Carpenter succumbs to anorexia

The Carpenters' soft rock was all sweetness and innocence, from (They Long to Be) Close to You to We've Only Just Begun. Even the melancholy of the duo of her and her brother, Richard, pictured above, was wholesome. But stardom - more than 100 million records sold, 15 No. 1 hits - intensified Karen Carpenter's struggle with her appearance. She began dieting in high school and weight loss became an obsession that we now know is a disease. By 1975, when she was an international superstar, she weighed just 91 pounds. Shortly before her 33rd birthday, Carpenter suffered heart failure and was rushed to hospital, where she was pronounced dead. The cause: "heartbeat irregularities brought on by chemical imbalances associated with anorexia nervosa." Looking back, those Carpenters songs still sound sweet, but if you listen closely enough, you hear how really sad they are. -- Dave McGinn

Moment in time: Feb. 3, 1947: Coldest day in North America recorded

The winter of 1946-47 in the Yukon was so harsh that thousands of rabbits, foxes and wolves died of cold. At Snag, a military airstrip and weather station in the territory's remote northwest, a duty officer named Gordon Toole ventured from his log cabin to the instruments shed on Feb. 3. His breath hissed as it froze instantly, leaving a vapour trail behind him. The cold air was so dense he could hear noises from a village five kilometres away. It was too cold for a mercury thermometer and the liquid in the alcohol instrument had dropped below the lowest graduation of -80 F ("-62.2 C). Toole estimated it was -83 F ("-63.9 C), and marked the spot by etching the glass with a file since it was too cold for a pen. The reading was later confirmed to be -81.4 F or -63 C. -- Tu Thanh Ha

Moment in time: Jan. 30, 1962 -- The Flying Wallendas fall, two die

The Flying Wallendas first performed without a safety net at Madison Square Garden in 1928, after this key piece of equipment got lost. The German-born founder of the family troupe, Karl Wallenda, was also said to believe that nets bred complacency. In 1962, before a crowd of 7,000 in Detroit, while crossing a highwire in a seven-person pyramid topped by a teenaged girl in a chair, a performer yelled, "I can't hold on any more!" All but three Wallendas fell to the floor more than 10 metres below. Two would die, and Karl's adopted son, Mario, was paralyzed for life. The girl in the chair was caught by two troupe members who did hang on. Karl himself escaped with a cracked pelvis and two hernias, and the troupe performed the next night. He died in a fall in 1978, aged 73. But his descendants, including great-grandson Nik, are still performing. -- Jeff Gray

Moment in time: Jan. 29, 1964 -- Premiere of Dr. Strangelove provides nuclear laughs

If Dr. Strangelove taught us anything, it was that timing truly is everything in the movie business. Released at the peak of the Cold War, Stanley Kubrick's black comedy fictionalizing a nuclear showdown between the United States and the Soviet Union also arrived several weeks after the assassination of John F. Kennedy - when moviegoers needed a laugh. Using the 1958 novel Red Alert by Peter George as a framework, Kubrick shrewdly cast comedy auteur Peter Sellers in three roles: stiff RAF officer Lionel Mandrake, ineffectual U.S. president Merkin Muffley and the titular Dr. Strangelove, an ex-Nazi scientist plotting a new endgame for the Yanks. Sellers was supposed to play a fourth character - B-52 pilot Major T.J. (King) Kong, who rides a missile to global oblivion in the film's dire denouement - but he couldn't master the Texas accent. -- Andrew Ryan

Photo: Associated Press

Moment in time: Jan. 28, 1914 -- Nellie McClung stages mock Parliament of Women

The day before the women of the Political Equality League took the stage at Winnipeg's Walker Theatre, Conservative Premier Rodmond Roblin rejected their demand for ballot-box justice. Women were too emotional to vote, he insisted, and giving them the franchise would tear families apart. His smug reaction inspired Nellie McClung, a 40-year-old author and long-time temperance crusader. The next evening, the curtain rose on her Mock Parliament, a women-only assembly that presided over weighty affairs of state with Roblinesque complacency. When a delegation of men petitioned for male suffrage, McClung praised their "splendid gentlemanly appearance" but noted that politics unsettled men, leading to broken furniture and broken vows. "Man's place," she concluded, was "on the farm." The crowd roared. Exactly two years later, with the Liberals now in power, Manitoba women got their vote. -- John Allemang

Moment in time: Dec. 29, 1959 -- Feynman speech foresees nanotechnology

It was both a thought experiment and a call to action for the atomic era. Richard Feynman stood before the American Physical Society in Pasadena, Calif., and proposed an idea: creating things by manipulating individual atoms. Computers could be made much more compact by shrinking their circuits down to a minute size; an entire encyclopedia could be inscribed on the head of a pin; a microscope could be made powerful enough to study atoms up close. In the decades following that talk, There's Plenty of Room at the Bottom, much of what Feynman imagined would come to pass. Today, we use nanotechnology in everything from computers to car bumpers. Microscopes can zoom in on single atoms. And yes, it is even possible to fill the head of a pin with tens of thousands of pages worth of text. Some of his other proposals, such as microscopic robots to perform surgery from within a patient's body, are still under development. -- Adrian Morrow

Moment in time: Dec. 17, 1996 -- Hundreds taken hostage in Lima

The elite of Peruvian society were feting the Emperor's birthday at the Japanese ambassador's residence in Lima when the explosions went off. Fourteen rebels from the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement crashed the party, taking more than 400 hostages. Frightened, well-dressed revellers scrambled under tables as the rebels fired into the air and issued warnings. Among the hostages were judges, diplomats, generals and members of then-president Alberto Fujimori's family. The hostage-takers, a Marxist group led by Nestor Cerpa Cartolini, were mostly youngsters recruited from the jungle. They demanded freedom for hundreds of jailed comrades. Fujimori refused. Many hostages were released during the standoff, including 225 just before Christmas. Talks mediated by the Canadian ambassador proved futile. As the rebels played soccer on April 22, 1997, commandos stormed the mansion, setting off explosions and killing all 14 of them. -- Joy Yokoyama

Moment in time: Dec. 4, 1977 -- Jean-Bedel Bokassa crowns himself emperor

Jean-Bedel Bokassa was no garden variety African despot. He seized power of the Central African Republic in 1966, calling himself President for Life. When he outgrew that title, he donned a crown encrusted with 2,000 diamonds, rubies and emeralds and proclaimed himself Emperor. His two-day coronation, including a golden eagle throne, cost $22-million, nearly bankrupting the country. Bokassa's tyrannical rule ended in 1979, when he was ousted in a coup and accused of clubbing to death schoolchildren who refused to wear uniforms made in a factory he owned. He became the first deposed African chief to be publicly tried for murder and convicted. In 2010, he was posthumously pardoned by President Francois Bozize. ''He was a builder,'' said JeanSerge Bokassa, his son. ''Unfortunately, the negative acts tarnished his image.'' -- Karen Howlett

Photo: Pierre Guillaud/AFP/Getty Images

Moment in time: Nov. 28, 1990 -- Thatcher bids farewell to Downing Street 

She would later call it ''treachery with a smile on its face.'' But the simmering parliamentary revolt that forced Margaret Thatcher out of office in just three weeks was actually prompted by her stubborn Euroskepticism. Britain's first female prime minister had utterly transformed her country, irrevocably stamping its economy with a free-market mould. But the Iron Lady's uncompromising approach left both her Conservative Party and Britain bitterly divided. Her normally composed voice cracked slightly and her eyes appeared to well up with tears as she stood in front of 10 Downing St. for the last time, husband Denis standing dutifully behind her. She told reporters: ''We're leaving Downing Street for the last time after 111/2 wonderful years - and we're very happy that we leave the United Kingdom in a very, very much better state than when we came.'' -- Jeff Gray 

Photo: Martin Cleaver/AP

Moment in time: Nov. 26, 1956 -- The Price is Right premieres on NBC

The original working title was The Auctioneer. Creator Bob Stewart, who was also the brains behind To Tell the Truth and The $10,000 Pyramid, liked the idea of a show where people had to bid on items. Plenty of viewers did, too. The night-time version was the most-watched prime-time game show from 1959 to 1961. Contestants typically vied for furniture, furs and household appliances, but there were special prizes, too: an island in the St. Lawrence Seaway; a mile of hot dogs; a live peacock to go with a colour TV; and a trip to Israel to appear as an extra in Otto Preminger's film Exodus. The show was revamped in 1972, with Bob Barker taking over hosting duties from Bill Cullen. The show has aired in one form or another in every decade since the 1950s. Making history, come on down! -- Dave McGinn

Photo: Everett Collection

Moment in time: Nov. 25, 1963 -- Assassinated president John F. Kennedy is laid to rest

 The funeral of U.S. President John F. Kennedy didn't lack for stirring images. There were scores of dignitaries and world leaders; a flag-draped casket on a carriage drawn by six horses; a riderless horse with empty boots reversed in the stirrups to symbolize a fallen leader. And Jacqueline Kennedy, a picture of grief and strength in a black veil, three days after her husband was assassinated before her eyes. But the most striking picture remains that of John Kennedy Jr., apparently saluting his dad's coffin on his third birthday. It's doubtful he was aware of his actions, or their impact. But as a country and much of the world grieved a leader in whom so much hope had been placed, it was apparent that the little boy in short pants had lost much more. -- Eric Atkins

Photo: Associated Press
"Ring of Fire": Today's editorial cartoon by David Parkins. More cartoons: http://trib.al/Sgd87d0

Moment in time: Nov. 20, 1947: Princess Elizabeth weds Philip

Britain was still nursing wounds from the Second World War when preparations began for the marriage of Princess Elizabeth to Lieutenant Philip Mountbatten. Such a show of pageantry in an age of austerity could have spurred public anger, but instead had the cheering effect of a day off from other worries. Canada sent the couple a selection of antique silver and a mink coat. Other gifts included 200 New Brunswick lobsters and, in keeping with the times, Halifax sent a special food shipment to the British city of the same name. Elizabeth also received 80 pairs of nylon stockings from around the world. As the royal couple left for the honeymoon, the bridal bouquet was quietly laid at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Westminster Abbey. The event had provided a balm for a nation in recovery. -- Kate Hopwood

Photo: Associated Press
"It's a start." Today's editorial cartoon by Brian Gable. More cartoons: http://trib.al/lR9AGf9

Moment in time: Nov. 18, 1966 -- Pitching ace Sandy Koufax calls it quits

Left-handed pitcher Sandy Koufax struck out 317 batters in the 1966 season. Then he retired, walking away from a glorious Major League Baseball career at the age of 30. ''My elbow is so arthritic. I feel I can no longer give the Dodgers my best,'' he said when he quit the game. The Los Angeles Dodger threw with speed and control to pitch four no-hitters and win the Cy Young Award three times in a career that began in 1955 and included league-leading stats in several seasons. But he is often remembered for the game he didn't play. Koufax, who is Jewish, refused to pitch in Game 1 of the 1965 World Series because it fell on Yom Kippur. When he returned to the mound for Games 5 and 7, he won both times and the Dodgers claimed the championship. -- Eric Atkins

Photo: Associated Press
"Out of a hat": Today's editorial cartoon by Brian Gable. More cartoons: http://trib.al/vH4htRC

Moment in time: Nov. 13, 1973 -- Morgentaler acquitted in jury trial

The jurors took 10 hours to deliver their verdict: Not guilty. Doctor Henry Morgentaler was still at the start of his legal crusade to secure safe abortions for Canadian women. He would go on to face Crown appeals, jail, more arrests, more trials and a lifetime at the centre of an issue that divided the country. But the 10 men and one woman who first acquitted Morgentaler on charges of performing an illegal abortion in Montreal set a pattern that would stick for successive juries. The day after the verdict, Morgentaler was back at work in his Montreal clinic, confident that public opinion would pave the way for women to access abortions ''safely and with dignity instead of going to butchers.'' It was a principle he defended until the day he died. -- Ingrid Peritz

Photo: The Canadian Press

Moment in time: Nov. 10, 1983 - Microsoft launches Windows 1.0 

Computer users were living in a world of DOS: square black screens with green or orange font that could only display letters and numbers in response to basic C: commands. This wasn't just a world without e-mails, tweets and Instagram - this was a world before start menus. So when Bill Gates unveiled a new operating system called Windows 1.0, people braced for a big overhaul. For $99 (U.S.), the software would be able to run multiple programs at once - things such as a notepad, calendar, clock and Windows Paint. Gates promised Windows would be compatible with 90 per cent of IBM computers. There was one small catch: The software wouldn't ship for two more years. Windows customers would have to learn to be patient - a virtue often practised since that day. -- Amberly McAteer

Photo: Paul Chesley/National Geographic Society/Corbis

Moment in time: Nov. 3, 1954 -- Godzilla stomps onto movie screens in Japan

His original name was Gojira, a combination of gorilla and kujira, the Japanese word for whale. Producer Tomoyuki Tanaka, who saw him as a hybrid beast born of our most destructive capacities, was inspired to make the film when the United States tested the largest thermonuclear weapon ever detonated in March, 1954. The 15-megaton hydrogen bomb wiped out three South Pacific islands and rained radioactive fallout on a distant Japanese fishing boat. Tanaka worked that story into his film: "Mankind had created 'the Bomb,' and now nature was going to take revenge." Today, the movie looks corny (the monster is a man in a suit stomping a miniature city), but it was the most expensive Japanese film ever made when it premiered in Tokyo. It inspired more than two dozen sequels and earned Godzilla a star on Hollywood's Walk of Fame. -- Dave McGinn

Image: Everett Collection

Moment in time: Sept. 29, 1978 -- John Paul I found dead

His death after just 33 days in office was bound to stir speculation, and the scandals surrounding the Vatican Bank raised questions about a Mafia-style hit. John Paul I, the amiable former Patriarch of Venice, had retired to bed at 9 p.m. and set the alarm for predawn prayers. The devoted nun who arrived with his morning coffee at 4:30 a.m. got no answer to her knock. She tried again, and allegedly found the 65-year-old pontiff sitting upright, papers in hand, stone-cold dead. The Church's secretive image-makers went to work: The nun morphed into a male private secretary, the work papers became a sacred devotional text and, with the papal apartment safely sealed off, the sudden demise was quickly attributed to a heart attack. The Vatican refused an autopsy, giving conspiracy theorists free rein to believe. -- John Allemang

Photo: Associated Press

Moment in time: Sept. 26, 1964 -- Oh, Pretty Woman hits No. 1 on Billboard's Hot 100

''Pretty woman, I don't believe you,'' Roy Orbison sang, his disbelief seemingly sincere and not a pick-up line. ''No one could look as good as you.'' With Bill Dees in 1964, Orbison co-wrote Oh, Pretty Woman in praise of his first wife, Claudette, after the two had divorced and then reunited. As a pop song, it lacked for nothing, with a rock-steady snare-drum beat, iconic twangy riff, fragile vocal plead and playful cat growl that ensured its evergreen status. It was a departure from Orbison's typical heartbreak conceit, and the unexpected good fortune at the song's end resolved a lilting tension charismatically. Would the woman walk away? Would she make the protagonist cry? No, she would not. She walked back to him - a dream come true and hope for the lonely. ''Mercy, '' indeed. -- Brad Wheeler
