Moment in time: Sept. 23, 1999 -- Mars Orbiter burns up due to math error

Scientists planned to lose the Mars Climate Orbiter's signal for a few minutes as the spacecraft disappeared behind its namesake planet. The MCO was preparing to orbit and collect data on Martian weather, water and climate changes. But when navigation commands were sent in English units instead of metric, the orbiter hit the atmosphere at a low altitude. It could not have survived the resulting friction and stress, and no signal was ever re-established. The MCO was half of the $193-million (U.S.) Mars Surveyor ''98 program; the other half, the Mars Polar Lander, was to arrive about two months later, so NASA said at the time that the disappearance of the orbiter ''is not necessarily science lost; it is science delayed.'' However, no transmission was ever received from the Lander's Mars arrival, either. -- Jacqueline Nelson

Image: Associated Press

Moment in time: Sept. 19, 1970 -- Mary Tyler Moore throws her hat into a TV career

Network TV received a needed makeover with The Mary Tyler Moore Show. Dropped into a prime-time landscape that still included The Brady Bunch and My Three Sons, the premise cast Moore as Mary Richards, a single woman relocated to Minneapolis, Minn., after a bad breakup. In short order, she landed a bachelorette pad, a new bestie named Rhoda (Valerie Harper) and a producer job on WJM-TV's evening newscast. The first two seasons followed Mary through wacky scenarios with boss Lou (Ed Asner), co-worker Murray (Gavin McLeod) and dim newsman Ted (Ted Knight). But by season three it was touching on such important issues as equal pay and divorce. By showing viewers that single women on TV need not be widows or wallflowers, the show paved the way for Sex and the City and Girls. Thanks, Mary. -- Andrew Ryan

Photo: Bettman/Corbis

Moment in time: Sept. 17, 1985 -- CBC investigation launches Tunagate

Inspectors found the fish to be rancid, decomposed and unfit for human consumption. But the New Brunswick tuna factory that processed and canned it argued the assessment was unfair, and threatened to shut down the plant if the rejected products couldn't be sold. An investigation by CBC's The Fifth Estate revealed that federal Fisheries Minister John Fraser used his authority to overrule government inspectors and allow nearly one million cans of tainted tuna to be sold in Canadian stores. The revelation caused a national scandal: Fraser resigned from cabinet shortly after the program aired on Sept. 17, and StarKist eventually closed its New Brunswick plant as its Canadian sales plummeted. Fraser, however, proved that there is life after political scandal: He was elected Speaker of the House of Commons the next year. -- Kim Mackrael

Photo: Issei Kato/Reuters

Moment in time: Sept. 16, 1977 -- Opera diva Maria Callas dies

After leading a life large enough for its own opera, Maria Callas's sparkling soprano voice was silenced by a heart attack in her Paris home at the age of 53. Born Maria Anna Sofia Cecilia Kalogeropoulos in New York in 1923, Callas, the daughter of a Greek pharmacist, electrified the opera world in the 1950s and ''60s, reviving previously neglected bel canto works. Offstage, she played the role of diva to perfection, waging feuds with conductors and rivals, and bailing on performances over fees. Her marriage to an Italian businessman was ended by her tempestuous affair with shipping tycoon Aristotle Onassis. In the 1970s, Callas's voice faltered. She once told Life magazine she made no apologies for being difficult: ''To me, the art of music is magnificent, and I cannot bear to see it treated in a shabby way.'' -- Jeff Gray

Photo: Tibor Kolley/The Globe and Mail

Moment in time: Sept. 8, 1504 -- Michelangelo unveils giant marble David

One of the world's most famous sculptures was originally intended to gaze out over the Italian city of Florence from atop a Gothic cathedral, but Michelangelo's weighty David never made it to the roof. Carved in Carrara marble, the figure of the young biblical hero who slew the giant Goliath and went on to become king would instead live out the Renaissance from a perch in front of the town hall, now known as Palazzo Vecchio. Naked and armed only with a slingshot, David was the embodiment of strength in a city also grappling with giant issues, from aggressive neighbours to income inequality. While a replica of David still stands outside Palazzo Vecchio, the original has been sheltered in the Accademia Gallery since 1873. -- Jacqueline Nelson

Moment in time: Sept. 3, 1967 -- Swedish drivers switch from left to right

At 4:50 a.m., traffic across Sweden ground to a halt as drivers were directed to switch lanes and stop their vehicles. As the clock struck 5, cars, trucks and bicycles resumed their journeys - and, for the first time since 1734, they kept to the right side of the road. Prior to H-Day (H for hogertrafikomlaggningen, ''the right-hand traffic diversion''), Sweden was the last country in mainland Europe to drive on the left, even though most Swedes at the time had American-made cars designed for right-side driving. The switch was unpopular, but the biggest difficulties were logistical: Streetcar doors and bus stops were in the wrong places, some 360,000 street signs needed changing and one-way streets were a special nightmare. -  Kate Hopwood

Photo: Associated Press

Moment in time: Sept. 2, 1666 -- Great Fire of London starts in bakery

Great events often arise from small causes. Take the Great Fire of London: It began on a warm, dry Sunday morning when embers from the ovens of the King's baker ignited a stretch of houses tightly packed along Pudding Lane near London Bridge. Most houses in the city of 500,000 were made of wood and there was no fire department, so when a strong east wind arose, the flames spread rapidly, consuming more than 70 per cent of the city before being extinguished on Sept. 5. Tens of thousands were left homeless, yet the official death toll was fewer than 10 people. Hopes that the conflagration would result in a new grid street system were dashed when Charles II decided the old, convoluted routes should be retained. But Christopher Wren got to design 52 churches, including St. Paul's Cathedral, completed in 1711. -- James Adams

Moment in time: Aug. 21, 1959 - Hawaii proclaimed 50th U.S. state

The map of the United States as we know it today was finalized when President Dwight Eisenhower signed the Hawaii Admission Act and commissioned a new national flag with 50 stars. The move was cheered by Hawaiians, who had voted more than 93 per cent in favour of statehood. The American presence in the remote islands had begun when the first missionaries arrived in 1820, but it was during the 1898 Spanish-American war, when the strategic importance of the naval base at Pearl Harbor became clear, that U.S. interest in the islands 4,000 kilometres west of its mainland was cemented. Alaska had joined the union earlier in 1959. These days, tourists flock to Hawaii for surfing, volcano-viewing and beach relaxation, or a glimpse of familiar pop-culture locales from Magnum P.I. and From Here to Eternity. -- Kate Hopwood

Photo: Associated Press

Moment in time: Aug. 18, 1995 -- Shannon Faulkner drops out of the Citadel

''I know so many people are either mad at me or disappointed in me,'' Shannon Faulkner told reporters in the rain outside the Citadel, the storied South Carolina military academy whose gender barrier she had smashed after a 21/2-year legal battle. The all-male college accepted Faulkner by mistake in 1993, assuming she was a man. When Citadel brass realized their error, they rescinded her acceptance and spent millions trying to keep her out. Faulkner triumphed in court, but the brutality and emotional isolation of ''hell week'' proved too gruelling for the 20-year-old. She dropped out less than a week into her training. Male cadets were gleeful, tearing off their shirts and chanting C-IT-A-D-E-L. Such celebrations wouldn't last. In 1999, Nancy Mace became the first female cadet to graduate from the Citadel. Hundreds have since followed in her boot steps. -- Kelly Grant

Photo: Wade Spees/Reuters

Moment in Time: July 31, 1910: The notorious Dr. Crippen is arrested in Quebec

When you're making a run for it, maybe a steamship is a bad place to be. Hawley Crippen and his young lover, Ethel Le Neve, thought they'd dodged a murder warrant when they boarded the Canadian Pacific liner Montrose in Antwerp en route to Quebec. But the ship's captain had been reading newspaper reports about the London murder and dismemberment of Dr. Crippen's showgirl wife, Cora. He saw through the two fugitives' disguises – Ethel was dressed up as a boy – and sent a wireless message to inform British authorities. Scotland Yard's lead investigator immediately hopped on a faster Atlantic liner and nabbed the pair nine days later when the Montrose stopped to take on river pilots in Pointe-au-Pere, Que. Dr. Crippen was executed four months alter, and carried his acquitted lover's photo to the grave. – John Allemang

Moment in Time: July 30, 1973: Settlement for thalidomide victims in Britain

Doctors prescribed thalidomide for pregnant women who felt nauseous or worried. But the German-made drug that was popular in the late 1950s and early 1960s caused children to be born without arms or legs, among other deformities. The drug was pulled off the shelves in Europe when its effects became known, yet it remained available in Canada for several more months. On July 30, 1973, the company that sold the drug in Britain, Distiller Co., agreed to pay $36.8-million to more than 400 children who were thalidomide victims. More than 100 Canadian children born with the devastating effects of the drug were not as fortunate. They had to fight individually for compensation, which came in varied amounts, and with gag orders that kept the details secret. – Eric Atkins

Moment in Time: July 29, 1967: The Doors score their first No.1 hit with Light my Fire

When it came to California dreaming in the late 1960s, there were musical options. While the Beach Boys preached good vibrations, the San Francisco bands embodied a stoned utopia. From the Doors, it was moonlight drives, Hollywood bungalows and weird scenes from inside the gold mines. Their first hit was Light my Fire, a drug alluding psychedelic-pop trip about a love that couldn't get much higher. The sprawling album version was a team effort by rock originals. Singer Jim Morrison's baritone-inspired croon implored ominously, Ray Manzarek's organ solo was baroque-inspired and Robby Krieger's six-string flight had a flamenco flourish. Drummer John Densmore started it all off with the snap of his snare, as if to signal an announcement – the time to hesitate was through. Things got heavy quickly, what went up came down hard and not all the dreamers would leave the decade upright. – Brad Wheeler

Moment in time: July 25, 1956 - Andrea Doria collision sets off huge sea rescue

The ships had detected each other on radar and the men on the bridges believed they would calmly pass in the night. But just after 11 p.m., the bow of the Stockholm stabbed the starboard side of the Andrea Doria, ripping a hole in the glamorous Italian liner, causing it to tilt, and setting off a massive rescue operation. A half-dozen ships joined the Swedish liner in picking up Doria survivors from the Atlantic, 70 kilometres off Nantucket island in Massachusetts. Desperate passengers struggled to free loved ones from debris, parents flung their children overboard to lifeboats and others searched for missing family members. In total, 1,660 passengers and crew were saved, while 46 Doria passengers and five Stockholm crew perished. At 10:09 a.m. on July 26, the Doria disappeared beneath the waves. - Joy Yokoyama

More photos: http://trib.al/pycuciD

Photo: Associated Press

Moment in time: July 24, 1847 - Mormons settle in Salt Lake Valley

''This is the place,'' declared Brigham Young upon his first sighting of the valley of the Great Salt Lake. Along with a handful of Mormon followers, Young arrived at the barren location after a year-and-a-half-long trek initiated by the murder of Joseph Smith, the Christian sect's founder and first leader. As Smith's successor, Young had the responsibility of finding a new home for the Mormon pioneers back in western Iowa. Within days of arrival, Young and his companions began building shelter at the foot of the Wasatch mountains and designated the site of the Salt Lake Temple. In years to follow, Young escorted thousands to Utah, mostly by wagon and handcart. By 1852, the Mormon population in the new promised land numbered 16,000; by 1869 they were 80,000 strong. And thus Salt Lake City was born. - Andrew Ryan

Photo: Jeffrey D. Allred/AP

Moment in time: July 18, 1986 - World gets first glimpse of Titanic wreck

The Titanic's wealthiest travellers passed beneath the ship's crystal chandelier every time they took the grand staircase to reach their cabins or lounge. The wooden staircase is long gone, but the chandelier hung for 74 years amid the wreckage on the Atlantic seabed. It was visible in the first grainy images of the lost ship, broadcast on news stations around the world, in video captured by the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution. A robot deployed by a submarine took the footage, moving deep into the ship through the void left by the grand staircase, and revealing passengers' luggage and dinner plates within the rusted hull. There was little left of the interior woodwork, the furniture and the remains of the 1,500 people who died. - Eric Atkins

Moment in time: June 26, 1959 - Britannia sails the St. Lawrence Seaway

It was the brief journey of the Royal Yacht Britannia that officially marked the opening of the St. Lawrence Seaway and unlocked the Great Lakes ports of Chicago, Toronto, Hamilton, Detroit and Thunder Bay to the rest of the world. The Queen, U.S. President Dwight Eisenhower, Prime Minister John Diefenbaker and a throng of lesser dignitaries boarded the vessel at Montreal for a trip through the St. Lambert Lock. In fact, the seaway had opened two months earlier, but the pomp awaited the arrival of the monarch and her sleek blue ship, sailing gracefully down the channel. Whistles blew, rockets exploded and miniature flags of the United States, Britain and Canada were sprayed through the air. "We can say in truth," the Queen said, "that this occasion deserves a special place in history." - Gloria Galloway

Photo: Duncan Brown/Library and Archives Canada

Moment in time: June 19, 1990 -- Mandela enjoys heroic accolades in Canada

Jailed for 27 years and still barred from voting in his own country, Nelson Mandela received a hero's welcome when he travelled to Canada in 1990, just months after his release. Parliamentarians gave the South African anti-apartheid leader a standing ovation in Ottawa and throngs of admirers gathered to hear him speak at Queen's Park. But it was during a smaller assembly at a Toronto high school that Mandela appeared most at ease. ''What is more comforting to a man of my age than to know I have the support of future leaders of the world?'' he told the group of about 1,000 students. Four years later, Mandela would became South Africa's first black president, marking a turning point in the country's history. He was awarded the Order of Canada during another visit in 1998 and granted honorary Canadian citizenship in 2001. -- Kim Mackrael

Photo: John McNeill/The Globe and Mail
Approved*: Today's front page, June 18, 2014 #globefrontpage

Moment in time: June 18, 1840 - Verdi devastated by his wife's death

Albert Schweitzer opined, "There are two means of refuge from life's miseries: music and cats." How much solace Giuseppe Verdi took from felines during his 87 years is unclear. But music? The proof's in his stature as the world's pre-eminent opera composer. To think it could have been otherwise! Near-crippling tragedies struck early in Verdi's career - the deaths of his daughter at 17 months in 1838, then his son at 15 months in 1839 and finally Margherita, 26, his wife of fewer than four years. Dispirited, Verdi swore never to write again. Luckily, the vow did not hold, thanks to an inspiring chance encounter with what became the libretto to Nabucco. Mounted at La Scala in 1842, it was the first in a long string of successes for the composer, including Rigoletto and La Traviata. -- James Adams

Image: AndreaTamoni/AP

Moment in time: June 16, 1904 -- A day so pivotal for James Joyce, he set Ulysses on it

It could almost have been June 14. That was the date James Joyce had set for his first date with his future wife, Nora Barnacle, when they were to meet outside Sir William Wilde's house on Merrion Square in Dublin. Nora didn't show, prompting the legendary author to write her to propose a new plan. Two days later, they strolled the city's Ringsend district and legend has it Joyce later told Barnacle she "made him a man" on that day. No matter what happened, he made sure the day endured by setting his masterpiece, Ulysses, on June 16, 1904. Now the date is known as Bloomsday, celebrated in Ireland since 1954, the original's 50th anniversary. Today, Joyceans around the world party with readings, costumed re-enactments and countless Gorgonzola sandwiches. -- Jared Bland

Photo: Popperfoto/Getty Images

Moment in time: June 2, 1983: Folk Singer Stan Rogers dies in plane fire

Stan Rogers had just played the renowned Kerrville Folk Festival in Texas when he boarded Air Canada Flight 797 in Dallas en route to Toronto. At 33, the Hamilton-born singer-songwriter with a booming baritone voice and a feel for working people's concerns was a stalwart of Canadian folk music. At 33,000 feet, a fire broke out in the DC-9's washroom, billowing toxic smoke and knocking out electrical circuits. The plane made it safely to the ground in Cincinnati, Ohio, and passengers started escaping on slides. But the open doors brought an inrush of oxygen and ignited a flash fire that killed 23 passengers who had yet to get out. Musician Shari Ulrich told the CBC last year that Rogers seemed "possessed" when he played. "He was unstoppable. Until, of course, that fateful day." -- Jane Gadd 

Photo: Larry James Fillo

Moment in time: May 22, 1987 -- Rick Hansen completes his Man in Motion world tour

"When you are out wheeling," Rick Hansen said at the midpoint of his 40,000-kilometre Man in Motion tour, "there is nowhere to hide." He was describing the singular focus, even loneliness, of his odyssey. But by the time Hansen rolled into Vancouver, 792 days and 160 worn-out tires after he'd left, the thousands of Canadians cheering him on demonstrated he was far from alone. Paralyzed from the waist down at age 15, Hansen was an accomplished wheelchair marathoner before launching his 34-country tour to raise funds for spinal cord research. His determination inspired millions of people and the tour raised $26-million. Today, the Rick Hansen Foundation has raised 10 times that amount and its founder remains a national hero. "Be the best you can with what you have," Hansen said. "That's what counts in life." -- Kate Hopwood

Photo: Greg Kinch/Reuters

Moment in time: May 16, 1986 -- Bobby Ewing rises from the dead

The return of Bobby Ewing to Dallas came as quite a shock. Viewers sensibly assumed the character played by Patrick Duffy was gone forever after he was run over by a car while valiantly trying to save ex-wife Pam (Victoria Principal) in the prime-time soap's eighth season. But in the closing moments of the ninth-season finale, Pam - on the day of her wedding to Mark Graison (John Beck) - was stunned to discover a naked and perfectly healthy Bobby in her shower. The truth behind Bobby's comeback: Duffy had left the show for other acting opportunities that never materialized, and requested his character's reprise. For the 10th season, Dallas writers simply reframed the entire previous season as one long, feverish dream by Pam. You could get away with a lot more on TV in those days. -- Andrew Ryan

Photo: The Kobal Collection

Moment in time: Churchill issues a great rhetorical blast 

At 65, back from political exile, the lion roared again. On May 10, Hitler's army invaded France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg, and Britain's government fell. King George VI invited the canny old warrior Winston Churchill, First Lord of the Admiralty, to lead the country through the coming storm. Three days later, Churchill struck a war cabinet and pledged in his first speech to Parliament ''to wage war against a monstrous tyranny never surpassed in the dark and lamentable catalogue of human crime.'' Having already served his country in various conflicts as a soldier and Secretary of War, he was armed and ready with the first great rhetorical blast of his new role: ''I have nothing to offer,'' he told politicians who would put aside partisanship to defeat the enemy, ''but blood, toil, tears and sweat.'' -- Elizabeth Renzetti

Photo: Press Association

Moment in time: May 9, 1974 -- Bruce Springsteen opens for Bonnie Raitt

In spring, 1974, after witnessing a particularly seismic performance from a relatively unknown troubadour opening for established act Bonnie Raitt in Cambridge, Mass., music writer Jon Landau crowed excitably in the Boston alternative weekly The Real Paper. ''I saw rock and roll's future,'' wrote Landau, ''and its name is Bruce Springsteen.'' When the Columbia label used the quote in an ensuing ad campaign, sales of Springsteen's second album spurted noticeably. Landau, having already invested his reputation, strapped his hands across Springsteen's engines by becoming his manager and co-producing his breakthrough 1975 album Born to Run. The disc went gold, Time and Newsweek ran concurrent cover stories on the angst-ridden, anthemic artist, and the prophecy was fulfilled. -- Brad Wheeler

Moment in time: May 7, 1987 -- Closing time for Shelley Long on Cheers

Long before cable fare and reality TV, viewers were invested in the relationship between bartender/Lothario Sam Malone and waitress/intellectual-wannabe Diane Chambers on Cheers. Played by Ted Danson and Shelley Long, the tempestuous couple were booked to walk down the aisle in the fifth-season finale of the 1980s sitcom, but forces were at work behind the scenes: Danson had renewed his contract, but Long had decided to chase a film career. In the closer, I Do, Adieu, Diane learned that a publisher loved one of her manuscripts. When the wedding day arrived, Diane was willing but Sam persuaded her to pursue her literary dreams and underscored his support by telling her to "have a good life" - twice. Long's movie career fizzled (Troop Beverly Hills, anyone?), but Danson remains a prime-time staple. -- Andrew Ryan

Moment in time: April 30, 1997 -- Ellen comes out on her ABC sitcom

Ellen DeGeneres scooped herself with the announcement that her sitcom persona was gay. The comedy veteran was the reason to watch These Friends of Mine, a top show in 1994. ABC changed the name to Ellen, and by the fourth season there were rumblings that bookstore manager Ellen Morgan might acknowledge her same-sex preference. On April 14, 1997, DeGeneres was on the cover of Time magazine with the words: ''Yep, I'm Gay.'' Two weeks later, more than 42 million U.S. viewers watched the coming-out episode, which guest-starred Laura Dern. But ratings sagged by the end of the season and ABC pulled the plug. The real Ellen married Portia de Rossi in 2008 and reinvented herself on daytime TV. -- Andrew Ryan

Moment in time: April 28, 1994 -- 250,000 flee Rwanda in a single day

They are portraits of pain. Alone and unsmiling, the children in the snapshots were orphaned or separated from their families in the wave of refugees who left the Rwandan civil war and genocide that killed almost one million people. On April 28, 250,000 Rwandans flooded into neighbouring Tanzania, the biggest and fastest one-day movement the United Nations had ever seen. By the end of the year, more than 100,000 Rwandan children were without a parent and dependent on aid agencies for food, water and safety. Thousands of refugee photos, shot on film donated by Kodak, were circulated among refugee camps and would help Save the Children find the parents of 40,000 children. -- Eric Atkins

Moment in time: April 25, 1983 -- Soviet leader writes to U.S. schoolgirl

In a bizarre Cold War moment, 10-year-old Samantha Smith posed the question that terrified hundreds of millions of adults. In a letter to Soviet leader Yuri Andropov, she asked: "Please tell me how you are going to help to not have a war." The innocent missive ended up in Pravda, and the world's media descended on Samantha's Maine home. She wanted an answer, so in a second letter she pressed Andropov for a reply. This time he wrote back, calling her a "courageous and honest girl" and inviting her family for a two-week summer visit. Mikhail Gorbachev later said he was much moved by Samantha's plea. Ronald Reagan hailed "her idealism and unaffected sweetness of spirit" after she died in a 1985 plane crash. Three months later, Gorbachev and Reagan met for the first of the summits that ended the Cold War. -- Paul Koring

Photo: UPI

Moment in time: April 24, 1942 -- Lucy Maud Montgomery dies

In her 21 books, Lucy Maud Montgomery always provided happy endings. Her feisty heroines - most famously red-haired Anne Shirley - invariably defeated the naysayers who undermine the dreams of the young. A happy ending eluded Montgomery herself. She died at 67 at her Toronto home, officially of coronary thrombosis but more likely of a self-inflicted overdose, a circumstance her descendants revealed only six years ago. A bedside note read: ''May God forgive me. ... My position is too awful to endure.'' The depression that claimed her sprang from her miserable marriage to a mentally ill clergyman who never read her novels, and from the shame of her elder son's criminal behaviour. Diagnosed with "neurasthenia," she was prescribed barbiturates and bromides, whose dangers weren't understood. Barbiturates are habit forming and bromides, toxic. She is buried in Cavendish, PEI, a place of pilgrimage for her readers from around the world. -- Judy Stoffman

Photo: The Canadian Press

Moment in time: April 21, 1989 -- Dry Lips has its first taste of success 

Cree playwright Tomson Highway's Dry Lips Oughta Move to Kapuskasing was enthusiastically received in its world premiere at Toronto's Theatre Passe Muraille. A co-production with Native Earth Performing Arts, it would go on to nab the Chalmers and four Dora Mavor Moore awards. A follow-up to The Rez Sisters, the tragicomic play focused on the tribulations of men living on the fictional Wasaychigan Hill reserve who are threatened by the creation of a women's hockey league. In the cast were Gary Farmer, Ben Cardinal and Graham Greene. When Dry Lips transferred to the Royal Alexandra Theatre two years later, with the backing of Mirvish Productions, it became the first work by an aboriginal dramatist to have a commercial run on that historic stage. -- J. Kelly Nestruck

NOTE: This post incorrectly said the play was the first non-musical by any Canadian to be staged at the Royal Alexandra Theatre. There were other Canadian plays previously, and we have edited the post to corect it.

Moment in time: April 15, 2009 -- Susan Boyle video goes viral

Fame is fickle. Talent will out. Looks are deceiving. All those clichés can be applied to Susan Boyle in the wake of her appearance as a contestant on ITV's Britain's Got Talent. When the portly, unemployed, 47-year-old Scot took the stage to sing I Dreamed a Dream from Les Misérables on April 11, expectations were not high - certainly among the studio audience and the judges, including the acerbic Simon Cowell. Boyle, of course, went on to wow them - and 11 million Britons watching on the telly. But this was only the beginning. Within four days, Boyle's triumphant performance had gone viral, drawing more than four million views on YouTube alone. Today they number more than 200 million. Six weeks after her debut, Boyle was signing a recording contract with ... Simon Cowell. -- James Adams

Moment in time: April 9, 2005 -- Prince Charles weds Camilla Parker-Bowles

It was a rocky road to marital bliss. They met in 1970, both 23. Camilla was said to have whispered to the future king: "My great-grandmother was your great-great-grandfather's mistress, so how about it?" But they went on to marry other people. By 1992, it became public - that tampon comment - just how much Charles was devoted to her. They divorced within a year of one another. Camilla was Public Enemy No. 1, seen as the wrecker of a home and a fairy tale. They kept their romance quiet in the aftermath of Princess Diana's death in 1997. When they married in a civil ceremony, the Queen and Prince Philip didn't attend, lest they upset traditionalists. (They were present at a later blessing.) But Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall, is now an accepted member of The Firm. Some even say she'll be called Queen one day. -- Sarah Hampson

Moment in time: April 4, 1581: Francis Drake knighted on the Golden Hind 

Never mind that the Spanish were calling his conduct piratical. Francis Drake kneeled to be knighted by Queen Elizabeth I on the deck of the Golden Hind, the ship he captained through the first circumnavigation of the globe, a trip of 58,000 kilometres. Drake set out in 1577 with five ships and a royal commission to cross the Atlantic Ocean, explore the Pacific and disrupt Spanish shipping. Down two vessels when he passed through the Strait of Magellan in 1578, he soon lost two more in stormy weather. Only the Golden Hind moved up the Pacific coast, attacking and plundering Spanish merchants and claiming California as New Albion. Drake crossed the Pacific in 68 days and, after a three-year voyage, finally docked at Plymouth harbour in 1580, lighter on men but heavy with treasure and spices. -- James Bradshaw

Moment in time, March 27, 1964: 
In Anchorage, the ground began shaking violently at 5:36 p.m. Buildings crumbled or were buried by landslides, huge fissures split streets, and the airport control tower collapsed. 

In the port of Valdez, 60 kilometres from the quake's epicentre, a giant wave swept dock workers to their deaths and destroyed waterfront buildings. The tsunami travelled down the West Coast, striking Prince Rupert, B.C., and washing away homes in Port Alberni on Vancouver Island. In Crescent City, Calif., more than 2,500 kilometres away, the tsunami killed a dozen people. 

At 9.2 on the Richter scale, the Alaskan earthquake was the second largest ever recorded. Only the sparseness of the Northern population kept casualties to 129 dead. 

The most lasting effect may have been the quake's influence on the newly emerging science of plate tectonics.

Moment in time: March 26, 1992 -- Beloved broadcaster Barbara Frum dies

The self-taught interviewer ruled the airwaves for more than two decades with her take-no-prisoners approach with everyone from Brian Mulroney to Margaret Thatcher to Nelson Mandela. Barbara Frum became a daily presence in our lives in 1971, at the helm of CBC Radio's As It Happens, and later as a host of The Journal on TV. Despite her tough style, her audience felt so close to her that when Frum once checked into an Alberta hotel, the entire staff lined up to meet her. Only her very tight circle knew she'd been battling leukemia for 18 years, so the news of her death at 54 shocked the country. As friends and colleagues paid tribute, we learned Frum was also an accomplished gardener, called her mother daily and had discreetly come to the aid of many.

As one of her producers put it, she became a den mother to a whole country. -- Alison Gzowski

Photo: CBC

Moment in time: March 24, 1944 -- The great escape from Stalag Luft III

On a moonless night in Lower Silesia, 76 Allied airmen (nine of them Canadian) made their way out of a cramped 102-metre tunnel named Harry and ran for their lives into enemy territory. The escape from escape-proof Stalag Luft III, immortalized in a 1963 film that unnecessarily added Steve McQueen and his wire-jumping motorcycle, was achieved by meticulous preparations. Three nine-metre-deep tunnels (Tom, Dick and Harry) were built with bits of tin cans, planks from prison bunks and stolen wiring. Scroungers weaselled maps from guards, forgers faked travel documents and tailors made passable civilian clothes out of coarse blankets. Tonnes of excavated sand were scattered on parade grounds and prison gardens. But only three men made it home; 23 were reimprisoned and 50 executed on Hitler's orders. -- John Allemang

Photo: Imperial War Museum

Moment in time: March 21, 1970 -- American Woman released as a single

"American woman, stay away from me," the song went, "American woman, mama let me be." It was a rugged FM staple that became the Guess Who's breakthrough hit in the U.S. despite its less than red-white-and-blue bent. The song was invented spontaneously at a concert in a curling rink outside Toronto, where Burton Cummings came up with the undiplomatic themes while Randy Bachman struck a stuttering guitar riff. "It wasn't political," Winnipeg-bred Cummings would explain. "What I was paraphrasing was 'Canadian women, I prefer you.' " Later he added lines about ghetto scenes and war machines, which should have cut close to the American bone. Instead, the song became an ironic anthem. Pat Nixon was the one mama who would not let the Guess Who be. She banned the song from the White House. -- Brad Wheeler

Photo: Alamy

Moment in time: March 20, 1995 -- Tokyo commuters gassed with sarin

It wasn't the apocalypse that Shoko Asahara had predicted, but the carnage unleashed on Tokyo's subway by followers of the doomsday cult leader scarred Japan. Five men released colourless, odourless sarin gas in train cars on three central Tokyo lines, bent on ultimately ushering in Armageddon as prophesied by Asahara, the half-blind ''Venerated Master' of the Aum Shinrikyo religious sect. Crowds of confused rush-hour commuters were left gasping, blood gushing from their noses and mouths. The attack killed 13 people, injured at least 5,500 and prompted a massive manhunt. After two months, authorities captured Asahara, who was hiding at an Aum compound, and rounded up some 200 sect members. The last of Aum's leaders was caught only in 2012. -- James Bradshaw

Moment in time: March 14, 1985 -- Cats launches Toronto megamusical era 

Toronto's megamusical moment began as the city awoke to rave reviews for producer Marlene Smith's production of Andrew Lloyd Webber's Cats at the refurbished Elgin Theatre. A musical song cycle based on T.S. Eliot's poems about felines with godawful names like Grizabella and Mungojerrie, the show was already an international hit by the time it reached Canada. "Cats has arrived with a triumphant yowl," Globe and Mail theatre critic Ray Conlogue declared. Soon enough, Livent and Mirvish Productions would embark on a megamusical competition, with The Phantom of the Opera on one side and Les Miserables on the other, that saw Toronto touted as the world's third-biggest English-speaking theatre capital. Until it was no longer, and we finally got Magical Mr. Mistoffelees out of our heads. -- J. Kelly Nestruck

Moment in time: March 13, 1996 -- Sixteen children and a teacher die in Dunblane school massacre

Thomas Hamilton wore hearing protection and carried four handguns when he burst into the gym at Dunblane Primary School in Scotland just after 9 a.m. He shot and killed 16 children and their teacher, Gwen Mayor, who died trying to protect her class of five- and six-year-olds. In less than four minutes, the 43-year-old jobless shopkeeper aimed and pulled the trigger more than 100 times before putting the muzzle in his mouth and killing himself. Ten children and three adults were treated at hospital but lived. Among the children lined up for the next gym class was a boy named Andy Murray, who was unhurt and would go on to become a star tennis player. The massacre, carried out by a misfit known to police, prompted Britain to ban private ownership of handguns and semi-automatic weapons.  -- Eric Atkins

Moment in time: March 7, 1897 -- Dr. Kellogg Serves Up the First Corn Flakes

Though Corn Flakes were sugar-free and tasteless in their earliest incarnation, the cereal eventually became a breakfast staple around the world. Their creator, John Harvey Kellogg, was a Seventh-day Adventist who invented the foodstuff to fill out the diets of patients at his "healthy living" sanitarium in Battle Creek, Mich. His more enterprising brother Will added sugar to the recipe shortly after. The commercialization of corn flakes created a rift between them, and John sued Will to prevent him selling the product. John lost, Will formed his own company and marketed Kellogg's Corn Flakes to the hilt. For the rest of his days, John distanced himself from his invention and devoted his time to the sanitarium, which remained open until a year before his death in 1943 at age 91. Will died eight years later, also 91 but considerably wealthier. -- Andrew Ryan 

Photo: Kellogg Canada Inc.

Moment in time: March 6, 1899 -- Bayer Patents Aspirin 

Headache? Or maybe your doctor has told you to take one daily to help prevent heart disease or stroke. When you reach for the most common drug in household medicine cabinets - the painkiller we consume more than 40,000 tonnes of every year - think of Felix Hoffman. He was the chemist named on the patent for Friedrich Bayer & Co.'s first major product. But don't forget the name Arthur Eichengrun. Rumour - and an article Eichengrun wrote in 1949 - suggest Hoffman was merely carrying out Eichengrun's research, for which he never got credit. Talk about a bitter pill to swallow. Folk remedies used salicylic acid from willow bark to relieve pain. What Bayer produced was a stable, palatable form of acetylsalicylic acid, first in powder form and later in a tablet. The rest is quick-fix, pill-popping cultural history. -- Sarah Hampson

Photo: AP

Moment in time: March 3, 1991 -- Rodney King Beaten by Los Angeles Police

Rodney King was hardly the first black man beaten by police, but a then-rare amateur videotape of the vicious, systematic attack captured the grim, often racist reality of U.S. inner cities. When the baton-swinging, Taser-firing LAPD officers were acquitted, President George H.W. Bush said he was "stunned." Riots erupted. By the time troops restored order, 53 people had died and more than 2,300 were injured. As L.A. burned, King issued his famous plea: "Can we all get along?" Eventually a second, federal trial sent two officers to prison. King won a multimillion-dollar lawsuit, married and divorced one of the jurors, battled drug addiction, became a minor celebrity and had multiple run-ins with the law. He drowned accidentally at age 47 with alcohol, cocaine and marijuana in his blood. - Paul Koring

Photo: George Holliday/AP

Moment in time: Feb. 28, 1996 -- Alanis Morissette Cleans Up at the Grammys

Alanis Morissette was only 21 when she released Jagged Little Pill, her third studio album and first to be released internationally. The mix of pop and angst on songs like Ironic and You Oughta Know made it a phenomenon. It sold millions of copies (more than 33 million to date), reached No. 1 on the Billboard 200 and prompted widespread debate over the definition of the word "ironic." The album was nominated for nine Grammy awards and won four, including best rock song, best female vocal performance and best rock album. The Ottawa-born artist  also beat out Pearl Jam, Mariah Carey, Michael Jackson and Joan Osborne to win album of the year, making her the youngest ever to win that award until Taylor Swift unseated her in 2010. -- Dave McGinn

Moment in time: Feb. 26, 1936 -- Hitler Introduced the Volkswagen
 
Adolf Hitler didn't have hippies in mind when he commissioned the Volkswagen. Designed by Ferdinand Porsche in the 1930s, the "people's car" was meant to be an affordable family automobile in a Germany where car ownership was a luxury enjoyed by just one in 50. The dictator envisioned his people touring the homeland on newly-built autobahns. Though an assembly plant was opened on this date, Volkswagens weren't produced in large numbers until after the war. The Beetle, with its simple, air-cooled engine in the rear and rounded corners, became one of the best-selling cars of the century. Sales in North America took off in the 1960s, when the Beetle and its bigger brother the Volkswagen bus were embraced by the peace-loving counterculture, festooned with flowers and full of unwashed shaggy types. -- Eric Atkins

Photo: Alamy

Moment in time: Feb. 25, 1994 -- Mass killing of Palestinians at prayer in Hebron 
 
It wasn't unusual for Israeli physician Baruch Goldstein to pray at the Tomb of Abraham in the West Bank town of Hebron, and it was normal for a settler like him to carry his submachine gun. So Israeli guards didn't bat an eye when Goldstein strode past them. Muslims that day were marking the holy month of Ramadan in their mosque next to the tomb, while Israelis in the adjacent room celebrated the feast of Purim, which recalls Jews escaping a death sentence in ancient Persia. Goldstein was on a Purim mission of his own. A disciple of the anti-Arab rabbi Meir Kahane, he opened fire on the Muslims kneeling before him, killing 29 and wounding dozens before being beaten to death by survivors. Forty days later, Hamas retaliated with its first suicide bombing, killing eight Israelis in Afula. The peace process has never recovered. -- Patrick White 

Photo: Jerome Delay/AP

Moment in time: Feb. 21, 1974, Tim Horton killed in sports car crash -- Yes, there really was a Tim Horton. Though the current generation may know the ubiquitous coffee chain was named for a hockey player, it's unlikely they are aware of the events leading to the death of its namesake at age 44. By 1974, the sturdy defenceman from Cochrane, Ont., had spent 25 seasons in the NHL, mostly with the Toronto Maple Leafs, and was making good money from the coffee-and-doughnut empire he launched in 1964. Buffalo Sabres general manager Punch Imlach enticed Horton to play the 1973-74 season with a bonus - a De Tomaso Pantera sports car. Following a game between the Sabres and Leafs in Toronto, Horton was driving the vehicle back to Buffalo when he lost control. Not wearing a seatbelt, he was ejected 60 metres and pronounced dead at a local hospital. -- Andrew Ryan 

Photo: Hamilton Spectator

Moment in time: Feb. 20, 1992, Last member of the Group of Seven dies -- By the time Alfred Joseph "A.J." Casson joined the Group of Seven in 1926, stepping in after Frank Johnston left for Winnipeg, there were no more big battles to fight. The group had won over critics with its mission of creating a distinctive Canadian style; it disbanded six years later. Casson preferred watercolour over the oil favoured by the group, and his heart belonged in the villages and farms of Southern Ontario rather than rough northern landscapes. But as the last surviving member, he was the group's longest-serving ambassador. And when he died at 93, earning a place beside five other members on the grounds of the McMichael Canadian Art Collection, critic John Bentley Mays wrote that the group "quietly, suddenly became distant, as every artistic movement becomes distant once its last storyteller has died." -- Simon Houpt

Photo: McMichael Canadian Art Collection

Moment in time: Feb. 14, 1962, Jackie Kennedy hosts televised White House tour -- For the first time ever, a presidential family invited the nation into their living room - and more than 80 million TV viewers tuned in for the occasion.

Jacqueline Kennedy, then just 31, led an hour-long televised tour of the newly restored White House, a project she had overseen with the aim of showcasing U.S. history and design. It was a broadcasting sensation, reshaping the way Americans related to their leading family, burnishing the aura surrounding the Kennedy White House and turning the first lady into a major celebrity.

The end result was not only good politics but also compelling diplomacy: A version of the show was later broadcast in countries all over the world.

Kennedy, meanwhile, was awarded an honorary Emmy for her role as host. -- Joanna Slater 

Photo: AP

Moment in time: Feb. 7, 1845, Portland Vase smashed at British Museum -- The "stout young man," as police would describe him, admitted he'd been on a bender for a week, but still: Could that explain why William Lloyd wandered into the British Museum just before closing and smashed one of its greatest attractions to smithereens? This was the Portland Vase, a superb Roman cameo-glass vessel dating to the early first century, entrusted to the museum by its owner, the 3rd Duke of Portland, in 1810. Lloyd, a university student, was packed off to prison (briefly) while the museum brought in a restorer to put its treasure together again. Fortunately, near-identical copies made decades earlier by the famous Josiah Wedgwood could be consulted. Unfortunately, 37 tiny fragments were left over and vanished from sight until 1948, when another restoration was done. -- James Adams 

Photo: British Museum

Moment in time: Feb. 5, 2010, Jack Layton announces he has cancer -- Jack Layton's aides were shaken. Their boss, the leader of the federal New Democrats and a man known for his commitment to physical fitness, was announcing he had prostate cancer. To some outsiders, the whole thing may have seemed over-dramatic. Mr. Layton, who revealed his illness at a specially arranged news conference in Toronto, had been diagnosed months earlier. His father had been successfully treated for the same disease. And no, he wouldn't be stepping down as party leader, just taking a little time off for treatment. It seemed obvious he would recover. And he did - rallying to lead his party to Official Opposition status a year later when Quebeckers embraced him en masse as "un bon Jack." But less than four months after that election he was gone - taken by a different, undisclosed type of cancer. -- Gloria Galloway 

Photo: Mark Blinch/Reuters

Moment in time: Feb. 4, 1924, Canada basks in first gold at Winter Olympics -- As the French town of Chamonix wound down the festivities, Canadians across the Dominion awoke to discover their country had mined Winter Olympic gold for the first time. Represented by an amateur club, the Toronto Granites, Canada became the last nation to successfully defend a Summer Olympics title at a Winter Games, having won the inaugural "ice hockey" tournament four years earlier in Antwerp. As in 2010, it came at the expense of the U.S., and while there was no Sidney Crosby golden goal, Harry (Moose) Watson handily eclipsed the superstar who will lead the Canadian men's hockey team in Sochi. The Newfoundlander notched a hat trick in a 6-1 final victory over the Americans, running his total to 36 goals in five games - including 13 in a 33-0 win over Switzerland - before spurning the NHL for a career in insurance. -- Paul Attfield 

Photo: Hulton Archive/Getty Images

Moment in time: Jan. 31, 1958, Canada's first aboriginal senator approved -- James Gladstone, or Akay-na-muka (Many Guns), was appointed to the Senate two years before status Indians had the franchise. Born a Cree in 1887 and later adopted by the Blood Tribe of the Blackfoot Nation, he was twice elected president of the Indian Association of Alberta. Appointed by Prime Minister John Diefenbaker as an "Independent Conservative" senator, Gladstone spoke in the Blackfoot language in his maiden speech in "recognition of the first Canadians" and successfully lobbied for changes to the Indian Act and the right to vote. A dozen years later, in his farewell speech, he predicted that "some day this country will come of age, and all people whatever their national differences will unite as one nation." He didn't live to see that day, but his bust stands in the Senate antechamber as a tribute - and reminder. -- Sandra Martin
 
Photo: Newton

Moment in time: Jan. 30, 1649, Charles I beheaded in London -- 
His authority came from God, Charles insisted, and only God could take it away. Yet there he was on the scaffold outside the Banqueting House in London's Whitehall district, forced to bend to parliamentarians who'd judged him guilty of treason. In better times, for him if not for the country that he reduced to civil war, the Banqueting House was a symbol of royal grandeur - Charles commissioned the Rubens paintings that still decorate its opulent ceiling. Now it was the setting of monarchy's end. On a chilly afternoon, Charles wore two shirts to prevent the shivering that might be mistaken for fear. He tucked his flowing locks under a humble cap to make the executioner's job easier. When he stretched out his arms - the agreed sign that he was ready - the blade descended and England became a republic. -- John Allemang

Photo: The Art Archive

Moment in time: Jan. 27, 1938, Niagara's Honeymoon Bridge felled by ice -- Just like nearby Niagara Falls, the collapse of the Honeymoon Bridge was a spectacle. Thousands lined the banks of the Niagara River to watch the bridge twist and buckle under the tonnes of ice that had been piling up around its base since an earlier storm. The steel-arch bridge, which connected Ontario with New York state, was known for swaying and there were plans to replace the 40-year-old structure long before it fell onto the ice. Mother Nature sped up those plans. The final pieces of the Honeymoon Bridge sank in April, after the springtime thaw. Its replacement, the Rainbow Bridge, would open in late 1941 and stands to this day. The new bridge was built 150 metres downriver from the old one, and its abutments are well away from the fast-flowing river and the ice grinding below. -- Eric Atkins 

Photo: Jack Smith/The Globe and Mail

Moment in time: Jan. 22, 1924, Britain elects first Labour prime minister -- A pacifist, a socialist and a traitor to some, Ramsay MacDonald managed a remarkable political comeback in 1924, forming a minority government and becoming Britain's first Labour prime minister. The illegitimate son of a Scottish farmhand, MacDonald had been declared politically dead a few years earlier for suggesting at the outset of the First World War that Britain was "morally wrong" for declaring war on Germany. His government only lasted a few months. He won another minority in 1929, but formed a coalition government two years later with the Conservatives and Liberals. The Labour Party never forgave him for joining with the hated Tories and drummed him out of the party in 1935. He died two years later. No wonder current Labour Party Leader Ed Miliband models his policies after a different politician from roughly the same era: Theodore Roosevelt. -- Paul Waldie

Photo: Press Association

Moment in time: Jan. 20, 1942, Nazi officials meet at the Wannsee Conference -- In the third year of history's bloodiest war, the Nazis had already murdered hundreds of thousands, through the euthanasia of mental patients, shooting squads in the Soviet Union, the opening of death camps that started the mass killing of Polish Jews. But a key moment in the Holocaust took place in the leafy Berlin suburb of Wannsee. Fifteen high-ranking Nazis and bureaucrats met at a lakeside villa to coordinate the systematic, total annihilation of all of Europe's 11 million Jews. In cold, clinical language, the conference minutes repeatedly speak of the "final solution of the Jewish question," a euphemism for deportation, forced labour and mass executions. "No other document from the National Socialist regime," the historian Wolfgang Scheffler wrote, "sets out so clearly the complete plan for the extermination of European Jewry." -- Tu Thanh Ha 

Photo: Reuters

Moment in time: Jan. 14, 1967, The Human Be-In offers a glimpse of Summer of Love -- When the California government banned the use of the hallucinogenic drug LSD, leaders in the state's emerging anti-establishment movement decided to register their unhappiness with the new law. They organized a protest rally at San Francisco's Golden Gate Park under the moniker The Human Be-In, a good-humoured riff on the dozens of protest sit-ins that had begun to spring up on U.S. college campuses. The event attracted some of the biggest names of the nascent hippie movement, including Harvard professor and LSD advocate Timothy Leary, who took to the stage to utter the famous phrase: "Turn on, tune in, drop out." The music was provided by some of the most iconic bands of that era, including Jefferson Airplane and The Grateful Dead. Many of those in attendance had wandered over from the city's Haight-Ashbury district, which would become the epi-centre of the counter-culture phenomenon. Five months later, the Summer of Love would begin. -- Gary Mason 

Photo: AP

Moment in time, Jan. 10, 1901, Spindletop oil strike -- On Spindletop hill in Texas, energy pioneers struck oil in the form of a massive, crude-spewing gusher 113 years ago today. Oil from the Spindletop well, about 140 kilometres east of Houston, shot up 60 metres into the sky, launching Texas's first energy boom and making America a dominant energy player. The geyser took days to harness and a land rush followed, as did the boom and bust of Beaumont, the neighbouring town. Spindletop, at the time, became the world's most plentiful oilfield and Chevron Corp., the modern-day powerhouse, is one of the companies that owes its existence to the find. But forget oil. Without Spindletop, there would be a yawning gap in U.S. pop culture: Texas, after all, had to boom in order for Dallas, the oil-soaked soap opera, to flourish. -- Carrie Tait

Photo: Reuters

Moment in time: Jan. 6, 1978, Sun Life annouces it is quitting Quebec -- Sun Life Assurance Co. was among many firms to leave Montreal for fear of language laws and Quebec independence, but few matched its inelegant departure. Its stately building in Montreal was the biggest in the British Empire for a time, and by the 1970s French was still scarcely heard in its marble halls. In 1978, citing Bill 101's ban on discrimination against francophones, the corporate giant announced it was heading to Toronto, along with 1,800 jobs. Jacques Parizeau, then finance minister, called it a final chapter for "one of the worst corporate citizens Quebec has known." Four years later, Sun Life picked a British firm over a lower Quebec bid to build a Toronto headquarters. The rejected builder said Sun Life executives seemed to fear the building would collapse the instant Quebec separated. -- Les Perreaux

Photo: Canadian Press

Moment in time, Dec. 27, 1831: Darwin sets sail on HMS Beagle -- Charles Darwin was a 22-year-old Cambridge graduate with an uncertain future as a backwoods clergyman when he was recruited to keep the captain of the HMS Beagle company. Robert FitzRoy, whose predecessor had shot himself in a fit of desolation, was leading a surveying expedition to the remotest parts of South America, and sought out a paying passenger who was keen to explore the land while he charted the coasts of Patagonia and Tierra del Fuego. For weeks the Beagle waited for a favourable wind in the stormy waters off Plymouth, making several failed attempts to reach the open sea. At Christmas, the crew drank heavily and were too hung over to sail. Finally, on Dec. 27, sobriety and decent weather came together. The Beagle weighed anchor, and a seasick Darwin began his life-changing five-year voyage. -- John Allemang

akgphotos/Newscom

Moment in time: Dec. 24, 1871, Verdi's Aida premieres in Cairo -- The first performance of Verdi's epic opera Aida took place in a three-tiered theatre in Cairo that held only 850. A paper airplane thrown from the cheap seats might have hit the painted sets, which had finally arrived after being trapped in Paris for several months by the Franco-German war. The opera, set in ancient Egypt, deals with the travails of a captive Ethiopian princess. The viceroy of Egypt, who built the theatre and commissioned the opera, was happy. But Verdi, who did not attend, was annoyed to hear later that the house was too small to hold anyone but invited guests and critics. He always regarded Aida's Milan debut in 1872 as the opera's true premiere. The opera house went bankrupt in 1887, burned down in 1971, and was replaced with a multi-tiered parking lot called Opera Garage. -- Robert Everett-Green

Photo: Newscom

Moment in time: Dec. 20, 1989, U.S. troops invade Panama -- Operation Just Cause, which ousted General Manuel Noriega, was complicated by the messy reality that the drug-lord-turned-dictator was a former CIA stooge who had dealt with U.S. President George H.W. Bush when he was running the agency. U.S. Special Forces blew up Noriega's personal gunboat and jet to prevent him escaping. The invasion involved thousands of troops, hundreds of deaths, considerable chaos and some farce: Noriega eventually surrendered from his refuge in the Vatican embassy after being deafened for days with rock music. A century after the United States created Panama to complete its canal, and a decade after the canal was given back to the Panamanians, Noriega stood trial in the U.S. In 2011, Panama's democratically elected president, Ricardo Martinelli, extradited him. He's still in prison. -- Paul Koring 

Jaime Fernandez/AP

Moment in time, Dec. 18, 1941, The Battle of Hong Kong erupts -- Before they were posted to Hong Kong, the Royal Rifles of Canada served in Newfoundland and the Winnipeg Grenadiers in Jamaica. With minimal combat training, the 1,975 soldiers were expected to merely garrison the British colony, which was guarded by 14,000 British, Indian and Chinese troops. But three weeks after the Canadians arrived, Japan sprung attacks on Pearl Harbor and across the South Pacific. The Japanese 38th Division stormed ashore on Hong Kong Island on the night of Dec. 18. Heavily outnumbered, with almost no naval or air support, the Canadians soon found themselves in hand-to-hand combat. Days later, 290 were dead - including some bayoneted as they lay in field hospital beds - and 493 were wounded. A further 267 would die as prisoners of war after the colony surrendered. -- Mark Hume

Photo: AP
Today's editorial cartoon by David Parkins

Moment in time: Dec. 16, 1809, Napoleon divorces Josephine -- "Don't wash," Napoleon is said to have entreated his lover Josephine in an ardent message announcing his imminent return from a military campaign. When they met, she was a widow with two children and a reputation as a licentious political mistress with expensive tastes. Six years his senior, curvaceous, with chestnut hair and hazel eyes, she had an engaging personality, though she rarely smiled because her teeth were rotten. Despite her infidelities and spendthrift ways, Napoleon adored Josephine and made her his empress. They only divorced because she hadn't given him a child and he wanted an heir. Even after his marriage to Marie-Louise of Austria, the couple remained close. All that came between them was her debts, Napoleon said later, and her name was on his lips as he lay dying in exile on St. Helena. -- Sandra Martin 

Jacques-Louis David/Louvre

Moment in time: Dec. 13, 2000, Gore concedes presidency to Bush -- Were the chads dimpled, hanging or, er, pregnant? It is hard not to recall with a shudder the five weeks in the fall of 2000 when the American presidency seemed to hinge on small fragments of paper. Al Gore had won the popular vote, but George W. Bush eked out a victory in the Electoral College thanks to a hotly contested result in the state of Florida. So began a maze of recounts and legal challenges, culminating in a ruling by the U.S. Supreme Court on Dec. 12. The 5-4 decision in the case - Bush v. Gore - stopped the Florida recount. The next day, Mr. Gore conceded in a televised speech. "While I strongly disagree with the court's decision, I accept it," he said. "It's time for me to go." -- Joanna Slater
 
Photo: Amel Emric, CP

Moment in time: Dec. 4, 1991, Hostage Terry Anderson is freed -- A U.S. marine turned foreign correspondent, Terry Anderson seemed fearless as AP bureau chief in Beirut during the Lebanese Civil War - until the day in March, 1985, when members of the newly formed Shia Hezbollah militia abducted him as he left a tennis court. He was held for six years and nine months, the longest of all the 92 foreign hostages in Lebanon in those years. "I well remember - and shall never forget - the fear of being powerless in the hands of those who hate you," Anderson wrote. His joy at being released and reunited with family gave way a few years later to disappointment with his country. As a former prisoner, he was shaken by revelations of what transpired at Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq. "When torture becomes entertainment, we're sick," he said. "I think the U.S. has become less than it was." -- Patrick Martin 

Photo: Santiago Lyon/AP

Moment in time: Dec. 2, 1973, The Who are jailed in Montreal -- It had been a frustrating tour for the Who, as the shows to promote their ambitious album Quadrophenia were unusually complex. Eventually tensions led to the trashing of a room at Montreal's Bonaventure Hotel, where, among other things, a TV suffered the cliché rock-and-roll fate of being tossed out a window. Band and crew - except singer Roger Daltrey, who had retired early - were led off to jail, where they had a merry time for a few hours. Later, guitarist Pete Townshend unconvincingly justified the band's brash interior redecorating, saying: "I feel the same way towards hotels that our audience feels toward us - I'm kind of grateful that they're here, but I hate the prices they charge." The episode was chronicled in bassist John Entwistle's song Cell Number Seven, and rock-star hedonism lore grew a little bit more. -- Brad Wheeler 

Photo: Associated Press

Moment in time: Nov. 28, 1994, Jeffrey Dahmer murdered in prison: Jeffrey Dahmer, the serial killer and sexual monster who dismembered and cannibalized many of the at least 17 boys and men lured into his clutches, was murdered in a far more ordinary fashion: beaten to death by another inmate in the Wisconsin prison where he was serving multiple life sentences. Dubbed the Milwaukee Cannibal, Dahmer killed for the first time only weeks after graduating high school. He dissected his victim, beginning a gruesome pattern of dismemberment and necrophilia. Nine years passed before he killed again. Increasingly frequent murders followed, but one intended victim escaped and led police to an apartment littered with gruesome photos and at least four severed heads. Convicted in 1992, Dahmer was first held in solitary confinement, but asked to be moved to the general prison population. -- Paul Koring
 
Photo: Allen Fredrickson/Reuters

Moment in time: Nov. 25, 1952, The Mousetrap opens in London -- When the curtain first went up at the Ambassadors Theatre, Agatha Christie thought her murder-mystery play would last for eight months. By 1957, it had broken the record for longest run in the West End, previously held by Noel Coward's comedy Blithe Spirit. (Coward sent a telegram to Christie from Bermuda: "Much as it pains me I really must congratulate you.") Sixty-one years later, the whodunnit remains unstoppable -- even though the Internet has tried. Critics have always been asked to keep the identity of the murderer secret -- and while they have generally obliged, Wikipedia has not. In 2010, Christie's grandson, who received the rights as a birthday present, complained about the online encyclopedia's spoilers, igniting an edit war that continues to this day. Regardless, the trap keeps ensnaring audiences worldwide. -- J. Kelly Nestruck

Photo: Ian Nicholson/AFP

Moment in time: Nov. 2, 1998, CBS shows Jack Kevorkian assisting suicide -- Watching a man die on TV is disturbing under any circumstances, and this death came wrapped inside the explosive issue of euthanasia. Jack Kevorkian, the Michigan physician known as Dr. Death, taped himself injecting lethal drugs into the arm of a 52-year-old man suffering from Lou Gehrig's disease. Then he sent the tape to CBS's 60 Minutes, which broadcast it in prime time. Kevorkian wanted to push the agenda on doctor-assisted suicide, and challenged authorities to charge him. "The issue's got to be raised to the level where it is finally decided," he told journalist Mike Wallace. Prosecutors obliged him. Kevorkian was arrested, tried, and convicted of second-degree murder. Sentenced to 10 to 25 years in prison, he was released in 2007. Four years later, he was dead. The right-to-die debate lives on. -- Ingrid Peritz

Photo: Associated Press

Moment in time: Nov. 20, 1995, Princess Diana confesses all on TV -- These were things that royals did not talk about, especially not on the telly: bulimia, depression, adultery. But Princess Diana opened the confessional floodgates on BBC's Panorama, and 21 million people sat rapt (one of them was her 13-year-old son, William, watching from Eton, unhappily.) The interview had been conducted in deepest secrecy, but when it was over few secrets were left. There were three people in that marriage; Diana had had her own fun with a riding instructor; and she did not want to be Queen, but a queen in people's hearts. Buckingham Palace was apoplectic. The head of the BBC almost lost his job. And Diana got something she didn't want - a divorce - and something that she did, her freedom. For the next 21 months, at least. -- Elizabeth Renzetti

Photo: Reuters

Moment in time: Nov. 18, 1987, London tube station becomes an inferno -- At 7:29 p.m., a man travelling up escalator No. 4 noticed a small fire beneath a step at King's Cross Underground station. A minute later, another man spotted an orange glow and smoke. Yet there was no immediate panic at Britain's busiest station, a labyrinth of passages, shafts and tunnels where five subway lines met. Escalator fires were not uncommon in the Underground, often sparked by a cigarette butt or match. But this one was different. Sixteen minutes later, station inspectors heard a whoosh - the tell-tale sound of a flashover. In an instant, flames shot up the escalator shaft, licked the ceiling and spread. People screamed in terror as thick black smoke and searing heat engulfed the tunnels. Thirty-one people perished and many others were injured. London Underground, it turned out, did not have a formal evacuation plan. -- Renata D'Aliesio

Photo: Press Association

Moment in time: Oct. 29, 1924: Doukhobor leader blown up on CPR train -- When he boarded the CPR train at Brilliant, B.C., Peter "Lordly" Verigin had more than a few enemies, including some who'd burned his house down months earlier. The charismatic leader of the Doukhobor empire in Western Canada was under attack from zealots. His own son had dismissed him as a reprobate, and the Russian government was seething because he'd broken ties with it. At 1 a.m. an explosion tore apart his rail car, killing Verigin, 65, his companion Mary Strelaeff, 20, and seven others. Parts of a time bomb were found in the wreckage. Among the suspects were two Doukhobors who'd placed luggage by his seat, an eccentric called the Czar of Heaven, who had foretold the leader's death, and a Russian watchmaker. Seven thousand attended the funeral, but the crime was never solved. -- Mark Hume

Photo: SFU Special Collections
Today's editorial cartoon by David Parkins

Moment in time: Oct. 28, 1830: Escaped slave Josiah Henson reaches Canada -- It was an autumn morning when Josiah Henson first set foot on Canadian soil after a gruelling journey with his wife and four children. After crossing the Niagara River from Buffalo, he recalled, "I threw myself on the ground, rolled in the sand, seized handfuls of it and kissed them, and danced around, till, in the eyes of several who were present, I passed for a madman." A staunch Methodist preacher, Henson founded a settlement for former slaves in Dawn Township near Dresden, Ont., and worked to help others escape the U.S. South via the Underground Railroad. But he's perhaps best known as the inspiration for the main character in Harriet Beecher Stowe's Uncle Tom's Cabin, an abolitionist novel often said to have helped start the U.S. Civil War. -- Kim Mackrael

Photo: Uncle Tom's Cabin Historic Site

Moment in time: Oct. 24, 1992: Blue Jays win their first World Series -- With apologies to lacrosse - and despite any Act of Parliament to the contrary - there was a time when Canada had a sports passion to challenge hockey's supremacy. It was America's beloved pastime, baseball. The lamented Montreal Expos had come close, but in the fall of 1992 the Toronto Blue Jays went all the way. It seemed the entire country was tuning in to the late, great broadcaster Tom Cheek as the Jays first knocked off the Oakland A's - remember Roberto Alomar's homer off Dennis Eckersley? - and then, in Game 6 of the final against the Atlanta Braves, 41-year-old Dave Winfield struck a double in the 11th inning that gave the Jays a 4-3 victory. It marked the first time ever that the championship was celebrated outside U.S. borders. One year later, the Jays did it again. -- Roy MacGregor 

Photo: Rusty Kennedy/AP

Moment in time: Oct. 21, 1966: Aberfan disaster buries children -- If you visit the Welsh village of Aberfan today, you'll find an empty wooded plot filling what used to be a busy residential area on its west side. At the foot of a hill, a memorial plaque lists the names of 116 children aged between 7 and 10, and 28 adults. This was once the site of a primary school and about 20 houses. On Oct. 21, 1966 - the last day before a half-term break - the children had just finished singing All Things Bright and Beautiful at a pre-holiday assembly when, with a roar, a 40,000-tonne pile of wet coal-mining waste slid down the hill and buried the school. The frenzied rescue efforts and public grief shocked British TV viewers, as did the town's fury at the public-sector coal industry - whose chairman refused to pay for the cleanup of the village. -- Doug Saunders 

Photo: Mirrorpix/Everett Collection

Moment in time: Oct. 17, 1967: Hair happens in New York -- The dawning of the Age of Aquarius got a so-so review. When Hair, billed as an "American tribal love-rock musical," whooped and stripped its way onto the stage at the Public Theater in the East Village, New York Times critic Clive Barnes praised its shaggy charms, its music by Canadian expat Galt MacDermot, and its youthful, multiracial cast. But he noted that the show, with its free-love, anti-war call for revolution, was more of a happening than a satisfying narrative. When it opened on Broadway six months later, it had a new shape and a dozen new songs comprising a taxonomy of outré touchstones (hashish, the racial send-up Colored Spade). Uptown audiences were delirious. Still, as it ventured across the U.S., several communities were scandalized. Now? It's standard high-school fare. -- Simon Houpt 

Photo: Time & Life Pictures/Getty Image

Moment in time: Oct. 15, 1917: Mata Hari is executed -- She refused to wear a blindfold as she faced the firing squad. Born Margaretha Zelle in the Netherlands in 1876, she was known to the world as Mata Hari - exotic dancer, courtesan and, as history likes to record, seductress and spy. After a failed marriage to an abusive Dutch colonial army officer, she arrived penniless in Paris in 1903. She adopted her stage name, Indonesian for "sun," and won renown as a dancer in a jewelled bra. Her travels across Europe and liaisons with German military officials as the First World War raged prompted France to accuse her of spying. After a trial in which the defence could not question its own witnesses, she was found guilty despite scant evidence. On the day of her execution, at age 41, 12 rifles were pointed at her. She blew a kiss at the men holding them. -- Dave McGinn 

Photo: Associated Press

Moment in Time: Oct. 11, 1939: Roosevelt receives a letter -- The typewritten missive to the president of the United States was double-spaced, two pages long and signed by the world's most famous scientist. It arrived a month after the Nazis invaded Poland, warning Franklin Roosevelt that atomic physicists were close to turning uranium into a source of energy, which could lead to the creation of "extremely powerful bombs of a new type." Germany was already hoarding uranium from mines it controlled, Albert Einstein noted. Roosevelt immediately set up a committee to investigate the use of uranium - the initial step toward what would become the Manhattan Project. Six years later, Einstein's prophecy was complete. The world's first nuclear bomb was detonated in a test in the New Mexico desert. Weeks later, the U.S. used the new weapon in Japan. -- Joanna Slater 

Photo: NNSA

Moment in time: Oct. 9, 1973: Elvis and Priscilla Presley divorce -- The couple left court holding hands. Elvis and Priscilla Presley's divorce may have been anything but typical, but so was their relationship. They started dating when he was a soldier stationed in Germany and she was just 14. She moved into Graceland, without her parents, three years later, while still in high school. By the time Elvis's career surged again after his 1968 comeback special, they were married and had had Lisa Marie. But Elvis continued the lifestyle for which he had become famous - working hard, playing harder. He blamed travelling for his divorce - "I was gone too much" - but Priscilla saw it differently: "I lived somebody else's life. It was never about me; it was really about him on every level." If the marriage wasn't happy, the divorce was: The two remained close friends until Elvis's death in 1977. -- Noreen Rasbach

Photo: Associated Press

Moment in time: Oct. 7, 1985:  Hijacking of the Achille Lauro  -- Only one man died, yet the murder of 69-year-old Leon Klinghoffer, a retired Jewish businessman from New Jersey, has haunted the Palestine Liberation Organization for three decades. An obscure PLO affiliate, the Palestine Liberation Front, known for trying to infiltrate Israel by windsurfer, sailed for Haifa on the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro. Discovered on board, the team of four seized control of the vessel, ordered it to a Syrian port and demanded Israel release 50 Palestinian prisoners. Syria didn't let them land, and the group shot Mr. Klinghoffer, dumping him and his wheelchair overboard. PLO leader Yasser Arafat, recognizing a PR disaster, ordered the men to sail to Egypt and free the ship. They were to fly to a safe haven, but U.S. fighter jets forced their plane to land in Sicily, where they were tried for murder. -- Patrick Martin

Moment in time: Oct. 4, 1957: First episode of Leave it to Beaver airs -- The Grade 2 classroom consensus makes Beaver imagine the worst about a note from his teacher, and he plots his escape from civilization's constraints without knowing where he went wrong. Theodore "Beaver" Cleaver and Huck Finn had a lot in common. A 1950s TV series set in the absurdly normal town of Mayfield will never get the full Twain treatment, but the show's child-centred awkwardness with an over-ordered world transcended sitcom stereotypes. The storytelling was patient and pensive rather than jokey as Beaver's attempts to make sense of things constantly led him astray. Open the note? That would be dishonest, says his brother and moral guide, Wally, as they go to elaborate lengths to fake the obligatory evening bath demanded by their all-wise yet oblivious parents. -- John Allemang

Photo: Tony Dow as Wally and Jerry Mathers as Beaver.

Moment in time: Sept. 27, 1964: Warren Commission report released -- Who really killed JFK? Seven days after president John F. Kennedy was assassinated in Dallas, his successor, Lyndon Johnson, ordered an inquiry led by chief justice Earl Warren. The panel, which included future president Gerald Ford, reported back 10 months later and, in its 889-page bestseller, concluded that a lone shooter, Lee Harvey Oswald, had felled the president. Despite subsequent investigations and the release of voluminous documents, conspiracy theories abound about a second gunman and a series of suspects including the Mafia, Cuban exiles, the CIA, even Johnson himself. Such theories were fuelled in part by the commission's failure to explore and refute them, and by the CIA's destruction of classified information about what Ford later called "potentially damaging operations in danger of being exposed" at the inquiry.  -- Sandra Martin

Moment in time: Sept. 20, 1985: Lincoln Alexander becomes Canada's first black lieutenant-governor -- As the first black to hold a vice-regal post in Canada, he was a symbol of society's growing intolerance for racial prejudice. Lincoln Alexander, the son of a railway porter and a maid, was sworn in as Ontario's 24th lieutenant-governor at the age of 63. He had grown up in an era when blacks were denied the basic rights and opportunities enjoyed by whites, something he experienced first-hand when he could not get a sales job at Stelco - he was told customers would not want to deal with a black man. His appointment as the Queen's representative capped a distinguished career for the first black member of Parliament and the first black federal cabinet minister. "I want to believe it served as a beacon of hope for the black community," Alexander wrote in his memoir. He died last year, his beacon still bright. -- Karen Howlett 

Photo: Dennis Robinson/The Globe and Mail

Moment in time: Sept. 18, 1888, Grey Owl is born -- 
His books, films and lectures delivered a ground-breaking message about the importance of protecting Canada's wilderness. He enthralled tens of thousands as he toured North America and Britain - once addressing the future Queen. The eloquent plea came with a commanding personality: He wore a fringed buckskin outfit, lived in a cabin with beavers and described himself as the son of an Apache woman and a Scottish guide. But there were many shades to Grey Owl. Immediately after his 1938 death, the North Bay Nugget exposed him as a bigamist with no native ancestry. Archibald Belaney was born in England, moved to Canada as a teen, learned trapping in an Ojibwa community and dyed his skin and hair. Still, admirers hoped the false front would not detract from his truths: "You belong to nature, not it to you." -- Joy Yokoyama

Photo:  Lovat Dickson Collection/Library and Archives Canada

Moment in time: Sept. 12, 1977 -- Three weeks after being arrested under the Terrorism Act, Steve Biko was found dead on the floor of a Pretoria prison hospital. The South African government, knowing Biko's prominence among students and as founder of the black consciousness movement, claimed the 30-year-old had succumbed to a hunger strike. His autopsy revealed he died of a brain hemorrhage from head injuries, gleaning international headlines. In 1997, five former police officers confessed to a Truth and Reconciliation Commission that they had beaten Biko, who had been shackled naked for days and whose funeral drew 10,000 people. In 2003, justice officials said the officers - who claimed they beat Biko in self-defence, days before his death - wouldn't be tried due to insufficient evidence and too much time elapsed. -- Kathryn Blaze Carlson
