Moment in time: Sept. 11, 2001 -- At 9:27 a.m., the only remarkable thing about the San Francisco-bound flight was that it was about half an hour behind schedule. One minute later, 35,000 feet over Ohio, the nose of the Boeing 757 dipped violently. Four hijackers, who had boarded at Newark, N.J., commandeered the cockpit: United Flight 93 had become the fourth and final winged weapon in al-Qaeda's assault on America, a devastating attack that shattered the country's - and the world's - sense of security. The hijackers intended to destroy the Capitol or the White House. But as though the passengers knew that the country needed heroes more than victims, they staged a courageous attack on their captors, who were forced to ditch the plane in a field near Shanksville, Pa. It was the first salvo in the war on terror, and the early volunteers paid with their lives. -- Dennis Choquette

Photo: Tim Shaffer/Reuters

Moment in time: On this date in 1997, Mother Teresa died. So revered in life that her name became synonymous with virtue, Mother Teresa was overshadowed in death by the accident that killed her friend Princess Diana just days earlier. Born in Macedonia in 1910, Agnes Gonxha Bojaxhiu heard God's call at 12, took vows at 20 and went on to found a Catholic convent. She cared for the poor and dying in the slums of Calcutta, which earned her the Nobel Peace Prize and support for her beatification - a step toward sainthood. In later years, she was dogged by religious doubts and aspersions cast by the likes of Christopher Hitchens, who argued that given her opposition to abortion, contraception and painkillers, Mother Teresa was ''no friend to the poor.'' Nevertheless, the diminutive nun inspired generations of followers, many of whom can still be found ministering to the marginalized around the world. -- Genna Buck

Photo: Reuters
Today's editorial cartoon by Brian Gable

Moment in time: On this date in 2006, the Crocodile Hunter was killed. Steve Irwin had seemed invincible. For years, the animal conservationist best known for hosting TV's The Crocodile Hunter mesmerized audiences with his infectious enthusiasm and apparent disregard for his own safety. In khaki shorts and hiking boots, he stared down snapping crocodiles, danced with cobras and swam among sharks. But the 44-year-old Irwin's luck ran out in 2006, while diving near Australia's Great Barrier Reef, when a venomous bull stingray stung his chest - he was shooting a documentary, The Ocean's Deadliest. Irwin always figured he would die young, his wife, Terri, later said, but from a car accident, not an animal. Detractors accused the showman of unduly disturbing wildlife, but his reverence for animals was undeniable, and his desire to demystify their kingdom genuine. Crikey! Wasn't he a beauty? -- James Bradshaw

Photo: Greg White/Reuters

Moment in Time -- On this day in 1945, Japan formally surrenders.
The first man to sign the surrender document limped towards the table leaning heavily on a cane. He wore a top hat and white gloves, his strained presence a symbol of the nation he represented. Foreign minister Mamoru Shigemitsu had long opposed the war. Aboard the USS Missouri on that September day, he appeared frail and relieved to end the final front of the Second World War. Next came General Douglas MacArthur, the Supreme Commander of the Allied Forces. Oozing bravado, he signed with six pens that included a red one that belonged to his wife, before stepping in front of a microphone cluster. "Let us pray that peace be now restored to the world and that God will preserve it always," he announced to a group that included short-lived military allies representing China and the Soviet Union. "These proceedings are closed."  -- Patrick White

Moment in time: On this date in 1905, Ty Cobb debuted with the Detroit Tigers. His brilliance on the baseball diamond put him in a class by himself, but one tragic event ahead of his debut with Detroit sheds some light on his spikes-up approach to the game and to life. On Aug. 8, 1905, Cobb's mother fired a shotgun at what she thought was an intruder outside her bedroom window in small-town Georgia. Instead, it was Cobb's father who was shot dead, after he told his wife he'd be away all night. Ty never got over it, and channelled his rage into his fierce style of play. The inaptly nicknamed Georgia Peach (nothing sweet about him) went on to win 12 American League batting titles, post a career average of .367 and set multiple records. In 1936, he received the most votes of anybody elected to the first-ever class of the Baseball Hall of Fame. -- Mason Wright

Photo: Associated Press

Moment in time: On this date in 1968, a riot broke out at the Chicago Democratic convention. It was the most wrenching political convention America had ever seen -- bitter, divisive and violent, much of it broadcast live on national television. Earlier in the year, two towering figures had been assassinated: civil-rights leader Martin Luther King, Jr. and Senator Robert Kennedy, who was campaigning to become the Democratic nominee for president. By the time the convention took place, 10,000 anti-war protesters had gathered in Chicago, where they encountered more than 17,000 police officers and members of the national guard. The worst moments came on Aug. 28, in what was dubbed the Battle of Michigan Avenue: a full-on riot, where, amid thick clouds of tear gas, police beat protesters and bystanders alike. It was not until 1996 that the Democratic Party returned to the city for a nominating convention, trying to put ghosts to rest. -- Joanna Slater

Photo: Associated Press

Moment in time: On this date in 1979, the IRA killed Louis Mountbatten. Second cousin to the Queen, Lord Mountbatten had an illustrious military career, serving in the First and Second World Wars. He was the viceroy and then governor-general of India, and became Earl of Burma -- all of which made him a tempting target. While holidaying in Mullaghmore, County Sligo, in Ireland, Mountbatten ignored warnings from Irish police and went fishing in his boat, Shadow V. A 50-pound, radio-controlled bomb planted the night before blew up the boat, killing Mountbatten and three others. The Provisional Irish Republican Army took responsibility, saying the blast highlighted the British occupation of Northern Ireland. At Mountbatten's state funeral, military contingents from Canada, India, Burma, France and the United States were part of the procession. -- Anna Maxymiw

Photo: AP

Moment in time: On this date in 1935, William Aberhart and the Social Credit Party were elected in Alberta. Decades before Albertans were handed $400 in Ralph Bucks, a preacher turned premier promised citizens $25 a month in the Great Depression. Aberhart clinched power with the world's first Socred government nabbing 56 of 63 seats. "Alberta will kindle a world-wide torch," Aberhart wrote that day. But the $25 pledge, imagined as Alberta's homegrown economic stimulus, proved tricky. The province did not have the money and Aberhart could not get control of the banks. But the popularity of the evangelist, galvanized by the following for his radio broadcasts, trumped questionable economic theory. "Bible Bill" died in 1943, still in the premier's chair. The Socreds held power for 35 years and eight months, a provincial record that held until 2007. -- Carrie Tait

Photo: Canadian Press

Moment in time: On this date in 1825, Amor de Cosmos was born in Nova Scotia. He was born William Smith but changed his name in 1854 to Amor de Cosmos -- lover of the universe. A photographer who took portraits of miners, he moved to Victoria after gold was discovered on the Fraser River and started a newspaper, the British Colonist, which became a soapbox for his political views. Passionately advocating for the union of the two colonies of Vancouver Island and British Columbia, he entered politics in 1863, holding federal and provincial seats before serving as premier from 1872 to 1874. He was afraid of electricity and known for his emotional outbursts, which included crying jags during speeches. An early embodiment of the eccentric world of B.C. politics, de Cosmos was declared of "unsound mind" in 1895. Two years later, he died alone and largely forgotten. -- Mark Hume

Photo: Library and Archives Canada

Moment in time: On this date in 1812, Detroit, the future Motor City, was the springboard for the first American attack on Canada in the War of 1812. The offensive was short-lived: Despite outnumbering the region's British defenders by nearly two to one, Brigadier-General William Hull retreated to Fort Detroit as natives led by Chief Tecumseh harried his supply lines. British Major-General Isaac Brock seized the opportunity. What he lacked in troops, he made up for in cunning. Brock exaggerated the size and strength of the aboriginal force in letters he allowed to fall into Hull's hands. He dressed the Canadian militiamen in the distinctive uniforms of British regulars and paraded them before the fort's defenders. Unnerved, Hull raised the white flag. Brock had defeated a superior force without losing a man -- and proved Canada would not fall without a fight. -- Joel Eastwood

Photo: Parks Canada

Moment in time: On this date in 1925, Oscar Peterson was born. Duke Ellington called him the maharaja of the keyboard. Ray Charles said he could play like a [bleepity bleep]. Born in Montreal to parents from the West Indies, he arrived with the typical number of fingers, but put them to better use than most. In front of an ivory box, he was a jazz virtuoso, with a swinging method that was meticulous, but perhaps too dazzling for some. One critic was Miles Davis, the cool-blue trumpeter who took issue with what he saw as a derivative style. Grammy awarders disagreed with Davis on eight occasions, however, and jazz critic Gene Lees endorsed Peterson as "a summational artist." He died, at age 82, in 2007. His gravestone reads that he "lived and loved with joy and passion, dedicated to God, music and excellence." -- Brad Wheeler

Photo: Herb Nott & Co. Ltd.

Moment in time: On this date in 1990, a dinosaur called Sue gained immortality as the largest and most complete skeleton of a Tyrannosaurus rex ever found, 67 million years after thundering across the wilds of prehistoric South Dakota. Named for its discoverer, American Sue Hendrickson, the skeleton was auctioned off in 1997 for $7.6-million to Chicago's field museum -- ensuring that Sue was destined for scientific research and public display. Studies of the 90-per-cent preserved skeleton have helped cement the evolutionary link between theropod dinosaurs and modern birds, in part because Sue was the first T. rex found with a furcula -- a wishbone. Despite its name, Sue's gender remains in dispute. Less ambiguous are the signs of arthritis and multiple injuries that suggest life atop the food chain during the Cretaceous period was no picnic. -- Ivan Semeniuk

Photo: Sue Ogrocki/Reuters

Today's moment in time: Aug. 7, 1978: U.S. government declares state of emergency at Love Canal 

In the late 19th century, entrepreneur William T. Love dug a trench on the outskirts of Niagara Falls, NY., in preparation for a model city he envisioned. But funds dried up, he skipped town and decades later the hole proved a handy repository for chemical waste. In the 1970s, after houses and a school were built nearby, neighbours noticed developmental disabilities among their children, a rash of miscarriages and horrific diseases. Pregnant women and young children were evacuated and after the government declared a health emergency, hundreds of families fled. They left behind a model ghost town.

Today's moment in time: Aug. 2, 1918: Vancouver workers stage Canada's first general strike

By the hundreds, they downed tools to protest the death of Albert "ginger" Goodwin, a coal miner and labour activist. He has been shot to death after a police constable tracked him down. Goodwin had been called up for military service – a call up that came after he was previously deemed unfit and after he led workers in demands for an eight-hour day. Workers marked his death by staying off the job, returning soldiers stormed union headquarters and in the ensuing melee of Canada's first general strike, a labour leader was nearly thrown out the window.

Moment in time: On this date in 1934, John Dillinger was killed in Chicago. He had just finished watching a movie about a doomed gangster when he walked into a deadly trap. Federal agents gunned him down outside Chicago's Biograph Theater as his companions -- madam Anna Sage, labelled "the Lady in red" despite her orange skirt, and moll Polly Hamilton -- fled. It was a violent finale to a year-long run in which the Jackrabbit, known for hopping over teller counters, held up about a dozen banks, raided police arsenals and escaped jail twice. Craving the $25,000 reward and wanting to avoid deportation, Sage set off the theatre stakeout, but only got $5,000 and a one-way ticket to Romania. On display at the morgue, Dillinger's body drew 15,000 gawkers. -- Joy Yokoyama

Photo: Everett Collection

Moment in time: On this date in 1960, the first Etch A Sketch was introduced. On your next road trip, hand your kids a small red plastic rectangle with two white knobs at either corner and tell them it's the original iPad. Demonstrate that it will draw horizontal lines and vertical ones and, with some practice (say, over a four-hour-drive), it will also produce curves. On a much longer drive, they may even learn to draw the Mona Lisa. Insist that no, it is not the worst toy ever made, it is in fact one of the best, because it demonstrates that with great limitation comes great freedom. Show them the magic of shake and erase. Tell them that the Etch A Sketch was introduced 53 years ago and has remained virtually unchanged since, unlike their beloved iThings. Drive in blissful silence. - Elizabeth Renzetti, The Globe and Mail

Photo: George Vlosich/Rex Features

Moment in time: On this date in 1986, Kurt Waldheim was inaugurated as Austrian president. It may have been history's worst example of a fudged resume. Waldheim was one of the most respected people in the world, having served as Secretary-General of the United Nations for nearly a decade. During his campaign, people began to notice that his bestselling memoir, In the Eye of the Storm, had missed a few details, notably that he had been an active officer in the Nazi Wehrmacht when it was transporting the Jewish population of Southern Europe to death camps. The world reacted with outrage, but he still won the election in an Austria that was then unwilling to confront its Nazi past. His presidency was effectively boycotted by Western leaders. Waldheim denied participating in the atrocities, but in a letter published in German after his death in 2007, he regretted not speaking out more forcefully against the Nazi regime. 

Photo: Nora Schuster/Getty Images

Moment in time: On this date in 1826, Thomas Jefferson, right, and John Adams both died. Jefferson, a genteel libertarian, and Adams, a conservative from farming stock, forged a friendship in the summer of 1776 and, eventually, a country, with the drafting of the Declaration of Independence. When the Revolutionary War ended in 1783, their friendship did too. Adams accused Jefferson of atheism; Jefferson claimed Adams wanted to be king. They made peace a decade later, starting a 15-year correspondence that ended the day both died -- the 50th anniversary of the document that brought them together.

Photo: PR Newswire

Moment in time: On this date in 1980, O Canada was enshrined as the national anthem, a full century after composer Calixa Lavalee's Chant National debuted at a banquet on June 24, 1880. By then the country had tried out several English versions -- "O Canada! Our fathers' land of old" lost out -- and though Sir Adolphe-Basile Routhier's original French version remains unchanged, most of the current English lyrics were penned in 1908 by Robert Stanley Weir, a judge. By the 1920s, O Canada was played in schools alongside God Save the King; in 1967, a parliamentary committee recommended it be played "With dignity, not too slowly." But it took the National Anthem Act of 1980 to ensure that future generations of Canadians, from restless school children to triumphant athletes, would stand to attention for Lavalee's tune.

Photo: John Ulan/CP

Moment in time: On this date in 1997, Mike Tyson bit Evander Holyfield in a marquee Las Vegas fight. It was a rematch with front-page appeal: Iron Mike, a convicted rapist still seething from his previous loss to Holyfield, was hell-bent on retribution. But Tyson fell behind on points early, and in the third round, he bit Holyfield twice, tearing a chunk off of his opponent's ear. The fight had to be halted, and in ensuing days, endless replays of the savage act -- some say Tyson did it to be disqualified rather than suffer an embarrassing loss -- sucker-punched an already staggering sport. Now, hardly anyway knows the heavyweights' names.

Photo: Steve Marcus/Reuters

Moment in time: On this date in 1968, Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau was ending his first election campaign when he joined the reviewing stand at Montreal's St. Jean Baptiste parade. His staunch federalist views had not endeared him to Quebec nationalists. That night, protesters and police clashed in Lafontaine Park. As rocks and bottles landed near him, Trudeau famously refused to take shelter. Police arrested 290 people in what became known as the Lundi de la matraque (Trucheon Monday). A Globe and Mail reporter at the scene saw demonstrators being dragged away by the hair and children being injured. The next day, his tough-guy reputation cemented, Trudeau won a parliamentary majority. The following year's event was also marked by violence, so no official parade was held in Montreal for the next two decades.

Photo: Chuck Mitchell/CP

Moment in time: On this date in 1983, Sally Ride rocketed into space aboard the space shuttle Challenger. It was the journey of a lifetime and a turning point for the U.S. space program. She was the third woman to go into space, but thanks to a U.S.-centred media culture that had finally caught up to the idea, her mission carried far more resonance than those of her Russian predecessors. With a PhD in physics from Stanford University, Ride became an inspiration to young women the world over who dreamed of "reaching for the stars" -- her signature statement. That she was the first -- and only -- known gay astronaut emerged only after her death in 2012, a sign that social realities often lag light years behind technological achievement.

Photo: NASA/NYT

Moment in time: On this date in 1777, the continental Congress adopted the Stars and Stripes. A beautiful widow working as a seamstress in Philadelphia had received a visit from General George Washington. He had a patriotic task for her: putting needle to thread to fabric to produce the first flag of a new nation. The story turned Betsy Ross -- the eighth of 17 children born to a Quaker family -- into an American icon. But there's no documentary evidence supporting the tale. The account is rooted in a lecture that Ross's grandson gave to a historical society in 1870, nearly a hundred years after the Stars and Stripes became the official flag of the new republic. In a young country hungry for heroes, the story grew into a legend; the Betsy Ross house still draws tourists. As U.S. president Woodrow Wilson once reportedly remarked when asked about the tale: "Would that it were true."

Library of Congress

Moment in  time: On this date in 1987, Ronald Reagan called upon Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev to open up the Berlin Wall at the Brandenburg Gate. The U.S. president was losing a global popularity contest to Gorbachev, whose reformist policies of perestroika and glasnost were rocking the Kremlin. Europeans saw Gorbachev as more committed to ending the arms race. Reagan had come to set the record straight. "Mr. Gorbachev, open this gate. Mr. Gorbachev, tear down this wall!" Pravda was unimpressed. Reagan, the Communist daily said, had mistaken the Berlin Wall for the Wailing Wall.

Photo: Ira Schwartz/AP

Moment in time: On this date in 2002, Elizabeth Smart was kidnapped. As she lay asleep in her bed, she was awakened by a cold knife at her neck and the threat of a homeless street preacher who had sliced through a window screen: "Don't make a sound. Get out of bed and come with me, or I will kill you and your family." Brian Mitchell then led the 14-year-old to the foothills near her house in Salt Lake City, where he took her as a second wife and raped her. Nine months later, sharp-eyed motorists spotted the veiled teen with Mitchell and his other wife, Wanda Barzee, in a Salt Lake suburb. After initially lying to police, the girl was finally reunited with her family. Now married and working as a motivational speaker and children's advocate, Elizabeth Smart has written a memoir, to be released in the fall. Her captors are in prison. 

Photo: M. Spencer/Associated Press

Moment in time: On this date in 1896, Henry Ford tested his first vehicle. Like the Wright brothers' Flyer, Henry Ford's Quadricycle was the first step in an industrial journey that would change the world. It took Ford nearly two years to build his primitive car in a shed behind his Detroit home. The Quadricycle rode on skinny bicycle wheels, made four horsepower, had a top speed of 32 km/h -- and broke down on its maiden voyage through the streets. But before long, Ford would create the Model T and the biggest factory ever built -- the Rouge River complex churned out a car every three minutes. His mechanical mission would sweep aside the world he had known: The buggy whip, the family farm and the dirt road were on their way out, to be replaced by suburbs, superhighways and the age of mass consumption.

Photo: Associated Press

Moment in time: On this date in 1534, Jacques Cartier sighted Cape Bonavista on the coast of Newfoundland and Labrador. The Breton sea captain from Saint-Malo, France, had set sail 20 days earlier with two small ships and a crew of 61 men to explore the "new lands," hoping to find gold and other riches. He had been commissioned by the King of France, and had a reputation for being capable and courageous. This would be the first of three voyages to North America for the French explorer, who became the first European to map the Gulf of St. Lawrence and sailed up the river as well. Cartier is not only credited with claiming Canada for France, but with giving this country its name after hearing natives use the word "kanata," meaning town or village.

Moment in time: On this date in 2005, Steve Nash won the NBA's most valuable player award. You're not supposed to be voted MVP if you're a smallish guy, a soccer player's son, ignored by U.S. college hoops powers, a sociology major, floppy-haired and Canadian. Yet Steve Nash was a sublimely skilled dribbler, passer, pick-and-roll wizard and three-point marksman. He also helped drive the Phoenix Suns to their first conference final in more than a decade in 1985. When he won the award a second time the following year, the once-overlooked kid from Victoria cemented his status as one of the greatest point guards ever.

Photo: Jeff Topping/Reuters

Moment in time: On this date in 1885, Métis rebels battled Canadian soldiers at Fish Creek. The skirmish, also known as the Battle of Tourond's Coulee, took place in what is now Saskatchewan, 25 km south of Batoche, where Métis leader Louis Riel had set up a provisional government. Métis commander Gabriel Dumont, with just 200 men, used the natural trap of the river to ambush 800 Canadian soldiers under Major-General Frederick Middleton, forcing them to retreat. The victory was short-lived, however. More than two weeks later, the rebellion ended in a bloodbath at Batoche. Dumont escaped but Riel surrendered and was hanged.

Lithograph by Fred Curzon/Library and Archives of Canada

Moment in time: On this date in 2002, the first Canadian soldiers were killed in Afghanistan, the grief magnified because their deaths resulted from friendly fire. An American F-16 pilot and his wingman wrongly assumed that a scheduled Canadian Forces anti-tank exercise near Kandahar was an enemy attack. Although told to hold fire, Major Harry Schmidt dropped a laser-guided bomb that killed privates Richard Green and Nathan Smith, Corporal Ainsworth Dyer and Sergeant Marc Leger, and wounded eight others from the Princess Patricia's Canadian Light Infantry. Both Americans were disciplined, but charges were dropped.

Photo: Adrain Wyld/The Canadian Press

MOMENT IN TIME

April 12, 1945: Franklin Delano Roosevelt dies

When Franklin Roosevelt arrived at his retreat in the hills of Georgia in the spring of 1945, his health was already fragile. The world, meanwhile, was on the verge of momentous change: The war in Europe was nearly over, plans were underway for a final assault on Japan and the founding conference of the United Nations was weeks away. Roosevelt, just 63 and starting an unprecedented fourth term as president, would not live to see any of it. While sitting for a portrait, he complained of a sharp pain in his head – a massive cerebral hemorrhage – and died shortly after. As a shocked nation prepared to grieve, Vice-President Harry Truman approached Eleanor Roosevelt and asked what he could do for the family. She famously replied: "Is there anything we can do for you? For you are the one in trouble now."

On this date in 1973, the sexual revolution hit Major League Baseball when Yankee pitchers Fritz Peterson (front) and Mike Kekich, teammates and best friends, announced they had swapped not just wives, but children and pets as well. Rumour had it the libidinally challenged Peterson did not meet the expectations of his wife, Marilyn. Peterson and the former Mrs. Kekich, Susanne, remain married with children 40 years later, while Mike and Marilyn soon parted ways. 

Photo: Marty Lederhandler/AP

On this date in 1994, John Candy died in his sleep at the age of 43 after suffering a heart attack. He was one of the most recognizable Canadians in the world, creating TV characters as memorable as Johnny LaRue, Yosh Shmenge and Dr. Tongue. In 22 years, he appeared in 43 movies, including Wagons East, his final film.

Photo: Reuters

On this date in 1985, Holocaust denier Ernst Zundel was convicted. Charged with "spreading false news likely to cause social or racial unrest" in connection with two pamphlets that proclaimed the Holocaust was a fraud, Zundel based his defence on truth and free expression. Hundreds of spectators, including neo-Nazi sympathizers in yellow hardhats and Holocaust survivors, lined up each day to watch one of Canada's strangest trials.

Photo: Thomas Szlukovenyi/The Globe and Mail

On this date in 1993, terrorists attacked the World Trade Center. As the lunch hour began, an explosive device stashed in a van in an underground parking lot exploded, killing six people. Today, their names are inscribed together with nearly 3,000 others on bronze panels commemorating the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, and just beyond them sit the deep pools where both towers once stood. 

Photo: Richard Drew/AP

On this date in 1965, militant black leader Malcolm X was assassinated in a New York ballroom as he prepared to address an audience. The men convicted of his death were members of the black supremacist Nation of Islam, from which Malcolm, once a prominent spokesman, split acrimoniously months earlier. Afterward Martin Luther King, sometimes regarded as Malcolm's antithesis, spoke of his "deep affection for Malcolm." 

Photo: Library of Congress/Everett Collection

On this date in 1962, John Glenn became the first U.S. astronaut to orbit the Earth, doing it three times. "Boy, that was a real fireball of a ride," he exclaimed after splash-landing in Caribbean waters. He later served as an Ohio senator and failed in a presidential bid, but his milestone in racing the Soviets to space cemented his place in history.

Photo: The Associated Press

On this date in 1989, Iran's Supreme Leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini issued a fatwa against The Satanic Verses author Salman Rushdie and his publishers. "I call on all zealous Muslims to execute  them quickly, wherever they find them," Khomeini declared. Worldwide protests ensued. Rushdie escaped, living on the run under police protection for nearly a decade until subsequent Iranian authorities reluctantly cancelled Khomeini's fatwa.

Photo: Kaveh Kazemi/Getty Images

On this date in 1865, the U.S. House of Representatives passed the 13th amendment abolishing slavery. Although Republican president Abraham Lincoln opposed slavery, he had been willing to tolerate the status quo for reasons of national unity. As former slaves joined Union forces and military victory became certain, however, his politics caught up with his principles. 

Image: Emancipation by Thomas Nast, c. 1865.

On this date in 1978, the Soviet satellite Cosmos 954 broke up over Great Slave Lake in the Northwest Territories. For four months it had been straying from its orbit, coming ever closer to Earth, until it finally crashed, scattering radioactive debris across hundreds of kilometres of barren land. Reluctantly, Moscow agreed to cover $3-million of the $14-million cleanup. 

(Photo: Canadian Armed Forces/The Canadian Press)

On this date in 1896, the first X-ray machine was exhibited publicly.  A year earlier, German physicist Wilhelm Rontgen was shooting electrical currents through vacuum tubes when he discovered invisible rays penetrated a piece of cardboard placed over the tube and lit up a barium-coated screen with a fluorescent glow. Professor Henry L. Smith read about the findings and gave the first public demonstration in the United States. 

Photo: X-ray machine invented by General Electric inventor Elihu Thomson in 1896 (GE)

On this date in 1945, Adolf Hitler retreated to his bunker to direct the Third Reich's last stand. On April 30, he and his wife, Eva Braun, killed themselves. This is one of the last pictures taken of Hitler in his bunker. He shakes hands with Col. General Schoerner, appointed commander-in-chief of the non-existent Wehrmacht in Hitler's last will and testament. In the doorway is Hitler's adjutant, Julius Schaub. (AP Photo)
